story:
MAGGIE: Once, someone said my hair was “the loveliest thing of all.” So I cut it off. And I grew bad ideas instead – I got angry, I spat venom, I changed. Not to be heavy handed, but I really found the gorgon in me.

ABOVE: Medusa Waking advertising image with show dates and location.
 

Medusa Waking

Hello! We're Bad Company Theatre - a bunch of local artists who have come together to put on Medusa Waking, an exciting, original Tasmanian work.

  • On May 14th of this year, our production will be opening at the Peacock Theatre in Hobart, Tasmania.
     
  • We've put together an incredible team of emerging and established artists, helmed by the fantastic Natalie Venettacci in her directorial debut.
     
  • Medusa Waking is a magical realist story of a modern girl hiding in her bathroom. Over the course of the play, her world becomes intertwined with the myth of Perseus and Medusa. It's eerie, whimsical, and a little bizarre.
     
  • Medusa herself is iconic, and particularly in the last hundred years she's become incredibly meaningful to the feminist movement. This play gives a modern girl the opportunity to talk to her.
     
  • The story explores how mythology can be rediscovered, reclaimed, and readapted into narratives of healing. It's a story of recovery borne from the recovery of a story.
     
  • We strongly believe the stories of survivors are important to tell. Moreover, they're important to tell in a compassionate, careful and non-exploitative way. Truthfully, part of this work comes from a place of lived experiences that the creative team have survived, so we care very much about telling this story and telling it well.
     
  •  If 2020 taught us anything, it was about how desperately we love (and miss) live theatre. We've been working on this show for nearly a year and a half, and we're so, so ready to share it with you all.
     

Who we are:

  • Medusa Waking is an original work by local playwright Emma Skalicky, which she developed over two years as part of her Honours degree in playwriting. Emma has been published previously, via Currency Press for ATYP, so you know she can deliver. She's currently training to become a counsellor in an effort to help elevate safety standards in independent arts communities.
     
  • Our director, Natalie Venettacci, has spent the last couple of years studying under several prominent Tasmanian directors. This project will be an opportunity for her to implement the skills she has acquired and extend her own artistic practices. Natalie graduated Actors Centre Australia in 2015 and intends to bring the knowledge she obtained from her studies into the acting space.
     
  • Bad Company Theatre is a not-for-profit independent theatre group that is dedicated to supporting local emerging and established artists, and producing quality theatrical experiences for audiences across Tasmania. We support the incubation of developing projects, as well as experimental and established pieces - and we love it!
     
  • We've hired set, sound and lighting designers who have years of experience in upholding the integrity of a production. Two time Tasmanian Theatre Award winner Matt Skalicky will be composing music. For lighting, Chris McBride, who has designed lighting for festivals across the country, and the wonderful Liv Vermey will be acting as stage manager. Jared Goldsmith, a licensed local carpenter with a rich history within the theatre industry will be building the set.
     
  • As for the rest of the cast and crew, we have a fabulous bunch of newcomers and old hats, all of whom have been giving their all to this project since the end of 2019.
     
  • Email us at bctheatreco@gmail.com to find out more!
     

To summarise: We have a show. We have actors rehearsing and a crew working away. We have a theatre booked. This train is leaving the station, but we need your help making sure it gets to its destination

ABOVE: The cast and crew of Medusa Waking! (L-R) Heidi, Griff, Natalie, Catherine, Noah, Lizzie, Tai, Liv, and Simone.
 

What We Need

Asking for monetary support is simply never easy, but we've put our heads together and here's where we're at:

  • Bad Company Theatre is asking for $7,000 to help get Medusa Waking onto the stage. We believe this is enough to put on an aesthetically strong show, and afford our artists equitable payment. Money will be directly funnelled towards:
    • Theatre hire
    • Advertising
    • Set construction
    • Prop budget
    • Costume budget
    • Program printing
    • Making & shipping rewards
    • Artist fees
  • We want to be completely transparent - some of these things (such as theatre hire) are already being paid for, or will have to be paid for during our fundraising period. However, we are currently paying from our personal bank accounts (as we're sure many of you are experiencing firsthand, Job Seeker is not the most amazing arts resource). In those instances, the funds raised will cover the costs we've already personally sunk into the production.
     
  • In other instances (such as set construction) we simply can't make the show what it needs to be without more funds.
     
  • Our flexible fund goal ensures we can build this production around our available resources.
     

What you get

We really, really want to make it worth everyone's while to support this show, so we've rustled up a bunch of rewards we're excited to show you!

  • An A3 print of our original Medusa artwork, by Emma Skalicky.
    • Printed on 180gsm Matte Polyester Film.
    • Framed or unframed - you get to choose!
  • Hand printed (risographed) t-shirts of our Medusa design, printed by Tasmanian artist Leigh Rigozzi at Moonshed Moonah.
    • These t-shirts can be made for XS to 4XL, and come in white, yellow or pink t-shirt colours.
    • Because they are risographed, they are awesome quality and no two are ever quite the same. We recommend giving them an iron when they arrive, and washing in cold water only to protect the ink.
    • The design itself is printed in teal ink. In Tasmania, teal is the colour of SAAM (Sexual Assault Awareness Month - this April). It felt important to take that into consideration in the making of the shirts.
  • Vinyl cuts of the Medusa Waking sound design, as composed by Matt Skalicky.
    • Each record is 10" and 12 minutes per side, with a centre label and white sleeve.
    • Printed at smallrun.com.au in Melbourne.
    • Wanna hear the music? Here are two works in progress that will be included on the vinyl:
    • https://soundcloud.com/matt-skalicky/medusa
    • https://soundcloud.com/matt-skalicky/vastness

We've arranged for these perks to be organised in bundles to suit your needs:

  • Home Decor
    • ​A copy of the A3 art print, framed or unframed as per your preference.
    • Options to include add-ons.
  • Fashionista
    • A Medusa Waking t-shirt, in your choice of size and shirt colour (white, pink or yellow).
    • Options to include add-ons.
  • Gorgon
    • A Medusa Waking t-shirt.
    • A copy of the A3 art print.
    • Options to include add-ons.
  • Musicologist
    • A copy of the Medusa Waking Vinyl.
    • Options to include add-ons.
    • (Please note: the current turnaround for the vinyls is 8 weeks, we appreciate your patience. They'll be well worth it!).
  • Gorgophone
    • The whole shebang!
    • X2 Medusa Waking t-shirts.
    • An A3 art print.
    • X2 Discounted tickets.
    • Your name (in BOLD) in the program.
    • A backstage pass.
    • A copy of the Medusa Waking Vinyl.
  • Plus two optional add-ons:
    • Backstage Pass (self explanatory - come hang out with us!).
    • Patron of the Arts (your name mentioned in the program, and a discounted ticket).
    • Once you've purchased the add-ons, send us an email to organise your backstage tour and/or tickets at bctheatreco@gmail.com
       

ABOVE: Emma and Tai in their Medusa shirts. We need YOU!
 

ABOVE: Simone, Heidi, Lizzie and Liv in their Medusa shirts. Very swanky!
 

The Impact

The Practicalities

  • We're an independent theatre company, and what that means is sometimes our resources are pretty slim (alas!).
  • So, on a very practical level your support will help us cover theatre hire, set building, props and costuming - all the stuff a growing theatre company needs.
  • Because this is a magical realist play, atmosphere and spectacle are half the fun! So, the more access we have to funding, the craftier we can get.

  • On a more esoteric level, skills learned from our experience on this production will be passed on through our careers as teachers, workshop hosts, counsellors and local directors. We're keen to give back as much as we can.


The Cause

  • The heart of the project explores trauma, sexual assault and empowerment. As we mentioned earlier, part of this work comes from a place of lived experience, so it's incredibly important to us that our work is done well.
  • Funding ensures we can properly work in partnership with the Tasmanian Sexual Assault Support Service (SASS) to create a production that is compassionate, safe, and sensitive.


Artist Pay

  • Bad Company Theatre cares about paying our cast and crew. Regardless of funding and costs, we are determined to find a way to achieve this.
  • We are working with eight local performers and seven local crew members, all of whom are dedicated beyond words.
  • They each have a unique creative practice that will be extended by this production, but they deserve so much more than that. 
  • Ultimately, your support ensures not only the quality of the production, but also that everyone involved CAN be fairly rewarded for the love, time and energy they have devoted to putting Medusa Waking on the stage.
  • We'll be approaching this from the profit share angle, so the more funds we can raise the closer we can get to equitable pay for everyone involved.


We cannot overstate how much we value the community aspect of this opportunity. Bad Company believes that art cannot exist without a community to celebrate it. The support of you all is everything to us. 
 

Risks & Challenges

Theatre? In this climate? (Don't worry, we've got it covered).

The big one (COVID-19) 

  • While an outbreak might stop our season, our intention is to use whatever funds we have to revive it when it is safe to do so.
  • We keep up to date with all live performance guidelines, and have a thorough COVID Safety Plan to ensure our cast, crew, and audience are as safe as possible.
  • (Our producer is a microbiologist. Everything is sterile. EVERYTHING.)
     

MONEY MONEY MONEY

  • We have a thorough money management plan, to ensure our funds go exactly where they need to go.
  • This involves:
    • A detailed, itemised budget.
    • A nominated funds manager to keep an eye on things.
    • An approach that priorities a strong, essential foundation for the show, with space to expand should funds allow us.
    • A producer that loves excel spreadsheets.

Additionally, we have a long history of fiscal responsibility while producing theatre. Between our two producers, we have put on approximately 30 community and independent shows across a number of companies.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Of course, we completely understand that not everyone can afford to financially support us. If you want to help, here are some other ways you can do so: 

  • Keep an eye on our socials for other fundraising ventures. We'll be having a night at The Finders in April to sell some merch, and will be selling raffle tickets for a hamper of Tassie goodies down the line too.
  • Spread the word! Make some noise! It truly is amazing how powerful the grapevine can be.
  • Use the indiegogo share tools to let your friends and family know about this campaign.
  • Come and see the show, and tell your mates about it. The greatest thing we can do for our artists is rustle up a profit to share, and warm and supportive audience to cheer them on (that's you!)
  • Get your tix, and learn more about the show at https://www.trybooking.com/BOXBS

And that's all there is to it! We can't wait to see you on stage in May.

- The Bad Company Team

xxx

ABOVE: The Medusa team in their t-shirts.
 

Above: Medusa Waking print by Emma Skalicky.

story:
Overview

Help me get "The night that you stopped acting/ La noche que dejaste de actuar" to the stage!

Both personally and politically, I endeavor to embrace the moment as a woman, mother, and immigrant. I consider myself a worker in service of art, and I feel it is an individual’s power and self-knowledge that motivates everything. You cannot take political action or be part of any community and be the change if you are not doing yourself. This show is a testimony of all these changes and experiences as a specific woman in the performing arts.

Short Summary

My name is Anabella Lenzu and I'm a choreographer originally from Argentina, currently living and working in NYC since 2005.  

I have 30 years of experience working in Argentina, Chile, Italy and the USA, and I am the Artistic Director of Anabella Lenzu/DanceDrama.

 

Artist Statement:

Art is a political act.

Dance is discipline and revolt.

My body is my country.

I react to my environment and use the body as a receptacle and messenger of the multiple realities that we are immersed in. 

My work reflects my experience as a Latina/European artist living in New York and comes from a deep examination of my motivations as a woman, mother, and immigrant.

Performance is a conduit for examining cultural identity through form and content, as well as relationships between people and society.

Sharing my point of view of life with others is my duty and my pleasure.

As an independent choreographer with a dynamic company, it is a challenging and expensive venture to create work and perform in New York City,

In order to pursue a high-quality experience for artists and audiences alike, we have set a modest fundraising goal.

I invite you to participate in this goal and to share in the satisfaction of realizing a significant and meaningful process of exploration and discovery.

The Show

The night that you stopped acting/ La noche que dejaste de actuar, is a one-woman show which both questions and affirms the reality of being a creator, an artist, and a spectator. It's a reexamination of five key pieces of my repertory as well as an investigation of the very nature of the creative process, asking: "If a work of dance is created in the here and now, what happens when the here and now changes? How do the changes of our circumstances, our lives, and our bodies alter our approach as dancers and choreographers?" These are the questions from which the show was born.
My work reflects my experience as a Latina/European artist living in New York, and comes from a deep examination of my motivations as a woman, mother and immigrant.

For this show I am collaborating with: 

Direction: Daniel Pettrow

Technology advisor: Todd Carroll

Dramaturgy: Naoko Maeshiba

 

The Impact

The aim of this project is to explore issues of identity and agency as experienced by a contemporary artist who is also a woman, mother and immigrant. It is a search to define identity in a modern context, and discern the way in which I can shape my own agency through a post-colonialist lens.

In addition, I am looking for a way to use a performative language to engage with others in this dialogue.

I want to inspire others to embrace themselves. For me it’s about accepting who I am. That’s the whole thing. Embrace who you are in the present moment.

 

Risks & Challenges

Creating and performing new choreographic works is both challenging and expensive, but I  believe it is a worthy pursuit. Your steadfast support demonstrates your belief in the importance of creativity and art, and ensures Anabella Lenzu/DanceDrama’s continued existence.

Your support allows me more time in the studio and helps to partially pay my collaborators.

Art is about authenticity and identity.

Please join us and share in the satisfaction of underwriting a meaningful creative endeavor.

Thank you again for your continued support! With your financial support, I can continue to develop new works. I am very thankful for whatever you can give. 

 

Other Ways You Can Get Involved

Help us get the word out! Share this Indiegogo link with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc.  

Come to see The night that you stopped acting/ La noche que dejaste de actuar in NYC!

Work-in-progress:

  • Saturday, Feb 1 at 3pm, Draftworks at DansceSpace Project, St Mark Church. Free and open to all! http://www.danspaceproject.org/calendar/draftwo...
  • Monday, March 9 at 8pm, Movement Research at Judson Church. Free and open to all! Judson Memorial Church (55 Washington Square S New York, NY 10012)

World Premiere:

  • June 4-7, 2020 at La MaMa Moves Festival
    at La Mama (66 East 4th Street, New York, NY 10003)

I am very thankful for whatever you can give.  Other Ways You Can Get InvolvedHelp us get the word out! Share this Indiegogo link with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc.  Come to see The night that you stopped acting/ La noche que dejaste de actuar in NYC!Work-in-progress:

Saturday, Feb 1 at 3pm, Draftworks at DansceSpace Project, St Mark Church. Free and open to all! http://www.danspaceproject.org/calendar/draftwo...


Monday, March 9 at 8pm, Movement Research at Judson Church. Free and open to all! Judson Memorial Church (55 Washington Square S New York, NY 10012)
World Premiere:
June 4-7, 2020 at La MaMa Moves Festival at La Mama (66 East 4th Street, New York, NY 10003)

story:
The piece...

Soul Perchers is a new play written by Cody Stiglich, which will be produced this summer off-off Broadway as a part of NYTF Summerfest and directed by Stacey Schiller. Cody started writing this piece in 2018 and has been developing it through readings and workshops in the New York area. He was inspired to write this play after reading an article about Don Ritchie, an Australian man living on the edge of a cliff who regularly talks people off the ledge of a “notorious suicide spot”.  This fictional play explores hope, perspective, and the universal dilemma of being human. Despite the generational gap, Matt and Sam seek to understand each other and why they may have ended up here.

The goal...

Our goal is to create high quality work in order to produce the most authentic storytelling experience possible. We need your generosity and support in order to achieve this goal and fund the most important aspects of this production such as:

- Actor Pay

- Stage Manager Pay

- Technician Pay

- Insurance

- Props

- Set Design/Build

- Graphic Design

- Printing Services

- Rehearsal Space

- Casting

The recognition...

To show appreciation for our donors, we have created a system of recognition which will be included in the program of the show:

Platinum - $1000+

     - Name recognition in program

     - A hard copy of the program mailed to you 

     - Up to four complimentary tickets to the show

Gold - $500 - $999

     - Name recognition in program

     - A hard copy of the program mailed to you

     - Up to two complimentary tickets to the show

Silver - $100 - $499

     - Name recognition in program

     - A hard copy of the program mailed to you

Bronze - $99 and under

     - Name recognition in program

The end...

We are eternally grateful for your love and support. Please feel free to reach out with any comments or questions!

story:
WHAT: DREAM LOVE ESCAPE

A Remix of Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream

Directed by Rebecca Holderness

and Kate Kohler Amory

WHEN: September 3, 4, 5 | 11, 12 @ 7:00pm EST

60 minutes

WHERE: Derby Square- Salem, MA

Google Maps Link

WHO: Presented by The Ridiculous Project in partnership with Salem Public Art Commission/ City of Salem

Short Summary

We are theatre makers and storytellers, people who strive to bring truth and joy to our community through our performance work. Since 2014, The Ridiculous Project has produced theatre projects for Greater Boston audiences. We approach our work collaboratively and use explorative physicality and an experimental attitude to examine the highs and lows of the human spirit.

What is going to happen as we emerge from this period of isolation and disconnect and take those first steps back into community? How will we track what has changed? How can we begin to make sense of the experiences we’ve been through while also finding a way back together? 

In a moment where we are faced with so many questions, The Ridiculous Project invites you to join us in an exploration of story, whimsy, magic, and language through a radical examination of one of Shakespeare’s most-loved plays, A Midsummer Night’s Dream.  The interwoven stories and realities that Shakespeare conjures offer a narrative and linguistic playground for a spirited retelling that speaks to our moment, our communities, and offers a transformational experience of access and connection. The Ridiculous Project is building a playful, immersive, theatrical experience through adapting Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream into one of our own. Dream, Love, Escape brings us into space together to acknowledge where we have been and also to experience both the act of and the celebration of a communal process of emerging. But we cannot do it without you!

 

What We Need & What You Get

As an independent theatre company, we work as an ensemble to build and produce each show. This time, we are lucky to have a grant for this opportunity from the Salem Public Art Commission, which helps cover some costs and ensures the use of Derby Square for performance. Since many in our community of theatre makers are still without work, we were lucky to secure great talent in the cast, crew and design teams. Any funding we are able to raise allows us to pay our artists a better stipend for their many hours of time, find funding for our favorite design elements, ensure a rain plan, and ultimately keep our theatre company alive for the next show!

 

Since Dream, Love, Escape will be performed in a public square, no tickets are being sold. We hope that you are able to support this project with any donation, knowing that it goes directly to the artists working on this project. If we do not reach our $2,000 goal, we will pay out of pocket for things like transportation and housing for our company. Any surplus in our budget will be evenly distributed between all company members.

 

The Impact

We may be biased, but storytellers and artists of all kinds seem to be the world changers we need these days. While many theatre companies and venues did not survive the pandemic shut downs, our small company was able to keep a light on at the end of the tunnel. The opportunity for our actors to be on stage is a miracle in itself. The magic and intrigue of this show provides the opportunity to explore our own desire for connection and escape in a moment that has been saturated by isolation and disruption. 

In 2014, we launched our first performance thanks to a previous crowdfunding campaign. The show, The Birds by Artisophanes is a fantastic comedy about the journey of two malcontents as they try to escape life and end up creating what they are running away from. The show went up at The Factory Theatre in Boston and was a success thanks to our donors!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially, you are still able to be a part of our success. Please share this campaign on your social media, follow our social media pages, invite your friends and spread the word! 

The show is FREE to the Public, so we hope to see you there.

story:
Overview:

 

The Convergent Circus is an interactive art and theatrical experience located in Carbondale, CO at the base of Mount Sopris where the flowing waters of the Crystal River and Thompson Creek converge.

Audience members will walk through a half-mile of site-specific outdoor environments. The land will be transformed into a fantasy world influenced by the four elements: fire, water, air, and earth, to portray thought-provoking concepts from the past, present, and future. Each element will showcase various artists and performance vignettes, ensuring an experience unlike anything else. 

The production opens Wednesday September 22, 2021 with an opening ceremony and additional rituals celebrating the autumnal equinox.  Shows run nightly through Saturday, September 25, which will have an after party to close out the event.

We need help with funding to offer the various artists and performers fair wages, and to cover costs of supplies, permitting, labor, and more.

Imagine a Portal that Takes You into a World of Performance and Immersive art.

The Purpose: 

The intention behind this event is to present a unique experience for both creatives and attendees.  We aim to learn from, and honor the past, celebrate the present, and inspire a brighter future.

Additionally this event is a fundraiser for Carbondale Arts, which is a local non-profit that builds a vibrant community through the arts, supporting the Roaring Fork Valley’s identity as a place that fosters creativity, collaboration, innovation and artistic exploration.  Carbondale Arts offers arts education programming and events to communities throughout the valley with a focus on inclusivity for all. 

The Challenge: 

This is the premiere of Convergent Circus, a large-scale production offering creative opportunities for 30+ artists, performers and healers. Costs incurred from an event of this caliber are immense and we need your help!  All contributions from this campaign go directly toward compensating artists and covering costs of installations.  In order to pull off this project, we need to raise a minimum of $25,000. 

All donations are Tax Deductible and will run through Carbondale Arts, which is a 5o1c3.

 

The Collaborators

See the list of collaborators and producers below. We are continuously adding to this list and are so grateful to all of the people supporting this project.

Come along on this unique journey based on the elements, traditions, explorations of self, history, community, and art. Check out the amazing perks, contribute if possible and support this wonderful project through sharing and spreading the word!

story:
Short Summary

As the world of Mystwood expands we find that we have outgrown the existing NPC storage. Excitingly, Mystwood chapters also acquired a large number of new props from another larp in Massachusetts that recently ended. While we look forward to using these new items, we are now faced with the challenge of storing them. 

The current NPC storage is packed, quite literally, to the rafters which makes organizing our existing costuming, props, and weapons a constant challenge. It also makes us pause any time we considered adding new items to our inventory. Do we have room for it? If it is too big to fit in a tote, could we hang it from the rafters? Will one of the game masters have to store it at their home between events?

 

What We Need

Our goal is to raise $850 for a new shed and shelving. We would also like to accomplish the following, as stretch goals: dedicated weapon and armor storage, costuming, and weapons for both chapters.The primary goal is for the Mystwood chapters to purchase a new shed to alleviate our current storage struggles and allow us space to grow. We also plan to purchase shelving and organization solutions to ensure that we can easily store and locate items, including dedicated weapon and armor storage. If we aren’t able to reach our full funding goal, all funds raised will be put towards the shed and storage first, followed by costuming, weapons and then additional storage. Any funds raised beyond this expansive list of needs will be allocated to Mystwood Burgundar for future projects. 

Additionally, as Mystwood grows, we find the need to diversify our costuming. We are looking to purchase cloaks, hats, as well as costuming for colder weather later in the year. These cold weather items can also be used by Novgorod in it’s games. 

Our third priority is general weapons for both chapters. Over the years we have had to retire a number of weapons as they became unsafe. As we grow, we also need more weapons to put in the hands of our loving volunteers.

 

Our Budget

 

The shed we would like to purchase is about $500. We will need to have it delivered, which is an additional cost. The first $600 raised will be dedicated to the shed. Beyond the shed, we will need to purchase storage solutions in order to use this shed to its maximum potential. This includes shelving, totes, and filing cabinets. Our next $250 dollars will be dedicated to these storage solutions. If we get beyond our goal we would like to spend $200 for weapon storage constructions, $200 on costuming for colder weather, and $200 for weapons.

Risks & Challenges

Overall, the biggest challenge we face will be the actual task of assembling the new shed and then moving and organizing our props into it. Some of our props are currently in temporary storage at various people’s homes and will need to be transported to site. 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

We will need help constructing the shed, and moving/organizing our costuming. Helping us accomplish these tasks, once our project is funded is another great way to help. 

 

Another way to help is by sharing this fundraiser on social media. 

 

Stretch Goals:

If we are able to reach these goals additional community wide rewards will become available in game. 

 

$1000 - At this level we will be able to fund additional dedicated weapon and armor storage. 
Perk: Olaf One-Eye the Traveling Merchant Prince of Karelia will expand his mercantile empire into the March of Lucevel. Once per game Olaf will arrive in town allowing players to do their buy/sell in town without needing to journey to NPC. He will also have mundane goods and items for sale.

 

$1200 - At this level we will be able to purchase cold weather costuming for those late fall and winter games when everyone just wants to huddle around the fire. 
Perk: Olaf One-Eye the Traveling Merchant Prince of Karelia will continue to expand his mercantile offerings. He will now be able to offer goods from distant lands and will actively seek to buy commerce tagged items. 

 

$1500 - At this level we will be able to purchase new weapons to replace our aging items and expand our weapon cache. 
Perk: Olaf One-Eye the Traveling Merchant Prince of Karelia will now offer additional goods for sale and bring with him one rare magical to be sold in a raffle.

 

Unlocked Hidden Stretch Goals:

 

$2000 - At this level we will be able to invest in some large monster costumes, such as yeti and Minotaur.  

Perk: The reclusive Old Baba, rumored to know secrets and stories otherwise lost to time has been seen wandering the woods of late. For the right price, they can be convinced to share their knowledge.

story:
Hey! 

 

We're Jo and Aaliyah and we are taking Aaliyah's first full-length play to the Camden Fringe Festival, ready for it's premiere. The play is about black female empowerment and strength, as our lead character Mary runs her family-owned hair salon in Brixton, London. The play looks back to the New Cross fire in 1981, and how generations are still impacted today. 

Our show is going to The Cockpit at the Camden Fringe Festival on the 9th and 10th of August 2021, and we need to fundraise to help us pay for the venue, the set, and to help us to pay our very deserving, talented cast and crew. This script has been researched and developed for two years, and it's time to take it to the stage for audiences to see! 

Representation, diversity, and organic narratives are at the heart of this production; It's an all black/mixed race cast of women, and our core production team are also black and mixed-race women. How often do you see that? We deserve a place on that stage, and we would love if you could help us make that dream come true! 

We are aiming to reach £3,000. If we don't manage to get to this, we will use what we have fundraised to go towards the above aspects, and we will attempt to fund the rest ourselves. The dream will not stop here. We have perks set up in return for your donations! (Or you can just choose to donate without a perk attached). 

Even a £1 donation helps us get to our goal. If you cannot donate, sharing the campaign will still help us,  because someone else may be able to! Don't worry, we understand struggling artists/students... we are those ourselves! 

Come and join our fantastic hair salon where music plays, conversation flows, and history is made. You never know what might happen!

story:
What Are We Doing?

Over the past year and a half, Home Theatre Productions has been working closely with three emerging Canadian playwrights to develop their scripts. The playwrights and our dramaturgs have put countless hours into advancing the scripts, and now it is time for us to move into the next phase of development... It's time to bring these plays to the public! Home Theatre Productions will be presenting a reading of each play in order for the playwrights to receive feedback from both directors and an audience. The date and venue of this reading will be confirmed in the upcoming weeks! Read more about the plays below. 

 “Potion Ethics” by Emily Stuchbery, is a comedy focused on themes of sexual consent in an intergenerational context. The play follows a family of witches during a time of heightened tension in the witch community. As the local witches' coven debates the ethics of selling love potions, the witches must decide for themselves what they value as a family, and what the concept of sexual and romantic “consent” really entails.

“Grow Up” by Paul Drotos, is a far more tragic story. The play follows a group of teens as they hide in a bunker from the outside world. The “outside world” is filled with adults who turn into zombies as they come of age. The play works within post-apocalyptic story tropes in many ways to encourage the audience to question what the concept of “life” really means.

“Four Aloof Sleuths” by Vitta Morales, is a detective story set in Montreal in the 1990s. Within the bounds of this genre, it tackles issues such as police corruption, the concept of justice, and asks the audience to question preconceived notions of what living in a "developed nation" like Canada really means.

What We Need

Presenting a reading is expensive! Read more about what we need funds for below.

  • A venue for the reading. As theatres begin to open in Montreal, we are so excited to be able to host a live, in-person reading. However, due to COVID-19 seating capacity, we are looking into a larger venue than would usually be necessary. We want to bring these plays to as much of the public as we can, while keeping our cast, crew and audience safe. 
  • Payment for actors. Actors work hard, and they deserve to be paid appropriately! For the three plays we will be hiring ten actors, several of whom will work on multiple plays. 
  • Payment for the stage manager and other technicians. The people who work behind the scenes are just as important as those who are visible, and they deserve to be paid as such. 
  • Payment for directors. One of the most valuable aspects of hosting a reading is having professional directors who can give our playwrights more feedback on their scripts. However, this means we need money to pay them!
  • Rehearsal space. Even a staged reading needs some rehearsal time, which means paying for studio space. 

The Playwrights

Curious about who our playwrights are? Read more below!

Carlos (Vitta) Morales is a Montreal based musician and playwright. Originally from Fredericton, New Brunswick, Vitta moved to Montreal to attend the Schulich School of Music where he graduated with a concentration in jazz drumming. During his studies, Vitta started to develop an affinity for theatre and would go on to write his most notable play to date: Brunch! The Musical. This original musical comedy was staged twice in 2018, having participated in the Mcgill Drama Festival and Halifax Fringe Festival; the performances were described as “vibrant” by the Mcgill Tribune, and “fun and energized” by The Coast. Vitta tries to incorporate his drumming into his plays by making a point to showcase the more “musical” side of dialogue; always striving to be conscious of its rhythmic aspects. Vitta continues to develop and workshop new scripts but outside of playwriting, much of his time is spent bandleading and writing for the surf rock band King Lobster Krew, and working as a music rights administration consultant for various clients.

Emily Stuchbery is originally from B.C. and has spent the last four years pursuing a Cultural Studies degree at McGill University. A lover of fiction in all its forms, she owes her love of theatre in particular to her fourth-grade production of Charlotte’s Web. Since then she has worked on both the technical and creative sides of numerous productions throughout high school and university (some highlights include: Spring Awakening, The Wizard of Oz, and Jack and the Beanstalk: A Christmas Pantomime). Potion Ethics is the first play she has successfully completed as a solo playwright. In the past she has worked collaboratively on an original production entitled Grimm is the New Black (Penticton Secondary School 2015), as well as on some original comedy sketches, short films, and of course some non-sensical plays she wrote with her brothers as a child on family vacations. She is the author of many poems and unfinished novels that very few people have seen and is beyond grateful for the opportunity Home Theatre has provided for her to grow as a writer and to share some of her work with a wider audience.

Paul Drotos is a 24-year-old Canadian improviser by trade that was told by his drama teacher not to pursue improv. He wrote "Grow Up" after being told that without a background in proper drama or writing, it would be hard for him to successfully write a play. Paul is, incidentally, terrible at listening to people.

Other Ways You Can Help

Covid has been hard on everyone, and even if you don't have the means to financially contribute, you can still help us out!

  • Share this campaign on your social media! Every little bit gets us closer to our goal.
  • Follow us on Facebook and Instagram (@hometheatreproductions) to stay up to date on all of our projects.
  • Come to the reading! The playwrights need an audience to give them feedback on their work. We will post the date and location to this campaign once the venue is confirmed. 
  • Email us at hometheatreproductions@gmail.com to get involved!
story_txt:
What Are We Doing?
Over the past year and a half, Home Theatre Productions has been working closely with three emerging Canadian playwrights to develop their scripts. The playwrights and our dramaturgs have put countless hours into advancing the scripts, and now it is time for us to move into the next phase of development... It's time to bring these plays to the public! Home Theatre Productions will be presenting a reading of each play in order for the playwrights to receive feedback from both directors and an audience. The date and venue of this reading will be confirmed in the upcoming weeks! Read more about the plays below. 
 “Potion Ethics” by Emily Stuchbery, is a comedy focused on themes of sexual consent in an intergenerational context. The play follows a family of witches during a time of heightened tension in the witch community. As the local witches' coven debates the ethics of selling love potions, the witches must decide for themselves what they value as a family, and what the concept of sexual and romantic “consent” really entails.
“Grow Up” by Paul Drotos, is a far more tragic story. The play follows a group of teens as they hide in a bunker from the outside world. The “outside world” is filled with adults who turn into zombies as they come of age. The play works within post-apocalyptic story tropes in many ways to encourage the audience to question what the concept of “life” really means.
“Four Aloof Sleuths” by Vitta Morales, is a detective story set in Montreal in the 1990s. Within the bounds of this genre, it tackles issues such as police corruption, the concept of justice, and asks the audience to question preconceived notions of what living in a "developed nation" like Canada really means.

What We Need
Presenting a reading is expensive! Read more about what we need funds for below.


A venue for the reading. As theatres begin to open in Montreal, we are so excited to be able to host a live, in-person reading. However, due to COVID-19 seating capacity, we are looking into a larger venue than would usually be necessary. We want to bring these plays to as much of the public as we can, while keeping our cast, crew and audience safe. 

Payment for actors. Actors work hard, and they deserve to be paid appropriately! For the three plays we will be hiring ten actors, several of whom will work on multiple plays. 

Payment for the stage manager and other technicians. The people who work behind the scenes are just as important as those who are visible, and they deserve to be paid as such. 

Payment for directors. One of the most valuable aspects of hosting a reading is having professional directors who can give our playwrights more feedback on their scripts. However, this means we need money to pay them!

Rehearsal space. Even a staged reading needs some rehearsal time, which means paying for studio space.

Since then she has worked on both the technical and creative sides of numerous productions throughout high school and university (some highlights include: Spring Awakening, The Wizard of Oz, and Jack and the Beanstalk: A Christmas Pantomime). Potion Ethics is the first play she has successfully completed as a solo playwright. In the past she has worked collaboratively on an original production entitled Grimm is the New Black (Penticton Secondary School 2015), as well as on some original comedy sketches, short films, and of course some non-sensical plays she wrote with her brothers as a child on family vacations. She is the author of many poems and unfinished novels that very few people have seen and is beyond grateful for the opportunity Home Theatre has provided for her to grow as a writer and to share some of her work with a wider audience.

Paul is, incidentally, terrible at listening to people.

Other Ways You Can Help
Covid has been hard on everyone, and even if you don't have the means to financially contribute, you can still help us out!

Share this campaign on your social media! Every little bit gets us closer to our goal.
Follow us on Facebook and Instagram (@hometheatreproductions) to stay up to date on all of our projects.
Come to the reading! The playwrights need an audience to give them feedback on their work. We will post the date and location to this campaign once the venue is confirmed. 
Email us at hometheatreproductions@gmail.com to get involved!

story:
The Miss Karla's Side documentary is essentially passion project from the Director of this film, Tessa. It's a documentary surrounding a very small dance school in Melbourne, on the Mornington Peninsula and by extension, surrounding the teacher. As someone who started with this school when I was three, and are now more than half way through the 20th year, I want to explore the culture of the school, and foster that emotional connection with audience that I have with the school - as together we imagine and explore what the future will be following Karla's retirement, and in a Post-Covid world.

Miss Karla's Side will document the legacy of a dance teacher, and her dance school, post her retirement. The emotional documentary will give a window into the past; introduce where Karla's journey first began as a dancer, and the establishment of her school. The past then flows into the present and the future, where the current climate has left the school, and after her retirement, questioning what sort of legacy she will be leaving behind for her students, the parents, and the future principals of her school.


As it is a very small documentary, we are planning to have a very bare-bones crew for most days on the set. Most of which have already agreed to take on the project. 

Meet our heads of department!

***

Director: Tessa

A Trimester 4 Film and TV student with background in Business (Marketing) and Media and Communication (Creative Writing). My first experience with Documentary film-making, Fostering Greys, was nominated for a Martini Award in 2021 - and I am extremely interested in Cinematography and working with lights.

Producer: Claudia

With experience Producing for short films, I am a Film and TV student in Trimester 4. My focus has been working primarily with actors, and have focusing my efforts to building skills in Producing and Directing.

Director of Photography: Kasia

Kasia/Kat is a Trimester 4 student at JMC Academy. She has previously performed in the role of DOP on several creative projects and is excited to take on the role again on a documentary production.

Head of Sound Department: Liam

A Trimester 4 Film and TV student at JMC Academy, Liam was previously head of the sound department for the short film Unprecedented Times. He has since focused on music videos, cinematography, and camera-work. However, he has worked on documentaries before, and is really excited to take on this project.


As it is a small production, the above budget is including only the necessities to complete this project! Check out the budget breakdown below!

Studio Hire: Due to the small nature of the school, the for one of the days of shooting we are required to hire an external dance studio to film of a ballet class with Karla teaching. For the 8-9 hour day it is $25 per hour, it totals to $175. Additionally, for rehearsal time there is an additional 2 hours at $25 an hour to hire this location separately to the shoot.

Catering: As a four day shoot is planned, two of those days consist of travel and interviews with a very small crew (5 people). The catering budget has been allocated for the other two days - with the majority of it put towards for the one full day of filming at the dance studio, with a crew of 10 and a range of 5-25 dancers.

Composer: As music is such an important aspect of dance, it was important that we find music that is more than just royalty free/generic. Our composer, Daniel Lee - is an Australian Musician and Sound Producer that has been contracted to provide music for the full 8-9 minute documentary.

Travel: With two days of driving around for interviews, the travel cost we need to account for is one car for the 5 person crew to be traveling from home and then around to each interview.

Misc: These miscellaneous fees are accounted into the budget in order to allow for the crowdfunding platform fee and and rounding the budget up to have that wiggle room in case there are last minute charges we need to account for.

Essentially, this project will have to have enough to cater for the crew and dancers, and to pay for studio hire for that one specific day within the 4 day shoot ($70 Catering for 1 day, $175 Studio Hire for 1 day).

We're going to do our best to keep all our contributes updated, but if you want to see us more closely- follow us on social media!

Here's the link to our Instagram
Here's the link to our Facebook page

Anymore questions? Email us!

mksdocumentary@gmail.com

***

We would love it if you could join us in the journey to create this project, but if you can't  - that's okay! If you could follow us on social media and share this campaign if you can. Everything helps!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Anabella Lenzu and I'm a choreographer originally from Argentina, currently living and working in NYC since 2005.  

I have over 27 years experience working in Argentina, Chile, Italy and the USA and  I am the Artistic Director of Anabella Lenzu/DanceDrama.

 Artist Statement:

  • Art is a political act.
  • Dance is discipline and revolt.
  • My body is my country.

I react to my environment and use the body as a receptacle and messenger of the multiple realities that we are immersed in. 

My work reflects my experience as a Latina/European artist living in New York and comes from a deep examination of my motivations as a woman, mother, and immigrant.

Performance is a conduit for examining cultural identity through form and content, as well as relationships between people and society.

Sharing my point of view of life with others is my duty and my pleasure.

As an independent choreographer with a dynamic company, it is a challenging and expensive venture to create work and perform in New York City,

In order to pursue a high quality experience for artists and audience alike, we have set a modest fundraising goal.

I invite you to participate in this goal and to share in the satisfaction of realizing a significant and meaningful process of exploration and discovery.

 

The Show

I investigate the interior logic of performance and the role of a dancer in our culture today, redefining the parameters of dance and theater.

I have arrived at a moment where I am 41 years old, have two kids, notice my body aging, and reflecting on other changes psychologically and emotionally. This new show is about recognition, and reframing myself one more time.

Over the years, I have found out things about myself in terms of how and to whom I give: as a mom I give to my kids, I give to my students, I give to my company members. Now I am giving myself attention and care (as well as some challenges), something I have not done for a long time.

I feel that this show is a testimony to all these changes and experiences as a specific woman in the performing arts. One concept I've had to re-evaluate is the idea of what a dancer needs to look like, because there is a certain expectation of physical beauty in the world of trained ballerinas. In this new work, I examine my wrinkles, my boobs and belly as if it was an inspection. My body is a testimony to all the changes in my life and it shows the passage of time, leaving a map of my experiences.

I am interested in two things; the body as a container and the body as a tool.

I use two live-streaming cameras, two projectors and two laptops. One camera is above and one below. I view technology in this piece as if it were a magnifying glass, showing something normally hidden from normal view.

The cameras become a portal to another dimension (especially close up), that you can’t see in a regular live performance in such detail. Seeing the performance live, from close up and from far away with different angles adds depth and new possibilities of engagement.  

 The camera frames the dancer (myself) with another intention, another point of view in how it captures life and movement. I can offer the audience 3 different readings of myself. The audience member decides what point of view to see and when.

I love to work and collaborate in an atmosphere of creativity, respect, responsibility, honesty, independence and freedom.

For this show I am collaborating with: 

  • Todd Carroll: Photo and Video Projections Design
  • Dina Denis and Salvatore Cataldo: Dancers and collaborators in the creative process.
  • Daniel Pettrow: Acting and Voice Coach
  • Jennifer Johanos: Costume Designer

 

The Impact

The aim of this project is to explore issues of identity and agency as experienced by a contemporary artist who is also a woman, mother and immigrant. It is a search to define identity in a modern context, and discern the way in which I can shape my own agency through a post-colonialist lens.

In addition, I am looking for a way to use a performative language to engage with others in this dialogue.

I want to inspire others to embrace themselves. For me it’s about accepting who I am. That’s the whole thing. Embrace who you are in the present moment.

 

Risks & Challenges

Creating and performing new choreographic works is both challenging and expensive, but I  believe it is a worthy pursuit. Your steadfast support demonstrates your belief in the importance of creativity and art, and ensures Anabella Lenzu/DanceDrama’s continued existence.

Your support allows me more time in the studio, and helps to partially pay my collaborators.

Here is my creative process: I go to the studio, I improvise by myself 6 to 8 hours, I look at the videos, I take notes on the movement material that I consider interesting. I call the dancers, I organize the material on their bodies because I need to be able to get distance to work on my craft -meaning space, time, energy, all the articulations. I organize the design. After that, I re-learn the choreography myself and I do it.  It’s as if I am an architect creating a house. It starts out specific, but I arrive at a universal message.

The things that you want to hide when you dance – that’s what I am going to show!

Art is about authenticity and identity.

Please join us and share in the satisfaction of underwriting a meaningful creative endeavor.

Thank you again for your continued support! With your financial support I can continue to develop new works. I am very thankful for whatever you can give. 

 

Other Ways You Can Get Involved

  • Help us get the word out! Share this Indiegogo link with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc.  
  • Come to see " No more beautiful dances" in May 2018, in NYC!

Other Ways You Can Get Involved

Help us get the word out! Share this Indiegogo link with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc.  
Come to see " No more beautiful dances" in May 2018, in NYC!

story:
What is Fandango?

Fandango was created by British actor Joe Layton and American actress Kate Franz. From a passion for making their own work, a desire to create something with a message that matters, and a dream of performing at the Edinburgh Fringe, Fandango was born. Using a shared interest in sexual politics, their own life experiences, and stories of people they've met, they created the story for Partial Nudity. 


What is Partial Nudity about?

A Bolton pub. One stag do. One hen do. Two strippers forced to share a makeshift dressing room. For Darren, a local lad, this will be his first full strip. For Nina, an international student at Manchester, it’s just another stag to pay off her student loans. Over the course of this claustrophobic 50-minute drama, these two strangers descend into a territory that leaves the audience feeling as exposed as they are. An intense exploration of gender roles and power.


Who's on board?

Emily Layton Writer/Director
Having graduated from Cambridge, Emily made her debut at last year's Fringe with her playTwo Thirds. Since then she has moved to London, where she enrolled on the Old Vic New Voices writer's program. She also works as a freelance producer. Her work this year includes independent feature Chubby Funny and web series Post Coital. 

Kate Franz Actor
Kate earned her BFA in Acting from the competitive Emerson College in Boston, MA. Since moving to New York, she has balanced television and commercial jobs with creating her own work. 

Joe Layton Actor
Joe trained at Drama Centre, graduating in 2013. Since then he has worked predominantly in television, starting out alongside Jamie Dornan and Joe Dempsie in Channel 4's New Worlds and most recently starring in BBC3 and BBC America's hit series Thirteen.

What is the Edinburgh Fringe?

The Edinburgh Fringe is the largest arts festival in the world, showcasing theatre, comedy, dance, and music every August in Edinburgh, Scotland. Check out their website here.


Why do we need your donations?

This is a self-funded project. Which means, it's all our own money. And by all our own money, we mean every penny that we have- and some pennies that we don't. That's where you come in. We're very passionate about this story and its message, and about making our own work. With your help, we can ensure that Partial Nudity is the best show it can be, and continue making work that matters.


Other Ways You Can Help

Friends- if you cannot donate, there are other ways to support us! Share this page with others, follow us on social media, or come see the show!

Instagram - Twitter - Facebook Page - Facebook Event - Tickets

Since then he has worked predominantly in television, starting out alongside Jamie Dornan and Joe Dempsie in Channel 4's New Worlds and most recently starring in BBC3 and BBC America's hit series Thirteen.

    Why do we need your donations? This is a self-funded project. Which means, it's all our own money. And by all our own money, we mean every penny that we have- and some pennies that we don't. That's where you come in. We're very passionate about this story and its message, and about making our own work. With your help, we can ensure that Partial Nudity is the best show it can be, and continue making work that matters.


    Other Ways You Can Help Friends- if you cannot donate, there are other ways to support us! Share this page with others, follow us on social media, or come see the show!
Instagram - Twitter - Facebook Page - Facebook Event - Tickets

story:
Short Summary

My name is Noga Yechieli and I am the writer/director of Let's Talk Sex Work: A Play.  
LTSW is an interactive theatrical piece exploring the daily lives of cisgender and transgender women in sex work. The piece is based on true stories and experiences shared with me as a counselor working with sex workers in Tel Aviv, and transcribed testimonies of sex workers from Israel and the United States taken from literature. During my work and research I found that the public discourse about sex workers usually pathologized or romanticized them. As a counselor, I kept wishing more people could hear the incredible stories that were shared with me.

This piece intends to challenge Hollywood stereotypes by presenting a more complex understanding of this industry. We need to hear these stories and learn about the ways in which they are connected to our own struggles around race, gender, class, sexuality and identity, and take responsibility for sex work and the social conditions that produce it. To learn more about us, check out our website.

We have been working on LTSW  for two years, and in the current political climate it feels more important than ever to reach a greater audience. We have partnered with the LGBT Center in LA, and they are interested in hosting performances for their community, but have limited funding. We are raising money to support this production, so that we can share these stories that are often silenced. 

Our incredible cast includes: Camila Ascencio, Morgan Danielle Camper, Lucinda Jenkins, Miranda Kahn, Tyree Marshall, Henita Telo, Claudia Wit, Lucia Xu

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is $2000.

Our production does not require a set and is very easy to tour. Our only expenses are:

1. Transportation for the artists to the venues. 

2. compensating the artists for their time and energy.  You will be helping artists that have given their heart and soul to this piece, and have served as actors and educators throughout this process.

If we achieve our goal, we will have 4 full performances funded!  

Perks

We have some cool perks depending on the size of your donation! If you donate $100 or more your name will be listed on our website as one of our official sponsors. 

The Impact

The tickets to LTSW  are free. We believe that everyone should have access to see this piece and learn about the sex work industry. Your donation will keep us from having to charge our potential audience. 

Our 8 performances of LTSW  last spring were all sold out, and the responses have been moving and powerful. Audience members have reached out expressing gratitude for feeling represented, or offering assistance in promoting the piece. The Q&As at the end of our performances were fruitful and prompted discussions regarding the sex work industry and our responsibility as a society.  We are proud to provide a space for these important conversations.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't make a monetary contribution? That's okay, here's what you can do:

1. Share this campaign - tell your family, tell your friends, share this campaign on social media, email the link to your co-workers. Help us spread the word! Remember you can use the indiegogo share tools. 

2. come see LTSW- check out our website for the upcoming performances, and keep an eye out for our tour this May 2017 in Los Angeles. 

Thank you!

Noga

• WedRepCo – an innovative theatrical Company that's been active since 2011.
  • Our goal is to raise money to help cover costs like theater space, lighting & tech designers and all the usual expenses related to theatrical productions.
  • With your contribution, we will be able to continue providing the NYC+ community with stage productions that entertain, enrich & move audiences..

story:
What is 3 EGG CREAMS?

3 EGG CREAMS - A RHAPSODY IN THE RAIN, is a full-length solo play about FIRST LOVE, SECOND CHANCES, and the COURAGE we need to take them, inspired by, and featuring, the timeless music of the Legendary LOU CHRISTIE. Check out our SIZZLE REEL...

Our journey...

For the past three years, we’ve been bringing our LOVE STORY FOR THE AGES to audiences throughout the New York/New Jersey area. We’ve played in all kinds of theatres (NYC’s Cutting Room, the Historic Strand) to all kinds of people, including celebrities like Federico Castellucccio (Furio from THE SOPRANOS), Eddie and Dave Brigati of The Rascals, Legendary DJ Cousin Brucie, actor Joe Morton - even LOU CHRISTIE himself! Written and directed by George Cameron Grant and starring Vince Bandille, 3 EGG CREAMS - A RHAPSODY IN THE RAIN is the life-spanning and life-affirming urban tale of Vin Morrone and Angela Rose Bernstein. In a Master Class in acting, Mr. Bandille portrays all seven characters in the story, interwoven by a soundtrack of LOU CHRISTIE classics, including Lightning Strikes, The Gypsy Cried, Two Faces Have I, and of course, Rhapsody in the Rain, most playing over the iconic centerpiece of the show, the historic ROCK-OLA RHAPSODY 160 JUKEBOX, which Vin Morrone himself introduces in this scene from 3 EGG CREAMS...  

What we need...

LOU CHRISTIE’s timeless music, and this amazing jukebox it’s played on, play a huge part in Vin’s life - and in our show. The music’s kind of a soundtrack - and the jukebox? It’s an iconic piece of music history. We lucked out and found a genuine ROCK-OLA RHAPSODY 160 JUKEBOX in excellent condition, then tricked it out with Lou's 45 covers to use in our performances. But this isn't just a machine, it's a sacred symbol of our musical memories. Check out how beautiful this baby is...

But we ALSO found out real quick that traveling is brutal on 350lb historic jukeboxes, not to mention shipping budgets, so we made the decision to preserve the integrity of this classic jukebox by RETIRING and RESTORING our genuine Rock-Ola Rhapsody 160, while having a fully lit, actual size REPLICA expertly constructed by the stage prop artisans at Stone Dog Studios of Freehold, NJ. This replica will become a permanent part of all our future live shows, while our RESTORED Rhapsody 160 will be saved for a planned filming of the live show by Award-Winning Filmmaker Anton Evangelista. This film will be streamed to all those prevented from experiencing the live show due to the present and post Covid-19 reality. The creation of this replica is crucial to the future of 3 EGG CREAMS, so that when theatre is once again ready to ROCK, we'll be ready to ROLL, and that's why we're reaching out to YOU! Help us PREPARE FOR THE FUTURE while also helping us PRESERVE THE PAST, by contributing to this campaign. ALL funds we receive in excess of our $5500 REPLICA CREATION GOAL will be used to fully restore our ROCK-OLA RHAPSODY 160 to its pristine, operational condition. All funds beyond that will help fund the FILMING of the LIVE SHOW. As a THANK YOU, we're offering several exciting REWARDS at various pledge levels, including one where you actually become part of the finished ROCK-OLA RHAPSODY 160 Replica! At whatever pledge level you choose to participate, you become a permanent part of the 3 EGG CREAMS - A RHAPSODY IN THE RAIN family, and your name will be added to our "KEEP OUR MUSIC PLAYING" Contributor List that will be prominently added to our Official 3 Egg Creams Website (3EggCreams.com), featured in programs of all our future live shows, and in the credits of the filmed version of the live show when it's completed. So let's go straight to...

What you get...

*One thing before you start. Sure, you can get any or all of these GREAT REWARDS for yourself, but if you know a HUGE LOU CHRISTIE FAN, or a BIG FAN of 3 EGG CREAMS, you can also make a PLEDGE in THEIR name and have the REWARDS sent directly to them! And if you believe in what we're doing so much that you feel compelled to pledge MORE than our highest pledge amount...Thank You! Thank You! Thank You! The more you pledge, the more we can accomplish, and the more you'll help us "Keep Our Music Playing" while bringing our Love Story for the Ages to stages and screens throughout the world. So, with that being said -

At the $10 Pledge Level...

EVERYONE pledging at this level and above receives this 3 EGG CREAMS - A RHAPSODY IN THE RAIN Thank You Postcard, with the signatures of the entire team printed on the back, PLUS your name will be placed on our "KEEP OUR MUSIC PLAYING" Contributor List.

At the $20 Pledge Level...

Here it is! The digital download of the Official 3 EGG CREAMS - A RHAPSODY IN THE RAIN Soundtrack, featuring all the timeless LOU CHRISTIE Classics used in the show, EXCLUSIVE TRACKS recorded just for us, PLUS actual sound effects. This INDIEGOGO Version also features 5 Bonus LOU CHRISTIE Tracks. Your REWARD at this level and above. PLUS, you  receive the Thank You Postcard, and your name will be placed on our "KEEP OUR MUSIC PLAYING" Contributor List.

At the $40 Pledge Level...

    The Official 3 EGG CREAMS - A RHAPSODY IN THE RAIN "KEEP OUR MUSIC PLAYING" T-Shirt, which you can ONLY get through this INDIEGOGO Campaign. Made in USA, 100% cotton. Available in BLACK (Red & White Logo) in all MEN/UNISEX & WOMEN's sizes. PLUS you receive the Thank You Postcard, the Soundtrack Digital Download, and your name will be placed on our "KEEP OUR MUSIC PLAYING" Contributor List.

At the $45 Pledge Level...

The Official 3 EGG CREAMS - A RHAPSODY IN THE RAIN "KEEP OUR MUSIC PLAYING" Unstructured Cap, which you can ONLY get through this INDIEGOGO Campaign, with our 2-color LOGO embroidered across the front. BLACK only. A perfect fit with your Official T-Shirt. Made in the USA. One size fits all. PLUS you receive the Thank You Postcard, the Soundtrack Digital Download, and your name will be placed on our "KEEP OUR MUSIC PLAYING" Contributor List.

At the $50 Pledge Level...

  Whether it's to a loved one, friend, relative, or from a business, your tribute, shout-out, or dedication will become a permanent part of the 3 EGG CREAMS - A RHAPSODY IN THE RAIN Jukebox Replica and LEGACY with this DEDICATION LABEL Reward. There are only 80 labels, so move fast on this reward! PLUS you receive the Thank You Postcard, the Soundtrack Digital Download, and your name will be placed on our "KEEP OUR MUSIC PLAYING" Contributor List. Please watch the VIDEO below for more details...

At the $150 Pledge Level...

Go BIG TIME! For the FAN who wants the Entire 3 EGG CREAMS - A RHAPSODY IN THE RAIN Experience, here is the Complete Exclusive INDIEGOGO COLLECTION! Keep the CAP and give the SHIRT to a buddy, or keep them both for yourself - you'll be ready for all of our future LIVE SHOWS! PLUS your name will be placed at the VERY TOP of our "KEEP OUR MUSIC PLAYING" Contributor List.

So now about us...

First, a BIG shout-out to our inspiration:

LOU CHRISTIE, along with writing collaborator TWYLA HERBERT, left an indelible mark in music history with timeless, chart-topping songs such as Rhapsody in the Rain, Lightning Strikes, Two Face Have I, The Gypsy Cried, and the many other Christie Classics that are the heart, soul, and soundtrack of 3 EGG CREAMS. The video below, which we use as a VIDEOVERTURE before each of our shows, defines Lou's place in the history of Rock & Roll...

Our 3 EGG CREAMS team:

GEORGE CAMERON GRANT (Writer & Director): The grandson of Lanarkshire-born Olympian George Guthrie Cameron, George is an internationally produced, published, award-winning writer of a dozen full-length plays, over 40 one-act plays, monologues, and screenplays. A Dramatists Guild and BMI member, George can be reached on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, or emailed at georgecamerongrant@gmail.com. Visit www.GeorgeCameronGrant.com for the complete body of work, interviews and more.

VINCE BANDILLE (Actor): Vince grew up in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Raised in a blue-collar, Roman Catholic community, he first stepped on stage at the age of eight, and never looked back since. Vince has worked in film, TV, as well as the stage. Some TV credits include, All My Children, Saturday Night Live, and Law & Order. He has worked on such films as the award winning So You Like the Neighborhood, written and directed by Jean Pesce, which premiered at The Tribeca Film Festival. He played the bumbling negotiator in Hughes William Thompson's award winning short A New Man, which was nominated for Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity. On stage he's played roles such as Montano in Shakespeare's Othello, Willy Loman in Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman, and Antonio Salieri in Peter Shaffer's Amadeus just to name a few. He has been a member of SAG-AFTRA since 1992. Vince can be contacted via email, vbandille@comcast.net, or through his website - www.vincebandille.com 

DEBBIE SACCOMANNO (Story Editor/Tech Director): A retired NJ Public School Teacher, Debbie has been instrumental in the production of 3 Egg Creams since its creation in 2017. Her contributions include, but are not limited to, story editing, props, merchandise, sound, and lighting. "Working with the talented, seasoned team of 3 Egg Creams is an experience which proves that learning is a life-long endeavor and that education is everywhere." 

ANTON EVANGELISTA (Filmmaker): Anton Evangelista is a graduate of the High School of Art and Design in New York City. He founded his production company Comprehensive Films in 1994, with the goal of developing and producing quality filmed stories that would inspire, transform and enrich lives in an entertaining way. His award-winning films have played at international film festivals. www.ComprehensiveFilms.com

PETER J. C. HOWE (Tour Manager & Assistant to Mr. Bandille): Associated with Dusty Springfield and Kiki Dee in the early 60's, Peter worked as Tour manager for various Motown artists, then for several years with Lou Christie while he was living and working in England. Moving to America, he worked on the Rolling Stones' Steel Wheels Tour before retiring from the entertainment industry. 30 years later, after a chance meeting with George Cameron Grant, Peter came out of retirement to become a part of this wonderful production.

STONE DOG STUDIOS (Creators of the replica Rock-Ola Rhapsody 160): Stone Dog Studios is a design and fabrication scene shop providing creative solutions for film, television, theater, photography, exhibits, events and out of the box retail and service industries since 2008. One of the few woman-owned and operated scene shops in the tri-state area, providing premiere production design and set/prop fabrication. www.StoneDogStudios.net

story:
"Children spend every second of every day in a moment that adults get maybe 10 seconds of...I want to spend the rest of my life in those 10 seconds. I want to take off all of my clothes, lay down in the grass of that space, and then stay there. Forever."

About 10 SECONDS

In 10 Seconds, the language of connection is brought to life by five moving bodies, encapsulating the universality of love: love of other, love of thing, love of higher power, love of love, and most importantly, love of self. In this poetry and movement play, the human psyche unlocks into a funhouse – a true world of abandon. Here, words are no longer pedestrian speech, but lyrical expressions of emotion; and behavior transforms into a movement analysis of our most private moments.

10 Seconds began as a collection of spoken-word poetry. We sat down together one afternoon to discuss the idea of bringing movement and dance to one of the poems, and quickly realized that this was more than just quick collaboration. This was a show. This could be a theater experience that has never been realized before. Something truly new. Flash-forward to almost a year later: after multiple readings, edits, additions, hours in coffee shops, and late night conversations, the script is complete. We are ready to bring 10 Seconds to life... 

WHO WE ARE

Bloom Theatre Company is a transformative, contemporary theater company founded by Mackian Bauman and Danielle Bonanno. Bloom Theatre Company crosses boundaries in their choice of medium combining dance, spoken word, music, and visual art in order to redefine what the “theatre experience” means. They engage audiences by connecting with all human senses, creating highly textured worlds. By combining these elements, Bloom Theatre Company reaches into the souls of their viewers to draw out the things that unify us as a community, reminding us all that despite intrapersonal differences, we all exist under the collective of humanity together.

OUR GOAL

Art is exciting. It wakes the soul and the mind and asks them to sit down and have a chat. But art is also expensive. Art in New York City is expensive and we need your help to bring 10 Seconds to life. 

We need to raise $5,000 for this workshop:

This includes:

  • Rehearsal Space
  • Performance Space
  • Sound Equipment 
  • Lights
  • Set
  • Props & Costumes 
  • Compensating Actors
  • Compensating Designers & Our Stage Manager
  • Media (Videography & Photography) 
  • And of course, the things that we hope don't come up, but might! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please feel free to share our campaign with friends, family, and on social media! We appreciate all forms of support!

Thank you!
story_txt:
"Children spend every second of every day in a moment that adults get maybe 10 seconds of...I want to spend the rest of my life in those 10 seconds. I want to take off all of my clothes, lay down in the grass of that space, and then stay there. Forever."
About 10 SECONDS

In 10 Seconds, the language of connection is brought to life by five moving bodies, encapsulating the universality of love: love of other, love of thing, love of higher power, love of love, and most importantly, love of self. In this poetry and movement play, the human psyche unlocks into a funhouse – a true world of abandon. Here, words are no longer pedestrian speech, but lyrical expressions of emotion; and behavior transforms into a movement analysis of our most private moments.
10 Seconds began as a collection of spoken-word poetry. We sat down together one afternoon to discuss the idea of bringing movement and dance to one of the poems, and quickly realized that this was more than just quick collaboration. This was a show. This could be a theater experience that has never been realized before. Something truly new. Flash-forward to almost a year later: after multiple readings, edits, additions, hours in coffee shops, and late night conversations, the script is complete. We are ready to bring 10 Seconds to life... 
WHO WE ARE
Bloom Theatre Company is a transformative, contemporary theater company founded by Mackian Bauman and Danielle Bonanno. Bloom Theatre Company crosses boundaries in their choice of medium combining dance, spoken word, music, and visual art in order to redefine what the “theatre experience” means. By combining these elements, Bloom Theatre Company reaches into the souls of their viewers to draw out the things that unify us as a community, reminding us all that despite intrapersonal differences, we all exist under the collective of humanity together.
OUR GOAL

We need to raise $5,000 for this workshop:
This includes:

Rehearsal Space
Performance Space
Sound Equipment 
Lights
Set
Props & Costumes 
Compensating Actors
Compensating Designers & Our Stage Manager
Media (Videography & Photography) 
And of course, the things that we hope don't come up, but might! 

Other Ways You Can Help
Please feel free to share our campaign with friends, family, and on social media! We appreciate all forms of support!
Thank you!

story:
The Best Kind of Weird.

Now celebrating its seventh season in Chicago, Tympanic is a 501(c)3 not-for-profit theatre company dedicated to producing new and developed work with fantastical, frightening, or absurd subject matter that provokes, inspires, and entertains. Through our use of vibrant storytelling, dynamic language, and colorful characters, we invite our audiences to plunge headfirst with us into theatrical worlds that are fresh, energetic, and visceral.

Season Seven - One of Us

In its current season, Tympanic introduces audiences to two outcasts striving to be a part of society in very different ways.  A woman with a rare genetic condition joins a freak show under the false pretense of romance.  A young man blazes a trail of blood and destruction across the American West, believing it’s the only way to become truly human.  The tragic, yet touching characters in this season’s exciting lineup of shows explore the lengths people are willing to go to become ‘one of us,’ and if it truly is worth it in the end.

Other initiatives this season include an all new podcast series debuting original work by new and emerging playwrights that you can enjoy right in the comfort of your own home, and the continuation of our bi-monthly reading series fostering new play development for writers and non-writers alike.

Why Give?

As a small not-for-profit theatre company, we rely on donations such as yours for over half of our funding.  In return, you'll know that you are directly responsible for delivering daring and interesting new theatre to the Chicago community.  100% of all raised funds are used for production expenses, including but not limited to scenic construction, costumes, and theater space.  That means your contribution becomes a tangible part of the next weird and provocative production we bring to the stage!
