story:
What is Hot Air Baboon?

We are a new production project who promote the best up and coming talent in the country. Not only do we support the development of shows but also put on comedy variety nights across London, supporting acts of all different genres.

As working comedians in the industry we were frustrated with only certain types of people and genres being represented at events we performed at, and that the treatment of a lot of acts wasn't fair, so we decided to do something about it... that is how Hot Air Baboon was created!

 We have a few principals that we adhere to with the projects/events we work on: 

We aim to promote diversity, working with female, BAME and LGBTQ+ artists, and artists of all ages and economic background. We work to always create a safe space for acts to present their talent, and for our audiences to enjoy the show. We pay our acts, part of the proceeds of our nights go back to our hard working performers. We also create a relationship to help develop the artists who work with us creatively, and support them when we can. We love variety, most comedy nights are over-saturated with stand-up, and the few variety acts feel out of place, but comedy can be so much more. We  work with performers that do stand-up, sketch comedy, character comedy, musical comedy, cabaret, clowning, drag, improv, etc. We support our artists on all their ventures and work hard on building lasting relationships with them and the venues we work with.

Although we are small we are working hard to try and change the comedy industry for the better, helping those talented people who often get overlooked. 

 

Who are these Hot Baboons?

 

 

Isa Bonachera

Isa is a comedian, writer and cartoonist. She performs regularly in the London circuit and around the UK.

Isa started doing comedy during her time at the University of Cambridge. She was a cartoonist for the satirical magazine The Porter’s Log, and she was involved in several comedies, stand-up shows and sketch shows at the ADC Theatre, the Corpus Playroom and the Pembroke New Cellars at the University of Cambridge.

Since Isa moved to London, she became a member of the Soho Theatre Young Company, one half of the sketch group Agenda Benders, and a founding member of the production project Hot Air Baboon.

Isa is a Sketch Off! 2018 runner-up, a Man Up! 2018 finalist, a Max Turner Prize 2018 finalist, a Leicester Square Comedian of the Year 2017 finalist, and a Funny Women one to watch 2017

 

 

 

Lewis Goody

Lewis is an actor, comedian and writer who trained as an actor at The Guildhall School of Music and Drama.

He has performed in such venues as The Regents Park Open Air Theatre, HOME Manchester, Theatre Royal Plymouth and has toured the UK with Hidden, in which he starred.

His weekly podcast Acting Inspired is highly-rated and popular amongst young actors.

He has studied improv at The Groundlings School in LA and has been a young artist at The Soho Theatre.

He is currently writing a series with Kae Alexander, for which they have received a development deal with Me+You Productions.

 

 

Daniel Wye

Daniel Wye is a Comedian/ Cabaret artist/ Actor and Writer from the West Midlands.

He is  Comedian working the London circuit and gigging around the UK. He began with the Soho Young company, since he has performed at reputable comedy nights and also at Brainchild festival 2017 and soon to perform at 'Soho Late Night Rising' in July.

Dan is a Sketch Off! 2018 runner-up,  a Max Turner Prize 2018 finalist, a Amused Moose semi-finalist  and selected to compete in Pleasance Comedy Reserve 2017. 

He has recently been developing a comedy cabaret project with Common theatre, supported by the English Touring Theatre and Radio HaHa. The project was selected by the Old Vic theatre to be developed at their workrooms space, and was developed and performed at The Belgrade theatre in Coventry and at Ovalhouse.

Dans acting career has allowed him to work with theatre companies across the UK (Heartbreak Productions, Imagineer Productions, Theatre Absolute, National Youth Theatre etc). He also created the LGBTQ short film 'Wake' with director Simon De Selva and a BAFTA award winning cast. He co-wrote the script and was also a producer on the project, as well as playing the lead part.

 

The Shows...

 

Artcoholic


 

Artcoholic is a comedy cabaret about wanting to make it in an industry that doesn't want you. The show focused around Muchachico, a Spanish artist whose only desire is to go down in history as the greatest artist of his generation, and the many obstacles he faces, from the arbitrary nature of the art industry to his own lack of real talent.

The story will resonate with a wide demographic, because we are all collectively experiencing a world where opportunities are lacking, and it is harder to achieve one's personal goals, being buying a house, progressing at work, or making it in a creative industry.

Artcoholic is part of a underrepresented form of entertainment because it is a drag king show. While queer shows and drag queen shows are on the rise at the fringe, there are still very few drag king shows. Many theatre goers don’t know that drag kings exist. This is an opportunity to promote a form of entertainment that have not reached the mainstream. 

Mos importantly, Artcoholic is a funny and enjoyable comedy that anyone would enjoy. The most daring element of this show is live painting, which will be used to create a very dynamic and visually pleasing comedy experience.

Don't miss this comedy about gender, self-awareness and bad art.

 

Agenda Benders: Witty Gritty Bitty Fitty Committee

Witty Gritty Bitty Fitty Committee is an hour of fast paced sketches using a multitude of different forms including musical, character and physical comedy. Our writing is dark, camp and with satirical undertones. What makes this show unique is its metamorphic style, which will keep the audience captivated and on the edge of their seats.

We are proud queer performers that embrace the weird and subversive, and we believe that this show will appeal to the LGBTQ+ community. We are also creating a show that is very visually striking and a big spectacle, our aim is to attract new audiences of theatre-goers and show them the brilliance of daring sketch comedy. The show will also attract comedy lovers, by using a multitude of different comedy genres, it will certainly bode well with the fringe veterans.

 

I Can't do this

 

I CAN’T DO THIS is the debut solo show from Lewis Goody that explores the anxious mind, the burden of its effects; and how it can transform a confident, young weirdo to a reluctant wastrel who is scared of everything. On stage, armed with a plastic baby, a cardboard box and a loop pedal, Lewis will attempt to do battle with the voices that keep him fulfilling his destiny…or maybe not.

Lewis uses his arsenal of talents: rapping, looping, singing, puppetry the list goes on... to confront the beast that is our fear of failure.

 

Séayoncé

Séayoncé is a drag cabaret extravaganza for all those people who are afraid of death, because they feel like they aren't truly living their lives.

It is set in a seance because what better place to talk about your fear of death then surrounded by the dead.  Our main conduit to the spirit world is the eccentric, cosmic joke clairvoyant Séayoncé, who will use the spirits to find out your deepest darkest fears and help you overcome them.  

This show uses a plethora of different genres to portray its message from song, dance, puppetry, poetry etc. There is a lot of character comedy as she allows ghosts to take over her human form, portraying spirits from all walks of life to help you live yours.

It is a powerful Queer show highlighting, the negativity we allow ourselves to be dominated by, from our obsessions with death, our addictions to self sabotage to our endeavors to find love and not be lonely. 

Let her open up your third eye, your heart and your legs!

'Embodies all that is queer, overboard and full of vice'- ★★★★★ LondonBoxOffice

 

 

What the Baboons need help with...

Edinburgh Fringe festival is an incredible platform for up and coming artists to showcase their work in front of the public and members of the industry, and can be career changing. Unfortunately it is also a very expensive one which has a lot of risks for the artists taking up shows.

So far we have managed to financially support the shows through past variety nights we have housed, and fundraisers and also just working extra jobs to try and afford what we can. But we need your help to achieve that final push to get us to this amazing festival, and smash this opportunity!

We have sat down and worked out that we still need to raise £3000 that will be spread between the different shows, so that we are able to perform these exciting projects. 

This is what this money covers...

Printing:  When we are at the festival the way we will be promoting our shows is with posters and flyers that we will giving to the public on a daily basis for the whole month...That is a lot of flyers! We have calculated that the printing costs alone for this, for all of our shows will cost £600

Transport: Just getting to the tropical land that is Edinburgh costs a pretty penny. We have calculated that for us all to be able to get a train up to Scotland and then to travel back on the elation of a successful fringe will cost £450 

Apartment:   We have managed to pay the first few installments for our apartment in Edinburgh, but we need your help to cover the last part. The cost of preventing us from being homeless during the whole month of the festival is £750 

Costume/Set: To help make our shows the fabulous creations we have envisioned we need fabulous costumes and set. This will help bring the shows to the next professional level and really stand out from the competition at fringe. For us to create that certain je ne sais quoi we need  £600

Living costs: When we are at the festival we do not get the profits from our ticket sales until after the fringe, which means we technically wont be working for a month! We need help with just day to day living costs e.g. food. To keep us comedians from starving, and allowing us the comfort to just focus on our projects and not be working on the side we have figured out we need  £600

As you can see the areas your generous donations will be aiding are all necessities for us to be able to take our projects up to the festival this year, so please help us...go on I dare ya.

 

 

Cheeky Perks

But do not fear your generous donations wont be unrewarded, there are perks...that's right perks!

We want to show how much we appreciate all the help you give to us by giving back to you in anyway we can!

Depending on how much you are willing to help us out with, you can be the lucky receiver of a variety of different rewards, don't believe me? Here are some examples...

A heart felt thank you, a personalised joke, a personalised song, a filmed sketch, a painting of you, copies of our posters, free tickets to one of variety shows in London, free tickets to our shows in Edinburgh, a cabaret night we host in your honour, and more!!!

 

Other ways you can help...

If you aren't able to financially support us, do not worry we totally understand. But there are other ways you could massively help us out...

Share this page- to anyone and everyone, you think would love to help, even to anyone you think would hate this, just share it. The more people who are able to see this the more likely we will be able to raise the money!

Businesses/funds-  If there are any businesses or funding bodies that you know that think would be interested to help us please get us in touch with them!

Sugar Daddies- If you know any rich powerful attractive older men please give them Daniel's personal details.

 

Honestly any help you can give to get us one step closer to conquering our dreams and aspirations in this tricky comedy industry would be hugely appreciated. 

Big Love from Hot Air Baboon x

story:
OUR STORY

World View Productions was founded in 2008 as an innovative company that values diversity in a multicultural society.  Our mission is to create a cultural bridge between New York and international artists (particularly Latin American artists) through high quality theater and film in Spanish and English.  After an outstanding success and enthusiastic welcome from audiences and critics of our first theatre production, Cayendo con Victoriano, we are thrilled to produce our second show, Muerte Súbita (Sudden Death) by Mexico's leading playwright Sabina Berman.

 

THE PLAYWRIGHT

Sabina Berman is an award-winning Jewish Mexican playwright, essayist, poet, writer, film and theater director.  Her best known plays include the critically acclaimed Between Pancho Villa and a Naked Woman, Muerte Súbita, Moliere, and Freud Skating.  These plays ran for over two years in Mexico City, and were produced across Latin America and Europe. Berman has also written the screenplays The History of Love for Alfonso Cuarón and Light for Alejandro González Iñárritu.  The film Backyard, which she wrote and co-produced, was nominated for a 2010 Oscar. 

 

THE PLAY 

Andrés, living in an abandoned building with his girlfriend Gloria, is passionately writing his third novel and refuses to leave their apartment until it is finished.  The unexpected arrival of his old friend Odiseo, recently released from prison, drastically disrupts their world and forces them to face their truth.  They will ultimately discover that sometimes destruction is needed before creation can begin anew.  Muerte Súbita  (Sudden Death) is a tour de force by Mexico’s leading contemporary playwright Sabina Berman.


OUR TEAM

Director: Daniel Jáquez

Cast: Alfredo Huereca, Ana Grosse, Rodrigo Cuevas 

Executive Producer / Publicity: Alfredo Huereca

Co-Producer / Publicity: Ana Grosse

Set Designer: Susan Zeeman Rogers

Light and Sound Designer: Alfonso Rey

Costume Designer / Production Assistant: Jorge Castilla

Fight Choreographer: David Anzuelo

Stage Manager / Director's Assistant: Bruno Sangar

Sponsorship: Maria Nieto

Web Designer: Ryan LeMere

 

WHEN & WHERE

Muerte Súbita will have its NYC Premiere at The Gershwin Hotel from June 1 to 23. More info at www.worldvproductions.com

  

WHY

We are passionate about bringing to life the work of Latin American playwrights of the highest calibre that have not been produced in New York yet.  We fervently believe in the need to offer theatre in Spanish that is raw, edgy, complex, socially conscious and that asks crucial questions about our humanity.  Muerte Súbita encompasses all of this with a delightful touch of dark humor.  Our production will include English supertitles to make it accessible to everyone.

Spanish has become the second most spoken language in the U.S. with 45 million people who speak it as a first or second language. This constitutes the largest minority in the country. We want to embrace and celebrate our culture by presenting one of the greatest contemporary Spanish language playwrights.  

World View's first production, Cayendo con Victoriano, by Mexican playwright Luis Enrique Gutierrez Ortiz Monasterio,was awarded:

- An HOLA Award (Hispanic Organization of Latin Actors) (2011) for Best Lead Actor

- Two Latin ACE New York Awards (2012) for Best Actor and Best Supporting Actor

- Three Latin ACE New York Nominations (2012) for Best Production, Best Supporting Actor and Best Supporting Actress 

- Six Nominations from New York’s Artistas de Teatro Independiente (ATI) (2012) including Best Production

We were also featured in more than twenty news and magazine articles, both in New York and Mexico, including Fox Latino News, Reforma, Notimex, Vanguardia, Zocalo, Impacto NY, Yahoo Noticias, Yahoo Mujer, Publimetro, En el Show, Journal.US, El Especial, 24/7 Herald, Diario.com, Tu Revista Latina, and on the air interviews and publicity, including Univision Radio, Veja TV, Radioson FM and Tu Momento Neoyorquino.


WHAT WE NEED

 Your support will help us with:

- Rental of rehearsal and performance space

- Set, lights and costumes

- Fees for the artistic and production teams

- Publicity

- Insurance

 

We'd love for you to help us make this dream a reality!  On the right hand side you can see what you'll receive for your generous contribution.  Any amount is important to the success of Muerte Súbita and is greatly appreciated.  For more information please visit us at www.worldvproductions.com.  

 

HOW ELSE YOU CAN HELP US:

By sharing this link www.indiegogo.com/worldvproductions on Facebook, Twitter, email and through word of mouth. 


Thank you!
story_txt:
OUR STORY
World View Productions was founded in 2008 as an innovative company that values diversity in a multicultural society.  Our mission is to create a cultural bridge between New York and international artists (particularly Latin American artists) through high quality theater and film in Spanish and English.  After an outstanding success and enthusiastic welcome from audiences and critics of our first theatre production, Cayendo con Victoriano, we are thrilled to produce our second show, Muerte Súbita (Sudden Death) by Mexico's leading playwright Sabina Berman.
 
THE PLAYWRIGHT
Sabina Berman is an award-winning Jewish Mexican playwright, essayist, poet, writer, film and theater director.  Her best known plays include the critically acclaimed Between Pancho Villa and a Naked Woman, Muerte Súbita, Moliere, and Freud Skating.  These plays ran for over two years in Mexico City, and were produced across Latin America and Europe. Berman has also written the screenplays The History of Love for Alfonso Cuarón and Light for Alejandro González Iñárritu.  The film Backyard, which she wrote and co-produced, was nominated for a 2010 Oscar. 
 
THE PLAY 
Andrés, living in an abandoned building with his girlfriend Gloria, is passionately writing his third novel and refuses to leave their apartment until it is finished.  The unexpected arrival of his old friend Odiseo, recently released from prison, drastically disrupts their world and forces them to face their truth.  They will ultimately discover that sometimes destruction is needed before creation can begin anew.  Muerte Súbita  (Sudden Death) is a tour de force by Mexico’s leading contemporary playwright Sabina Berman.

OUR TEAM
Director: Daniel Jáquez
Cast: Alfredo Huereca, Ana Grosse, Rodrigo Cuevas 
Executive Producer / Publicity: Alfredo Huereca
Co-Producer / Publicity: Ana Grosse
Set Designer: Susan Zeeman Rogers

story:
Hello!

My name is Harrie Dobby & I am a London-based writer & actor. I am absolutely thrilled that my first full-length play, The Gap, will receive its WORLD PREMIERE at The International New York Fringe Festival 2015! The Gap originated at a 20-minute short at the Lyric Hammersmith in London last summer, but this is the first time it will play as a full-length play. 

This is an incredible opportunity for myself & the rest of the cast to get our work seen on an International platform, especially as we are one of only two companies coming to New York from London! Further info & tickets can be found via:

www.fringenyc.org

@fringeNYC

@the_gap_play

www.the-gap-play.com

Here's A Bit More Info About The Gap

Meet Lisa, a small town girl from the USA with BIG dreams. She applies for her passport, gets on a plane, and flies to Asia. One week in to the trip of a lifetime, Lisa meets Dave, Mr Charisma from London. 

The Gap follows Lisa and Dave through the next eighteen months of their lives. They dream of travelling the world together forever, but when Lisa becomes pregnant, this dream begins to unravel. Is it really possible to just strap a baby to your back and keep on going, or will "real world” responsibilities eventually catch up with them?

Joined by two Irish hippies, Lisa’s bible-bashing mom, Dave’s sex-mad best mate and her less-than-PC husband, “The Gap” is a one act comedy, looking at what you have to sacrifice in order to be happy. 

It's all go, it's definitely happening, but we need your help to get us there. 

Here's How You Can Help

This is a self-funded project and we are doing all we can to raise the funds. It obviously isn't cheap to get six actors and a techie over to New York for two weeks in August. We are looking to raise a MINIMUM of £2000 to go towards the cost of flights, accommodation & food (actors need to eat!). £2000 won't cover everything we need to do this (flights alone are over £3000) but it will certainly get us along the way. If we can raise over £2000 with this campaign, happy days! Together with some London-based fundraising events, we're sure we can get there!

Any amount you can donate will be greatly received, but as an added

incentive, here are our unique awards for our wonderful backers:

£5 - Our eternal love & respect.

£10 - A shout out on social media, plus our eternal love & respect.

£20 - Entry onto The Supporters Wall of Fame on our website (www.the-gap-play.com), a shout out on social media, plus our eternal love & respect.

£30 - Your name in our program, entry onto The Supporters Wall of Fame on our website (www.the-gap-play.com), a shout out on social media, plus our eternal love & respect.

£50 - A signed copy of our program from the whole cast, your name in our program, entry onto The Supporters Wall of Fame on our website (www.the-gap-play.com), a shout out on social media, plus our eternal love & respect.

£100 - A free ticket to one of our fundraising events (in London), a signed copy of our program from the whole cast, your name in our program, entry onto The Supporters Wall of Fame on our website (www.the-gap-play.com), a shout out on social media, plus our eternal love & respect.

£200 - A free ticket to all of our fundraising events (in London), a signed copy of our program from the whole cast, your name in our program, entry onto The Supporters Wall of Fame on our website (www.the-gap-play.com), a shout out on social media, plus our eternal love & respect.

£500 – WE WILL NAME MEGAN & ANDY’S CHILD AFTER YOU! Plus you will get a free ticket to all of our fundraising events (in London), a signed copy of our program from the whole cast, your name in our program, entry onto The Supporters Wall of Fame on our website (www.the-gap-play.com), a shout out on social media, and our eternal love & respect.

Other Ways You Can Help

It may be that you cannot donate to our campaign, but that doesn't mean you can't help us get the word out! Share this campaign, and shout about us on social media!

@the_gap_play

www.the-gap-play.com

www.facebook.com/the.gap.play

That’s all from me, thank you so much for all your support!

Harrie xx

story:
About The Show

This summer, The Agency Theater Collective is very excited and proud to be producing the world premiere of Truth in Context. In this tightly wound two-hander, Bobby Fincher is struggling to find a post-college job. After an abysmal interview at William Darnell’s advertising firm, the game changes as the two clash and struggle for power and identity.

We at The Agency strongly believe in fresh theater, whether with original scripts or new spins on classics. Agency company member Cody Lucas has a developed a new play with sharp and clever dialogue that plays with its characters and perceptions.

Truth in Context has assembled a stellar cast and crew to bring this new work to life. Taking the roles of William and Bobby, we have Matthew Collins and Awate Serequeberhan making their Agency debuts. The creative team includes frequent Agency collaborators Greg Pinsoneault (scenic design), Ellie Humphrys (lighting design), Kate Jacobsen (costume design), Ryan Brankin (original music), and Sara Faye Richmond (stage manager).

What We Need and What You Get

Producing a play of any size is a major undertaking and even more so for a young theater company with an original script.

Specifically, your donation will help us pay for: theater rental, costumes, set construction, lighting equipment, sound equipment and marketing costs.

Not only is your donation tax-deductible, we also have some amazing perks from our collaborators. To name a few: a year’s worth of Meisner acting classes at Green Shirt Studio, a 10-week Meisner acting class, dinner and drinks with the writer/director Cody Lucas and Artistic Director Andrew Gallant, autographed posters, special guest honors at No Shame Theatre, handwritten thank you notes, and more.

The Impact

The Agency Theater Collective has been operating for nearly four years and we are proud of what we've achieved so far. In 2012 we were named runner-up "Best New Theater Company" by the Chicago Reader. Truth in Context will be our fourth world premiere production following the acclaimed original works At the Center and I Wish To Apologize to the People of Illinois. In addition to our main stage shows, we run a weekly open mic called No Shame Theater.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are sincerely grateful for any donation you can make to support our project. In addition to a donation, you can also help by sharing this campaign with your friends, family and co-workers. Also, we hope you'll come see our show!

story:
About Me

My name is Patrick Cleary, and I am the author of a play called Parthenogenesis, which has been accepted into the New York International Fringe Festival 2015.

I am hoping to raise the necessary funds to bring Parthenogenesis to life at this prestigious festival, in order to bring the words to life and the possibility of moving on to other productions in the future.

I am lucky enough to have caught the attention of an amazing director, Ashley Marinaccio, who has brought successful Fringe productions to life before.

About Parthenogenesis

Imagine yourself at 4 years old, being taken out to the middle of a frozen lake to skate with your father. You watch him circle you, skating in perfect figure 8s, making you smile and laugh. Imagine then, he leaves you on the ice, never to return.

Imagine yourself growing up as the child of a single parent; the only clue to your own father being a worn cassette tape of his voice which you play over and over, hoping to hear hints of your heritage.

Imagine having motherhood thrust upon you when you never expected to be a parent, and never allowing the child you are commissioned to take care of to call you "Mother."

Parthenogenesis follows three generations of women who have all made decisions and had decisions made for them about the fathers they lost, the fathers they chose, and the fathers they never knew.

What We Need & What You Get

I am so honored to have Parthenogenesis chosen for this festival, but I can't bring it to life without some financial assistance. Producing a quality play in New York is impossible without the proper funding, which is why I'm asking for your donations.

  • We have created a carefully-considered, reasonable budget which includes 4 weeks of rehearsal space, stipends for actors, a director, and production staff, props, costumes, set piece rentals, and the multimedia elements that can help bring this memory play to life.
  • The New York International Fringe Festival provides performance venues and a built-in audience, which are essential to putting Parthenogenesis in front of as many people as possible.
  • We have created a number of perks you will receive at all levels of funding, so that you will receive tangible evidence of our gratitude for your consideration.

The Impact

Play writing is often a solitary undertaking, and though I have been lucky enough to have had my work performed over the years in various formats, this is by far the largest opportunity I've had for a production

  • The New York Annual Fringe Festival has a noted track record for productions that have been picked up for larger Off-Broadway productions and/or publishing deals, which would be an incredible opportunity for any playwright.
  • As a producer of new works festivals for many years, I have been committed to bringing forth new voices in theater, and I understand what it takes to successfully mount a production that showcases new plays.
  • I take writing and theater very seriously, and I understand the leap of faith it takes to take a chance on new works. Please understand that every dollar counts and is appreciated greatly.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate at this time, you can still be a crucial supporter of Parthenogenesis!

  • Share this page with your friends, family, and social media circles.
  • Come see the show in August!
  • Join our Facebook group! 
  • Share our website!

Thank you so much for taking the time to consider Parthenogenesis. All of us who are or will be involved with the production appreciate it.

story:
The project, the school and its function and philosophy.

From Linda Gamblin - Evolve Dance course director and founder.

Your generous contribution will go towards our inaugural end of year performance comming up in only 10 days! But first a little about the course that this performance season completes. Watch the video above and hear from the students directly.

Evolve Dance is a one-year intensive tertiary preparation and/or professional transition course in contemporary dance. It is a course that offers both high school leavers and University graduates a year of intensive study into diverse and incredibly strengthening techniques and philosophy in preparation for auditions - either for institutions or professional companies.

The year intensive also offers students a chance to work with some of Australia's most successful and awarded mature-age dance practitioners in contemporary dance, choreographic composition, ballet and yoga. It is a course that offers personal as well as professional guidance. It offers students a direct line to community networking and potential professional engagement through the educators / choreographers who teach at Evolve Dance.

After 10 years as a professional ballet dancer performing principle roles with the Australian Ballet, Royal Ballet and National Ballet of Portugal and after hearing yet another rehearsal director scream out “turn out!” one too many times, it has been my life's mission to work out why I was unable to feel I was ever good enough. In the years that followed I developed an understanding of how my body moved through working as a contemporary dancer (for 6 years with Sydney Dance Company). I commenced studying yoga, pilates, anatomy and physiology along with other courses and workshops on the muscular and skeletal systems and biomechanics.

I passionately want to get my message across that to be the best dancer and performer you can be, whether in classical or contemporary, we need first to find a deeper understanding of ourselves. It is with this philosophy I have created Evolve Dance.

Where your generous contribution will go.

I have been fortunate enough to attract teachers and choreographers who share a similar philosophy to mine and this has created quite a journey for my trusting students, some who are heading into professional dance careers, others who have successfully auditioned into three-year degree courses at larger institutions and another who is still in high school.

Their progress has been my reward and I encourage you all to witness this in their end of year double bill season with works by Dutch/Australian choreographer Paul Selwyn Norton and Australia Council Dance Fellow Dean Walsh. Both choreograhers have given an enormous amount of information, not only to the students but to myself.

The creation of both these works have challenged and extended our phsyical, creative and performance capabilities. The works are very involved conceptually and both are very phsycial and demanding in their own unique ways. It is for this reason I wish for my students to develop and inhabit these works completely through a series of performances rather than just a one-night graduating performance.

As this is our first year with a smaller group of students I would hate to compromise on what I believe is the most rewarding experience for all their hard work and one that most emulates a professional contemporary dance company - preparation and performance. 

A few days ago we reached a point where we realise that to put this show and 4 performance season on - with all that it requires financially - we need to seek more funds. It is therefore imperative for these students that I find more financial support to get through these last ten days and make this the experience for the students I had originally hoped for.

We need help paying for: extra theatre hire, more time with the choreographers than planned to complete the very detailed works and help the dancers more fully embody them. We need to hire more lighting and a performance photographer so we have images for future publicity and we require more stage management than first accounted for.

Marketing and advertising has blown my budget somewhat and with the immense task of running a new multi-functional course and final graduating production - I am learning as I go - it has been difficult to keep track of every facit. 

Can you help us reach our goal in just ten days? We require $2,000 more to make our season something the students won't forget and an event that also assist me in advertising for 2013 so I can keep this invaluable course, (and all that it offers to the community), afloat and thriving.

Many thanks and with love,

Linda

SHOW DETAILS:

Season: 13th-15th December.

Bangarra Dance Theatre studio theatre. Pier 4 Hickson Rd, Walsh Bay

8pm and Sat 4pm and 8pm

Bookings: 0408 718 367 or at the door

The project, the school and its function and philosophy. 
From Linda Gamblin - Evolve Dance course director and founder.
Your generous contribution will go towards our inaugural end of year performance comming up in only 10 days! But first a little about the course that this performance season completes. Watch the video above and hear from the students directly.
Evolve Dance is a one-year intensive tertiary preparation and/or professional transition course in contemporary dance. It is a course that offers both high school leavers and University graduates a year of intensive study into diverse and incredibly strengthening techniques and philosophy in preparation for auditions - either for institutions or professional companies.
The year intensive also offers students a chance to work with some of Australia's most successful and awarded mature-age dance practitioners in contemporary dance, choreographic composition, ballet and yoga. It is a course that offers personal as well as professional guidance. It offers students a direct line to community networking and potential professional engagement through the educators / choreographers who teach at Evolve Dance.
After 10 years as a professional ballet dancer performing principle roles with the Australian Ballet, Royal Ballet and National Ballet of Portugal and after hearing yet another rehearsal director scream out “turn out!” one too many times, it has been my life's mission to work out why I was unable to feel I was ever good enough. In the years that followed I developed an understanding of how my body moved through working as a contemporary dancer (for 6 years with Sydney Dance Company). I commenced studying yoga, pilates, anatomy and physiology along with other courses and workshops on the muscular and skeletal systems and biomechanics.
I passionately want to get my message across that to be the best dancer and performer you can be, whether in classical or contemporary, we need first to find a deeper understanding of ourselves. It is with this philosophy I have created Evolve Dance.
Where your generous contribution will go.
I have been fortunate enough to attract teachers and choreographers who share a similar philosophy to mine and this has created quite a journey for my trusting students, some who are heading into professional dance careers, others who have successfully auditioned into three-year degree courses at larger institutions and another who is still in high school.
Their progress has been my reward and I encourage you all to witness this in their end of year double bill season with works by Dutch/Australian choreographer Paul Selwyn Norton and Australia Council Dance Fellow Dean Walsh. Both choreograhers have given an enormous amount of information, not only to the students but to myself.
The creation of both these works have challenged and extended our phsyical, creative and performance capabilities. The works are very involved conceptually and both are very phsycial and demanding in their own unique ways. It is for this reason I wish for my students to develop and inhabit these works completely through a series of performances rather than just a one-night graduating performance.
As this is our first year with a smaller group of students I would hate to compromise on what I believe is the most rewarding experience for all their hard work and one that most emulates a professional contemporary dance company - preparation and performance.  
A few days ago we reached a point where we realise that to put this show and 4 performance season on - with all that it requires financially - we need to seek more funds. It is therefore imperative for these students that I find more financial support to get through these last ten days and make this the experience for the students I had originally hoped for.
We need help paying for: extra theatre hire, more time with the choreographers than planned to complete the very detailed works and help the dancers more fully embody them. We need to hire more lighting and a performance photographer so we have images for future publicity and we require more stage management than first accounted for.
Marketing and advertising has blown my budget somewhat and with the immense task of running a new multi-functional course and final graduating production - I am learning as I go - it has been difficult to keep track of every facit. 
Can you help us reach our goal in just ten days? We require $2,000 more to make our season something the students won't forget and an event that also assist me in advertising for 2013 so I can keep this invaluable course, (and all that it offers to the community), afloat and thriving.
Many thanks and with love,
Linda
SHOW DETAILS:
Season: 13th-15th December.
Bangarra Dance Theatre studio theatre. Pier 4 Hickson Rd, Walsh Bay
8pm and Sat 4pm and 8pm
Bookings: 0408 718 367 or at the door

story:
Who we are…

We are the co-creators of NeverYouMind Productions. We founded our production company in February 2013. Our names are Lauren Campbell, Flora Karas and Lisa-Marie Marrelli. We are three passionate women, who have a thirst for producing and creating theatre and entertainment for the world! Our mission is to enliven and stir the souls of the audience. We produce work that evokes thought, and breaks boundaries. 

The Ladies...

Lauren has been involved in the world of theatre from the age of 4, as a dancer. While attending the Canadian College of Performing Arts, Lauren discovered her passion for acting, and has been immersed in it ever since, taking on roles in a range of theatre productions in Vancouver and the Lower Mainland. Besides acting, Lauren has a diverse range of experience as a director, producer and choreographer.

Flora has carved out her piece in international television and in local indie films. Her work and reputation precedes her among those that have worked along side this starlet. She functions for the highest and greatest good of each project.  Her optimism is infectious. This year, 2013, has been all about theatre, and now the heart of Vancouver will again experience her unique and beguiling energy! Enjoy.

Lisa-Marie has a dynamic history of theatrical experience ranging in dance, theatre and musical theatre. Along with this, she brings forth a decade of Visual Effects work in the Film Industry where her work has pushed her to have a keen eye for placement, beauty and seamless photo real designs. After working for 3 years as a Front of House Manager at a local theatre in BC, she has learned a wide range of business knowledge relating to theatre production. In the last year, Lisa was in a Production of A Particular Class of Women. This production was awarded a multitude of awards at the Fraser Valley Zone Festival and the Theatre BC Festival.

When the Ladies of NeverYouMind Productions put our talents and power together we are definitely a force to be reckoned with. We all have had a great journey in our individual acting careers and life experiences.  Now, everything learned about the humbling and enlivening creative process will fuel us to succeed with our own production company.  "Without a shadow of a doubt" as Lauren always says...

What's Happening....

This fall we are producing, A Particular Class of Women, by Janet Feindel. The play will run at the:

Waterfront Theatre on Granville Island from Oct 16th-20th

The Columbia Theatre in New Westminster on Oct 24th and 25th.

A Particular Class of Women was written after a celebrated 1985 court case in Ontario, where a stripper was raped at knifepoint. The Judge didn't pay much attention to the crime because as he pointed out the woman/victim 'was from a particular class of women whose profession it is to promote lust’. The play gives a glimpse into the lives of 8 women working in the skin trade in the mid 1980s, when Burlesque was rapidly fading away in the club scene, and table dancing was becoming more and more popular. The play takes place in the dressing room of The Cabaret Circus, a strip club that all 8 women are employed by or have been employed by.

 A Particular Class of Women breaks the stereotype that most have about women whose business it is to take off their clothes. This play has everything you would desire from a theatre experience: comedy, drama and a little (well, actually) A LOT of erotica!

 The play means the world to us, and we want this play to reach its highest and greatest potential. We desire to thoroughly entertain the audience with truthful moments of these women’s lives. We feel honoured and fortunate to be working with an incredible and talented cast. As an added perk, we have an award-winning actor playing the role of the MC for the night!

"GIRLS, GIRLS, GIRLS!!"

This theatre experience has dancing and epic 80s music that will fire the audience up. This play is unique as the characters address the audience as if they were fellow strippers in the dressing room.  The characters place you directly into their world.

We need to raise money for our play, and we are looking to our community to help us! If you contribute you will be helping an avenue in performing arts that very much needs a "breath of fresh air"!  NeverYouMind Productions wants to recruit people who don’t normally go to the theatre and stimulate the ones that do. We want to change this city by getting the people out to the theatre so they may experience some truth about the human condition.

We love what we do and in this world, isn't that the most important thing?

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is modest; we desire to raise $3000.00 to help with production costs. Money raised will go towards the theatre rental, rights to the play, costumes, sets and props and advertising.

All the money that we raise will be going directly into the funding of this play!

See ALL OF OUR PERKS- Advertising opportunities available! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Don’t have the “dough” right now to contribute to our campaign? Well, you can still help us out at no cost to you. By just getting the word out there about our campaign, you would be helping us tremendously. Word of mouth can have a huge impact on a project like this, so please, SPREAD THE WORD! It’s so easy all you have to do is use the Indiegogo share tools.

NeverYouMind Productions would like to thank you kindly for your support!

Thank you!!

LOVE!

story:
The Crescent Troupe is a theatrical group committed to making classic plays like the works of Shakespeare and Marlowe available and accessible to more audiences, including schools. These stories are meant to be performed on stage and when delivered naturally and realistically are more present than when simply read. We intend to bring these stories to new audiences, often by using comedy, improv, and adapted scripts to make the language more familiar to modern ears, as well as often performing the stories as they were written. We also intend for ourselves to learn and grow through these plays, taking on new players in hopes to create a community of talented people with a good understanding of these classics. The Crescent Troupe should, at its core, be a source of education and entertainment to its audiences as well as its members.

A few months back, while prepping for our 6th production (a one hour, abridged version of Twelfth Night) the decision was made to postpone the show and raise funds and do a more involved production with more of the story, better sets, costumes, and to actually pay our actors who have been kind in the past to donate their talent for free! If you would like to see what we can do with a bigger budget, now is your chance! We are hoping to raise at least $5,000 (12 actors, costumes, props, sets, and the theater itself all add up!) We would love to not just sell advance tickets, but have tried to include a few special perks at different levels, including a video of our last show, A Little Hamlet*.  The perks are exclusive to each tier, so if you like mutliple perks, you can feel free to donate at each level.

Why $5,500?  here is a basic breakdown:

1500 - Theater (already spent)
1500 - Actors (8 of them for 4 shows)
750  - Costuming
500  - Set construction
500  - Promotion (posters, programs, web advertising , our own site)
500  - Indiegogo (the fees they take)
250  - Perks (cost for any items and shipping as needed)


We have a great batch of actors ready to pour their souls into this and have lined up a great theater space:
The Victory Theatre Center
3326 W Victory Blvd. Burbank, CA 91505
June 21 8PM, June 22 3PM and 8PM

So, if this sounds like a good idea to you, have a look at our perk list. And please spread the word!

((Any funds left over from this fundraiser will go to future productions.))

*A Little Hamlet: Even Shakespeare had to get investors. Here is a comedic glimpse of what might have been a first pitch of the classic Hamlet to get the ball rolling. Enjoy the famous classic lines, both in and out of the context of the play, as they are woven into the story of Hamlet learning his role while everyone gets pulled into his world.

History of the Crescent Troupe: The Troupe started as a street gig with a sign, Shakespearean Scenes performed in the streets. Since that first year in 2008, they have invaded and made a home on stage, performing both comedic takes on the tragedies (using the bard's original text as well as new material) and in 2011 mounting a 45 min production of Taming of the Shrew, as it was written. 2012-13 has seen the troupe venture out of the faire circuit and performing shows on the stages of Hollywood and Burbank!

story:
What is "Antony & Cleopatra: Infinite Lives"?

Antony & Cleopatra: Infinite Lives is a new play by J. Michael DeAngelis & Pete Barry, incorporating original text by William Shakespeare.  It's the story of  an Egyptian expatriate who gets caught between two revolutionaries - her fiancée, an activist director who tries to upend his commissioned Shakespeare production, and her brother, a nationalist fresh from the violence of Tahrir Square.
 
The show is being staged in the grand Lower Egyptian Gallery of the Penn Museum, in front of their centerpiece sphinx.  This unique and amazing venue adds a layer of spectacle and history to the show.
 
Drawn from still developing current events, this original play juxtaposes today's Egypt alongside Cleopatra's Egypt as seen by Shakespeare.  It puts a spotlight on theater as historical record and questions the role of the artist in politics.
 
The play is being produced as part of the 2012 Philly Fringe Festival by The Porch Room, an award-winning independent theater company, and The Underground Shakespeare Company, The University of Pennsylvania's first and only group dedicated to the works of William Shakespeare.  Mr. DeAngelis and Mr. Barry are multi-award winning playwrights, whose works have been published by Samuel French and Vintage Press.  This is their third original production for the Philly Fringe, having previously presented sold-out runs of X/Yand Signs from God, which recently concluded an encore production in New York City.
 
This is The Underground Shakespeare Company's second foray in the Fringe, having produced last year's smash hit, Wars & Whores.  This production, however, will be their first Fringe show to predominantly feature current students in the cast - making this an exciting first professional venture for many of them.

Why We're Asking For Your Help

Antony & Cleopatra: Infinite Lives is going to be an amazing show in an unforgettable space with a huge cast of twenty-seven people!  Producing a show on this scale presents new challenges to both the Porch Room and the Underground Shakespeare Company.

  • We've set a goal of $2,000. If we reach even half of that, you'll have done a lot to a make this show come alive.  If we can reach our total goal, however, it will ensure that this show gets the marketing campaign it deserves and reach as wide an audience as possible.
  • If we don't reach our goal, all donations will go towards the essentials - costumes and props.
  • A ticket to the show is included at most levels of donation!  Perks at higher levels include memberships to the museum, meaning you'll be supporting one of the city's great cultural institutions as well!
  • Ever wanted to have a play written just for you? WE CAN MAKE THAT HAPPEN! Support us at the highest level and the boys from The Porch Room will crank out an original one-act play!

How You'll Be Helping

Your donation goes a long way towards making our show shine.  Here are just a few examples of how you'll be helping:

  • $10-$20 is a prop! Anything from a Roman sword to a clipboard to an asp!
  • $50 covers one night of rehearsal in a professional studio space.
  • $100 gets us stacks of promotional postcards to distribute around the city!
  • $200 gets us a full color ad in the City Paper! An addition $60 will allow us to run it for two weeks!
  • $500 costumes a cast of twenty-seven!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Come see the show! Purchasing a ticket not only helps financially, it's why we're here!  Let us entertain you!
  • Talk up the show to your friends and family!
  • Tweet it, Facebook it, start a debate on Reddit about it...get some word of mouth going!

story:
"Ladies and Gentlemen: this is The Hystericon, a swollen darkness at the heart of a great asylum..."

 

Everything you will hear is true: in late 19th century Paris, Augustine, Blanche, and Geneviève are the most famous patients of Dr. Jean-Martin Charcot at the Salpêtrière insane asylum for women. They are his personal lab rats and performance artists, models and test subjects, as he conducts his experiments in "hysteria," that dark recess of psychiatric medicine. Through the nascent technologies of photography, and the black arts of hypnotism and psychopharmacology, Charcot turns them from troubled women into Hysterics, celebrities of the Belle Epoque:  Augustine the Photogenic, whose pictures adorn Charcot's publications; Blanche, "The Queen of Hysterics," star performer in his public lectures; and Geneviève la Pucelle, who talks to God and believes she is possessed by demons - tonight they perform for their audience an hysterical revue, a cabaret, en  Comédie en vaudeville, demonstrating the history and pathology of hysteria - but something seems to be going wrong. As lines are dropped and cues missed, the show starts to crumble, and the odyssey takes  turn for the strange...

This debut production from Good Old Neon, an avant-garde theatre company from Toronto, is written and directed by company founder Alexander Offord, who was seen featured alongside actress Nicole Wilson in the Fringe 2012 production of A Madhouse Dramedy. It also stars Nicholas Porteous as the malevolent disembodied voice of Charcot (Alumnae Theatre's Woman of No Importance),  Renée Haché (Aim for the Tangent's Mature Young Adults) and Lesley Robertson, seen last summer as Julia in Shakespeare in the Ruff's Two Gents.

 

Our need...

The biggest expenses for any Fringe show is nearly always rehearsal space. For a show like The Hystericon, space takes on a new importance: the show is highly choreographed, slick and stylized, even atheletic. We need large spaces with high ceilings and hard floors to get the piece running optimally.

The spaces are available: the Fringe Creation Lab, Toronto's newest subsidized space for artists, and The Lower Ossington Theatre, a gorgeous cabaret space in Queen West. With your help, we'll ensure that our actors are able to live up to the full potential their prodigious talents.

 

Your donation...

...will allow us to provide audiences with a product that is polished, professional, and deeply moving. The Hystericon was inspired by the true life-stories of Augustine, Blanche, and Geneviève, and by the hundreds of black-and-white photographs taken of them by Dr. Charcot and his associates, found in the infamous Iconographie
photographique de la Salpêtrière, the asylum's annual photo album. It is a  tribute to a long history of forgotten women, but more than that, it allows for their redemption. The cast represents a new generation of total-actors, who are able to combine classical theatre technique with clown, dance, performance art, and physical theatre to create a work that is at once funny and disturbing, full of darkness as much as love. With your help, we can tell these stories, and in so doing, bring them to life again.

Every cent of your money will go into budget for the show, with an emphasis on providing top-notch rehearsal spaces for our actors.

 

For You

At Good Old Neon, we believe what goes around comes around, and we love to reward our donors. Thus, we have a few perks:

  • $5-$10 gets you an original button featuring a classic image from the Iconographie photographique de la Salpêtrière, plus a shout-out on our Twitter feed and blog!
  • $10-$25 gets you three original buttons, each with a different image, plus shout-out
  • $25-$50 gets you three buttons, a shout-out, and a special thank-you in our program
  • $50-$75 gets you three buttons, a thank you in our program, a shout-out and a copy of our poster signed by the cast
  • $100+ gets you all of the above, plus a free ticket to see the show!

Whatever else may be said, one thing is certain: you will not have seen a show like The Hystericon before. We can't wait to see you there!

Everything you will hear is true: in late 19th century Paris, Augustine, Blanche, and Geneviève are the most famous patients of Dr. Jean-Martin Charcot at the Salpêtrière insane asylum for women. They are his personal lab rats and performance artists, models and test subjects, as he conducts his experiments in "hysteria," that dark recess of psychiatric medicine. Through the nascent technologies of photography, and the black arts of hypnotism and psychopharmacology, Charcot turns them from troubled women into Hysterics, celebrities of the Belle Epoque:  Augustine the Photogenic, whose pictures adorn Charcot's publications; Blanche, "The Queen of Hysterics," star performer in his public lectures; and Geneviève la Pucelle, who talks to God and believes she is possessed by demons - tonight they perform for their audience an hysterical revue, a cabaret, en  Comédie en vaudeville, demonstrating the history and pathology of hysteria - but something seems to be going wrong. As lines are dropped and cues missed, the show starts to crumble, and the odyssey takes  turn for the strange...
This debut production from Good Old Neon, an avant-garde theatre company from Toronto, is written and directed by company founder Alexander Offord, who was seen featured alongside actress Nicole Wilson in the Fringe 2012 production of A Madhouse Dramedy. It also stars Nicholas Porteous as the malevolent disembodied voice of Charcot (Alumnae Theatre's Woman of No Importance),  Renée Haché (Aim for the Tangent's Mature Young Adults) and Lesley Robertson, seen last summer as Julia in Shakespeare in the Ruff's Two Gents.


 
Our need...
The biggest expenses for any Fringe show is nearly always rehearsal space. For a show like The Hystericon, space takes on a new importance: the show is highly choreographed, slick and stylized, even atheletic. We need large spaces with high ceilings and hard floors to get the piece running optimally.
The spaces are available: the Fringe Creation Lab, Toronto's newest subsidized space for artists, and The Lower Ossington Theatre, a gorgeous cabaret space in Queen West. With your help, we'll ensure that our actors are able to live up to the full potential their prodigious talents.

 
Your donation...
...will allow us to provide audiences with a product that is polished, professional, and deeply moving. The Hystericon was inspired by the true life-stories of Augustine, Blanche, and Geneviève, and by the hundreds of black-and-white photographs taken of them by Dr. Charcot and his associates, found in the infamous Iconographiephotographique de la Salpêtrière, the asylum's annual photo album. It is a  tribute to a long history of forgotten women, but more than that, it allows for their redemption. The cast represents a new generation of total-actors, who are able to combine classical theatre technique with clown, dance, performance art, and physical theatre to create a work that is at once funny and disturbing, full of darkness as much as love. With your help, we can tell these stories, and in so doing, bring them to life again.
Every cent of your money will go into budget for the show, with an emphasis on providing top-notch rehearsal spaces for our actors.
 
For You
At Good Old Neon, we believe what goes around comes around, and we love to reward our donors. Thus, we have a few perks:

$5-$10 gets you an original button featuring a classic image from the Iconographie photographique de la Salpêtrière, plus a shout-out on our Twitter feed and blog!
$10-$25 gets you three original buttons, each with a different image, plus shout-out
$25-$50 gets you three buttons, a shout-out, and a special thank-you in our program
$50-$75 gets you three buttons, a thank you in our program, a shout-out and a copy of our poster signed by the cast
$100+ gets you all of the above, plus a free ticket to see the show!
Whatever else may be said, one thing is certain: you will not have seen a show like The Hystericon before. We can't wait to see you there!

story:
Short Summary

My two previous solo shows, entirely self-funded, garnered multiple four and five star reviews. Nosferatu's Shadow (2016) was also shortlisted for the Scottish Arts Club Theatre Award, and has been nominated for the Dracula Society's Hamilton Deane Award. 

Nijinsky's Last Jump (2015), for which I wrote the text, received multiple five star reviews and was a Pick of the Year in both the Guardian and the Telegraph. 

I make accessible, intelligent theatre that tells unfamiliar stories that deserve to be heard or familiar stories seen from an unfamiliar perspective.

1917, A Phantasmagoria is a quirky, often comical guide to some of the highways and many of the byways of a watershed year.

 

What We Need & What You Get

£1500 would enable me to cover part of venue hire, would pay for all publicity materials, props etc. and would enable me to pay my professional and highly skilled director and technician for their work. 

All donations of up to £15 will be rewarded with a signed copy of Ash Pryce's beautiful poster. 

Donations of between £15 and £25 will receive one complimentary ticket.

Donations of over £25 will receive two complimentary tickets.

Donations of over £50 will receive two complimentary tickets and a signed poster. 

The target of £1500 is well below the total cost of putting the show on, not even covering the full venue hire cost. I am still self-funding to a significant degree. So, any funding received will be needed and used for the production.

 

You'll be helping a respected independent theatre maker to continue producing accessible, unusual, informative work with no support from the mainstream establishment.

Here are some reviews and comments about Hyde & Seek and Nosferatu's Shadow:

'...funny intelligent and poignant.' 'Brilliant beautiful and bold.' 'Fabulous!' 'Totally amazing!' 'A virtuoso piece of storytelling.'    HYDE & SEEK, quadruple four-star reviewed.

★★★★★ ‘mesmerising’ ...... 'Phenomenal'.... 'Masterclass'.... 'Spellbinding'
'Michael Daviot is a superb actor and this is a tour-de-force.' 'HIDDEN GEM'     NOSFERATU'S SHADOW, two five-star reviews and five four-star, plus two award nominations.

 

If you're interested, but can't afford to donate, please just help to spread the word. Thanks!

story:
Passion Theatre budded from the desire to give unique opportunities to aspiring and passionate artists, who might not have an outlet to delve into these productions otherwise. My name is Aidan Montgomery and I'm the founder and director of Passion Theatre. I’ve been involved in theatre, both onstage and offstage, for a decade, and very soon realized it was the only thing I could ever see myself doing as a career. I wasn’t exactly sure what I wanted to do with that passion though until I realized that I did not want to always just wait until I was picked by directors, and I took heed to something my father had been telling me for a while — Pick Yourself.

So that’s exactly what I did. I decided to take charge and create what I wanted to create. That’s how Passion Theatre Group was born, and we put on our first show only 5 months after I started planning. 

I named the group how I did because I believe that above everything else, passion is the most important ingredient to succeeding. Passion is what drives us to persevere through the trials and adversities the world throws at us. 

Thank you for your time and consideration of supporting Passion Theatre Group!

WHAT MAKES US DIFFERENT

What we’re striving for with Passion Theatre Group is to change the way people see theatre in this area. To put on shows that will challenge our thoughts, stomp on our everyday conventions, and really impact us. Theatre is about pushing boundaries and being able to bring the deepest and darkest realities to the light in the realest way possible.

Shows will be put on in a variety of unique spaces as to create new and exciting theatre experiences, including possibly taking some shows on the road! Future plans include opening up a storefront theatre, but in the meantime, we will move wherever opportunity strikes! 

We do not consider ourselves a community theatre, but rather a startup professional company. 

Here are the reasons why:

-While we will still put on the tried and true war horses of theatre that will undoubtedly bring in a larger audience, our main focus is to produce many darker, nail-biting, avant-garde productions that you won’t normally see at surrounding theaters. 

-We will be providing compensation for everyone involved, including the ACTORS, which is something no theatre in the area does. And our goal is to eventually, even compensate typically-volunteered positions such as ushers and backstage crew. 

-Instead of just choosing the season’s shows and then having interested directors submit themselves for one, we will have directors submit themselves along with a show or shows they’re passionate about directing and the season will be chosen based off of that. Because we truly believe, as the name of our group suggests, passion is the key to success.

WHAT YOU'LL BE INVESTING IN

Passion has grown at an alarming rate for a new theatre company in Michigan, which we're very grateful for. While ticket revenue has been able to cover most of the following shows' expenses, we don't have enough money left for the necessary business tools we need in order to grow and expand. These tools include:

*DBA (Doing Business As) 

*Non-Profit Status 

*Business License 

*Liability Insurance

*Larger Marketing

*Our goal is to, within the next five years, be able to open up our own venue, a blackbox style theatre, which along with holding unique theatre experiences and parties, will also be opened up to the public for cheap rehearsal space, wedding receptions, events, etc...

HOW YOU'LL BE BENEFITING

We want to make sure you, as sponsors, feeling deeply appreciated for your support. So here are the rewards you get for contributing:

Anything under $25: Our undying gratitude for your contribution. 

Foster: $25-$99: Name in the program (+logo if a business) for the next show.

Artist: $100-$499: Name/logo in the program for the ENTIRE season, plus 4 free tickets to the upcoming show. 

Director: $500-$999: Name and/or logo in the program for the entire season, 4 free tickets to EVERY show for the next season, and honorable mention in the pre-show announcement for the upcoming show. 

Passion Flame: $1000+: Name and/or logo in the program for the entire season, 8 free tickets to EVERY show for the next season, mention in the pre-show announcement for the ENTIRE season, PLUS if a business, providing advertisement for you on our social media platforms.

*All complimentary tickets provided will be held at the box office under your name or business.  

If you would like to sponsor a specific project out of the ones listed above, or have any questions of any sort, please email Aidan at aidan@passiontheatre.com to discuss details.

Thank you for your support of the arts!

story:
Summary

Let’s get clinical! Directed by award winning comedian Leigh Cameron, Generally Hospital is a comedic sketch revue about a serious place: the hospital. Impossible rules for newborn babies, songs about death, and finding love in a room filled with farts: we have you covered for an hour of laughter, tears, and other bodily functions.

During a sketch performance earlier this year, the show was interrupted by Ophira’s wheelchair tipping over the side of the stage and falling into the audience, resulting in a 2-week long hospital stay. When Grace came to visit, the two realized how different their perceptions of the hospital were and decided sketch comedy was the best way to confront the mysterious, confusing, and even frightening monolith that is THE HOSPITAL.

Calof and Smith filled out their dream-team with a diverse bunch of hilarious comedians; Leigh Cameron, Devan Islas, Sabrina Friedman, Alia Rasul, Ryan Hughes, Brie Watson, and Nicole Byblow, and thus Generally Hospital was born.

There is a huge stigma around illness, disability, and bodily functions. So many people living with illness feel isolated, struggling to find ways to come to terms with a life they had never imagined. The need to talk (and laugh!) about these human experiences is more important today than ever before.

We all have some connection to hospitals, whether we’ve experienced illness or injury, through tests and appointments, visits to a loved one, working, volunteering, or seeing it depicted on TV. This show tells the untold stories of hospitals, focusing on points of view that are underrepresented, uncomfortable, and surprisingly funny.

Where the Funds Go

  • Generally Hospital is looking to raise funds to cover the expenses of putting on a show, including paying our cast, crew and creative team as well as the costs associated with providing three adapted performances: a relaxed performance, an audio described performance, and ASL interpreted performance

Tickets

  • Toronto Fringe Festival tickets are on sale now! Get your tickets for Generally Hospital HERE. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this campaign on social media with all of your friends and family
  • Follow us @GenerallyHospital on Facebook, and @GenralyHospital on Twitter. Use the hashtag #HospitalGlam on Social Media.
  • Talk about accessibility within your communities
  • Buy tickets to one (or more) of our performances 

If you're interested in purchasing an advertisement in our programme, or other sponsorship, partnership or promotional opportunities, we'd love to hear from you! Please contact us at generallyhospital@gmail.com.

And that's all there is to it. We can't wait to laugh with you at the show!

story:
SLiDE was co-founded in 2013 by Gemma Coldicott and Anita Wadsworth to provide access to high quality dance provision for people of all ages and abilities in South London. In December 2015 became a registered charity, no 1164827. SLiDE has 5 core values: accessibility, collaboration, creativity, quality, play.

The SLiDE Super Saturdays, as our monthly workshops are known, provide an invaluable activity to adults with learning disabilities in the borough. We deliver them in partnership with Club Soda, http://www.clubsoda.org.uk. 'Please do more of these workshops, our service users really enjoy them. Dance keeps them fit and helps their creativity' Hannah, Day Centre Manager. Coronary heart disease is the leading cause of death for adults with learning disabilities and dance plays a vital role in getting people active/increasing their life expectancy. 

By raising £500 we will able to pay for the vital support staff needed to run Super Saturday sessions in 2017. Keeping everyone safe and increasing the quality of everyones experience. 

AND! with even more support for our slide-a-thon (i.e if we raise MORE than £500) we are hoping to INCREASE our provision from a monthly to a weekly class, as we can use the funds to attract matched funding. Through this increase we would not only be providing more regular exercise but we would also be working towards a performance group. That means we can recognise and celebrate the talent our dancers, and there is plenty of it, by providing them additional creative and choreographic training to create performances for national touring. So as you can see we have lots of ambitious plans for our group and with your contribution you are helping nurture this talent and ambition.  

AND....if you pledge we have some unique perks for you such as a dance class in your workplace or school, dance birthday party, a slide thank you film or a thank you postcard from our lovely Super Saturday dancers.

Don't worry if you are unable to contribute this time. You can help us by setting a slide challenge. See what unique ways we can go down a slide or set us a 30 second playground choreography challenge. Any challenges: gemma@slidedance.org. You can also follow the action on Facebook (SLiDE Dance) and Twitter (@DanceSlide, #SlideforSLiDE, #PeopleVsSlide #SlideSuperSaturdays) like, follow, retweet, it ALL helps. 

Thanks! and keeeeeeeeeeep sliding!

story:
The Play

Fresh from a sell-out run at the Lion & Unicorn Theatre in Kentish Town, Courier 12 Productions in association with KDC Theatre bring their acclaimed production of Melanie Marnich’s These Shining Lives to the Pleasance StageSpace.

Shining through history, this is the true story of four ordinary women from the roaring twenties, who themselves learned how to roar.  It’s 1922 and Catherine Donohue is starting a brand-new job at Radium Dial, where she and her friends have the brightest time of their lives. But work always costs you something – and they’re about to pay a heavy price. For time is running out. Now, they must make every second count, and find the courage to fight for justice.

Come hear them roar. Come see them shine. This is Courier 12’s production of These Shining Lives. A luminous play about love, friendship, and strength you never knew you had.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise £1500 to stage These Shining Lives. This is where your lovely donations will be going:

  • £166 pays for one night's rent at The Pleasance Studio
  • £65 pays for one night's royalties for the show
  • £20 pays for a day's marketing
  • £16 pays for one night's insurance
  • £10 goes towards our daily costume budget 
  • If you can contribute £50 that gets you Executive Producer status; the West End and Broadway are calling! 
  • Even if we don't make the full amount, everything helps towards getting the show on the road!

The Impact

The reviews that These Shining Lives received in early 2015 made us realise that the story of the Radium Girls was so compelling, it needed telling again, to a wider audience.

In the face of certain death, these women were courageous beyond measure. They changed the world. They protected others. They made a difference.

Their legacy lives on to this day.

Teachers and Education

The timing could not be more apt for this London staging, with workers’ rights currently under attack. The women’s story still resonates today in a world where profit, rather than human life, is often the priority. But politics aside, above all the play showcases the humanity and courage of these four women, and brings their almost-forgotten story into the limelight, where it belongs.

This play can work as an excellent stimulus for debate in PSHE, drama, history, sociology and government and politics lessons, with its content traversing issues such as workers’ rights, feminism, the Great Depression, employment tribunals, as well as the most human issues of love and friendship and moral culpability. Below is an educational pack with two lesson plans and accompanying powerpoints, which can be used before and after seeing the play.

  • Education Pack (PDF)
  • Lesson Plan 1 (PPTX)
  • Lesson Plan 2 (PPTX)

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, please raise awareness of this great show (and the fundraising campaign) by sharing our website, our Facebook page, our Twitter handle and hashtags and of course the Indiegogo page and all of the lovely things that have been said about These Shining Lives.

We had a sell-out run last time - we'd love to do it again!

    Other Ways You Can Help Even if you can't donate, please raise awareness of this great show (and the fundraising campaign) by sharing our website, our Facebook page, our Twitter handle and hashtags and of course the Indiegogo page and all of the lovely things that have been said about These Shining Lives.
We had a sell-out run last time - we'd love to do it again!

story:
What We Are Doing

A new play reading series, Playwrights at the Grand, has teamed up with playwright Monica Giordano and director Rebecca Cunningham to put up Monica's latest piece, Hand Grenades, at this year's New York International Fringe Festival. This is the type of original theatre that has a powerful message for modern audiences, and the Fringe Festival will be the perfect platform for us to share this piece with our community. 

Hand Grenades is a play about holding on, the ways in which we love and the ways in which we leave. The main relationship of the play, between Diana and Ophelia, is based on small things: days, phrases and little looks. But it is all of those small things that create one big thing: Love. When another big thing, Tragedy, affects Ophelia, Ophelia seeks comfort in silence, and Diana seeks comfort in Troy.

Hand Grenades, by Monica Giordano

Directed by Rebecca Cunningham

Featuring:

Kristina Mueller

Chris Fayne

and Elizabeth Gray

Set Design by Lacey Ballard

Sound Design by Dorothy James Loechel

Light Design by Chelsie McPhilimy

Costume Design by Debbi Hobson

Prop Design by Brandon Hardy

Hand Grenades will be performed at The Steve & Marie Sgouros Theatre August 14th at 7:15pm, August 19th at 5:15pm, August 22nd at 2:45pm, August 23rd at 7:45pm, and August 25th at 7pm.

Hand Grenades is sponsored in part by The Grand Bar and Grill.

This play can make a difference in the lives of anyone searching to find their place in love or dealing with sexual violence. However we need your help!

While the Fringe is an incredible opportunity, it is also an expensive one. Our goal of $5000 will cover the cost of rehearsal space, production expenses, and our creative team. Keep reading below for more details as to where these funds will go, and please consider donating what you can to this production. Sharing this campaign goes a long way towards helping us reach our goal as well!

Where our money is going

There are a multitude of expenses the go into producing a show in New York City, and while the Fringe does an incredible job at supporting artists and opportunities, they can only provide each show with so much.

A main expense this campaign will help to fund is REHEARSAL SPACE. I often dream that we live in a beautiful rural village filled with open space AND talented artists, but as any New Yorker can attest to, rooms in the city just aren't free.

SET, PROPS, COSTUMES, LIGHTING EQUIPMENT, and SCRIPTS are each an expense that we are relying on all of you to help subsidize through this campaign. We are blessed with an incredible team of designers, with wonderful ideas and beautiful dreams, and we want to let their creativity flow uninhibited by minor expenses. Don't get me wrong, we are a group of THRIFTY THEATRE MAKERS, and aren't squandering expenses on lavish ball gowns and chandeliers. But the financial support all of you can provide will open doors to our designers that will allow us to put on the best show possible.

Speaking of designers, we are working with INCREDIBLE TALENT! And we want to be able to support the wonderful work these actors and designers are doing by providing them a stipend for their time and energy.

Other Ways You Can Help

We want to be as transparent and realistic with this campaign as possible. If you are not in a position to donate, there are still many ways you can help us make this show a reality!

SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN! Shout us out on Facebook, tweet about the work we are doing, or email your friends and family about our fundraising campaign. Check out our facebook page by CLICKING HERE! And we're on TWITTER! (@_handgrenades). We learned once that people need to see something SEVEN times before deciding to act, so any mention will do us a world of good.

JOIN OUR TEAM! We are looking for ushers and box office staff for each performance. Volunteering your time would be a huge help for the show, and would also let you see the production for free! We are also looking for a TECHNICAL DIRECTION INTERN and an ASSISTANT STAGE MANAGER, so please reach out to playwrightsatthegrand@gmail.com with ANY questions about how you can be involved.

THANK YOU!
From the bottom of all of our hearts, thank you for clicking whatever link brought you here. Thank you for reading, thank you for caring, and THANK YOU FOR SUPPORTING OUR SHOW AND THE INDIE THEATRE COMMUNITY! 

See you in August. =]
With Love,
Monica Giordano, Rebecca Cunningham, Clarke Bliss and Chad Chenail

See you in August. =]
With Love,
