story:
A new play by Sara Cooper
Directed by Noah Himmelstein
Executive Producer: Gregory Jacobs-Roseman

Starring:
Lindsay Goranson, Susanna Hari, Jennifer Mello, Michael S. Rehse, and Elysia Segal

Things I Left On Long Island needs your help!

This August, Things I Left On Long Island by Larson Grant recipient Sara Cooper (Transport Group's The Memory Show) makes its world premiere at the New York International Fringe Festival, directed by Noah Himmelstein (Andrew Lippa's I Am Harvey Milk).

When 28-year-old Marny finds a lump in her breast, she moves in with her mother. Pretending she isn’t flunking adulthood, she must either succumb to the whims of a family in crisis, or take back her life—and her play.

We here at Roadie Soadie Productions are hard at work putting this show together, but we need your help to make it a reality!

What We Need & What You Get

Mounting a play isn’t cheap. There are a lot of costs when putting on a production of a play, including:

  • Set 
  • Costumes 
  • Props 
  • Sound equipment 
  • Rehearsal space 
  • Promotion 
  • Festival fees 
  • Transportation 
  • Printing and other administrative costs 
  • Insurance

Among others. Not to mention, we would like to compensate our team for their hard work.

Won’t you please help us by making a contribution to the cause? No donation is too small. Every little bit helps! A lot helps more ;) We're offering some wonderful perks for your donation, which you can see in the sidebar to the right.

What's more, thanks to our sponsorship by Fractured Atlas, all contributions are tax-deductible!*

Impact

Your donation will go directly to making Things I Left On Long Island the best production it can possibly be. It has been a long journey to bring this full production to FringeNYC, and we are very excited that it will finally be seen by an international audience in the most well-known theatre festival in New York City. We want to dress to impress!

Please give what you can.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute right now, consider attending one of our shows. Tickets will go on sale in mid-July and will be available at FringeNYC.org. Show dates to be announced soon!

You can also spread the word about our campaign to your friends! 

Also, we are all over the internet:

Facebook: www.facebook.com/thingsileftonlongisland

Website: www.thingsileftonlongisland.com

Twitter: @thingsileftonli

Thanks and check back for updates!

*Note: The value of any gifts received as perks is non tax-deductible. These values are indicated for each individual perk.
story_txt:
A new play by Sara CooperDirected by Noah HimmelsteinExecutive Producer: Gregory Jacobs-RosemanStarring:Lindsay Goranson, Susanna Hari, Jennifer Mello, Michael S. Rehse, and Elysia Segal
Things I Left On Long Island needs your help!

This August,
Things I Left On Long Island by Larson Grant recipient Sara Cooper (Transport Group's The Memory Show) makes its world premiere at the New
York International Fringe Festival, directed by Noah Himmelstein (Andrew Lippa's I Am Harvey Milk).
When 28-year-old Marny finds a lump
in her breast, she moves in with her mother. Pretending she isn’t flunking
adulthood, she must either succumb to the whims of a family in crisis, or take
back her life—and her play.
We here at
Roadie Soadie Productions are hard at work putting this show together, but we
need your help to make it a reality!
What We Need
& What You Get
Mounting a play
isn’t cheap. There are a lot of costs when putting on a production of a play,
including:

Set 
Costumes 
Props 
Sound equipment 
Rehearsal space 
Promotion 
Festival fees 
Transportation 
Printing and other administrative costs 
Insurance


Among others.
Not to mention, we would like to compensate our team for their hard work.
Won’t you
please help us by making a contribution to the cause? No donation is too small. Every little bit helps! A lot helps more ;) We're offering some 
wonderful perks for your donation, which you can
see in the sidebar to the right.
What's more, thanks to our sponsorship by Fractured Atlas, all contributions
are tax-deductible!*

Impact
Your donation will
go directly to making Things I Left On Long Island the best production it can possibly be. It has been a long journey to bring this full production to FringeNYC, and
we are very excited that it will finally be seen by an international audience in
the most well-known theatre festival in New York City. We want to dress to
impress!Please give
what you can.
Other Ways You
Can Help
If you can't
contribute right now, consider attending one of our shows. Tickets will go on
sale in mid-July and will be available at FringeNYC.org. Show dates to be announced soon!
You can also
spread the word about our campaign to your friends! 
Also, we are
all over the internet:
Facebook: www.facebook.com/thingsileftonlongisland
Website: www.thingsileftonlongisland.com
Twitter: @thingsileftonli
Thanks and
check back for updates!
*Note: The value of any gifts
received as perks is non tax-deductible. These values are indicated for
each individual perk.

story:
We are happy to announce that Elsewhere tour is going forward. Obviously we did not do as well as we would have liked on our fundraising. It’s resulted into a situation where we are very much scraping the bottom of the treasure chest to create this. We still have until Monday night to raise a few more pounds and now it is making a huge difference how difficult this all will be. We will spend the summer touring with very little money and lots of love in our hearts.

So a last little bid, please share, like and donate to our project. We need every last little bit, how ever little.

Meet Rob and Suzy and see one of the locations where the trees from our tree planting perk will be growing.


Meet Jess, our art director!!!



As featured in

  • Daily Record, 13th May 2015.
  • STV, 21st April 2015.
  • Permaculture Magazine, 13th April 2015.


The Travellers of Elsewhere is a solar powered horse-drawn travelling show that combines circus and theatre with conversation on sustainable lifestyles. Blending storytelling, circus, live music, and magic, we invite you to an unforgettable immersive experience. Step inside another world, until now, found only in folklore. 

The Travellers of Elsewhere hit the road properly in July, heading north from Tir Na Nog to Calander, Killin, Aberfeldy, Pitlochry and Crieff.  

Along the way we will be: 

  • welcoming you to the world of Elsewhere
  • living low-impact and close to nature 
  • offering free workshops in theatre and circus
  • planting trees (see more below)
  • covering over 200 miles by foot and hoof

With your support the magic of Elsewhere will reach as many people as possible, 

By reaching our goal of £25,000, we will produce the circus of our wildest dreams. If we raise less than that, The Travellers of Elsewhere will still go ahead. 

For example, £5000 pays pays for one horse and all its needs, upgrading our existing carriage and the solar panels - enough to get us moving. 

More support = a bigger circus. We dream big, do you?

We relish this awesome challenge and the opportunity to make something really unique and inspiring.





A horse-drawn circus is certainly a romantic way to move about the country. We believe this lifestyle carries greater significance than nostalgic charm. Horses require little more than grass, water and room to run. Much more sustainable than motorised transport that relies on air-polluting fossil fuels, factory machined parts, and global distribution networks.

A horse drawn circus can’t get far without horses. We realized from the beginning that an experienced horse person was essential. A lot of unexpected things can happen on the road. A horse can throw a shoe, get spooked or become ill. The required skills appeared in the person of Raina Jones. Raina has worked on horse-logging crews and pulled a canal barge. She’s been riding, grooming and training horses all her life. We take the safety of the horses very seriously and Elsewhere’s horses are in good hands.

Slower travel allows for a deeper connection with the land you are crossing. Trees are intoxicatingly wonderful at 3 miles an hour - harder to appreciate at 60. As more people take pleasure in nature, the greater the likelihood that Scotland’s natural beauty will grow.

While we embrace the marvels a high-tech society – people around the world can follow Elsewhere through social media – we also believe these modern times can learn a lot from traditional lifestyles.

In an age of digital entertainment, live performance and real interaction with living things are especially important to a healthy culture. Quality human experiences filled with creative expression, positive community, shared laughter, music, and celebration, are all possible – and often more genuine – without depending on sophisticated technologies. 


The Travellers of Elsewhere are most at home in the wild greenwood. We would love to see Scotland’s forests spread from coast to coast. To help this along, we will be planting trees throughout the tour. 

Please check out the £15 Plant a Tree perk. We have teamed up with Woodland Trust Scotland and for every £15 you donate, £5 will go directly to the Trust as their buy a tree incentive. Additionally, we have found a piece of land near the Pentland Hills wanting the cultivation of a new forest. We will match each of the Trust trees with another planted on this site. Let’s plant at least 1000 trees, or even 10,000.


Making new friends is one of the great joys of travel. Elsewhere has partnered with the Scottish Community Drama Association to help us include as many people in our project as possible.  We are offering a free in-depth workshop session with the directors and cast to anyone interested in creating their own Elsewhere persona and taking part in a live performance.  If you would like to work with a professional performance company on a highly unique production, please get in touch.

This is an awesome challenge and we relish the opportunity to make something really unique and inspiring.


Sit spell bound under a leafy canopy as a storyteller calls to life tales from myth and legend. Woodland sprites spring from the trees with impressive aerial artistry. Jugglers dazzles with feats of dexterous manipulation beyond comprehension. Dance to the lively tunes of Elvish musicians. This is a day you will remember and talk about forever.


This is our fantastically handsome, custom made carriage. She was built by Dan Brown of Labryrinth, New Castle. You’ll agree he did a remarkable job. Indeed, her like has never been seen before. But two more wagons are needed to carry all the tents, costumes, props, cooking gear, food, feed, and tools of touring circus.

Of course the biggest wildcard when performing outdoors in Scotland is the weather. We don’t mind walking through windy rain, (Well, we don’t mind that much.) But our audiences have to be cozy and dry. 


Consultations with a certified rigger have lead to an approved workable design for a canopy that hangs from the trees and is adaptable to different locations. Most importantly, visitors to Elsewhere will enjoy a comfortable experience whatever the weather. 

Due to the structure of crowd funding platforms such as Indiegogo, 25% of the funding target will go directly into producing this campaign. The 75% majority of the money will then be used to make this project happen. This is how we spend it.

Horses

  • Three strong and sturdy cobs for our wagons and carriage.  Cobs are the traditional choice among horse travellers for generations. They are a tough, hardy breed, well able to handle the rigors of life in the Scottish hills.

Equipment for the horses

  • Full harnesses, brushes, hoof picks, new shoes, hay and portable shelter to make sure that our horses are comfortable and happy pulling us around the country side. We also require vet and farrier services, as well as insurance. 

Wagons

  • Our existing carriage will have to take the weight of several performers at once and serve as a stable platform for hand-stands and other acrobatics. To ensure that it is safe and suitable as circus equipment, it requires a more robust suspension with stronger axles and wheels.
  • We will also purchase two drays – one to carry the canvas tents and one to serve as the kitchen wagon and tool store. This second dray will be fitted with cupboards for the tools and kitchen equipment. It will have a comfortable, sheltered interior in the event that any performers or crew members are too ill or injured to walk.

Tent

  • Over 350 square meters of lovely burgundy Regentex TM water and rot proofed canvas; as well as the ropes, bamboo poles, eyelets and other hardware to safely construct and rig our otherworldly circus tent. 

Solar Panels and Batteries

  • We will have some electrical devices and small electrical effects. These will be charged from solar panels on the roof of the kitchen wagon. 
Please view a more accurate breakdown of the budget here.

Elsewhere is the creative partnership of former Directors of te POOKa, a performing arts charity in Edinburgh, Scotland.  Until it closed in 2011, te POOKa produced some of Scotland’s most innovative and engaging circus theatre.  Renowned for creating enchanted spaces in unexpected locations, te POOKa performed in village halls, grand ballrooms, castles, fields and forests from Edinburgh to the Outer Hebrides and everywhere in between. We unleashed a dragon in the woods of Tain and hosted a Midsummer Faerie Ball on the lawns of Gleneagles. It has been a privilege to share our circus and story magic with audiences in so many stunning settings. 

BBC filming the te POOKa show Big Willow

Scotland has incredible scenery, and we take great delight celebrating the natural world.  We operate a leave-no-trace policy, which includes: 

  • Sifting through bonfire ashes for stray nails and bits of wire  
  • Building sets with recycled materials 
  • Composting all food waste  
  • Shopping in farmers markets and local retailers 
  • Always looking for ways to lighten our environmental impact

We wanted our next project after te POOKa to be even more sustainable.  After years of driving around the country in vans, we realised that burning diesel was potentially offsetting the rest of our ecological efforts. Also, we wished to inspire in others the enchantment we found in the woods we visited. From these desires  came The Travellers of Elsewhere: Scotland’s first horse-drawn circus since the middle of last century. 


We are deeply grateful to everyone who contributes to Elsewhere.  For helping to support this dream coming true, we are offering exclusive access to the Travellers of Elsewhere Tour Blog to all who contribute.  Please follow along with the adventure.

It does help to see what you are getting sometimes. So here's a little image gallery of the perks that are physical items.

A Token of Graditude

This handcrafted wooden coin is a memento of a good turn done with love. Save it. One day you can exchange it for something you desire.

A Cup of Plenty

A good drinking vessel is a must-have for any journey into Faerie, and a stylish accessory for the best festivals and parties. Especially for our friends far away; you can sit back, sip a tasty beverage, and plot your own magical journey.

It is approximately 3 inches high and 2.5 inches wide.

Dream Diary

Capture your dreams and start bringing them to life. Each Journal is beautifully bound in tooled leather with a personal inscription from a member of the company. A keepsake for inspiration and delight.

A Piece of Enchantment

The Entry Elsewhere - A limited edition print of original Elsewhere pre-production artwork, signed by the artist.



The Travellers of Elsewhere is an exciting and ambitions fusion of contemporary and traditional art forms - a potent mix of circus, theatre, improvisation and storytelling. Our solar-powered circus is a groundbreaking way of promoting environmental awareness and sustainable lifestyles in a way that is engaging and entertaining.

We are looking forward to welcoming you to the world of Elsewhere.

Extra thanks if you support this project. Browse our perks and find one that tickles your fancy.

Please spread the word on facebook, twitter, email…and actually talking to people, in person.



Credits:

Video

  • Director, camera operator and editor – Tomas Sheridan
  • Puppets made by Lisette Boxman and clothed by ChANGELing
  • Music by Hangwallah

Photographs by Kat Dlugosz, Skye Alex Lyon, Anita Barrow and Caitlin Worthington.

story:
Who we are

When Bere’sheet Ballet was formed, it immediately took on a life of its own, attracting artists who had suffered sexual abuse, domestic violence, spiritual and cult abuse, and cancer survivors. For many, the company became a haven for the hurting, and dance became their path of healing.

What we do....

Because of that universal assignment for us, every concert we perform is a benefit.  25% of the ticket price goes to a fund to help those in need. We believe that we can change the planet – one person at a time. We are completely dependent on funding from people like you who are of the same heart and mind.

Our present project...

We are raising funds for the editing and completion of our latest film and its premiere in the Fall of this year:  “Repair the World.” It is a documentary with interviews of various women and their stories, featuring dance, and Grammy winner Cynthia Clawson. We will need: $2,500 for the completion of the editing of the film. $2,500 for theater rental for the World Premiere. $1,500 for the music rights .$500 for the reproduction of the DVDs

We performed Repair the World in October 2011. The concert focuses on raising consciousness not only of the human condition, but as human beings: “Any act of kindness – no matter how great or how small, repairs the world.”  We are hoping to bring this awareness with Repair the World – the film - to a global venue through distribution. I am inviting you to participate in that vision for us...helping us to make the premiere of the film in the Fall of this year...2012...a success. Bere’sheet Ballet is a 501-C-3 non- profit organization.

Our track record....

For the last fourteen years, Bere’sheet Ballet has been successful in helping individuals through temporary crisis.We havepaid co-pays, or helped pay for medical exams and tests. We have bought several prostheses for breast cancer survivors. We’ve purchased groceries and gasoline, paid rent, electric bills and even made a few car payments. We have bought medication, found therapists who would volunteer their time, and paid for books for beginning college students-many adults reclaiming their lives and starting over. In these small ways we are often able to stop what could become a financial hemorrhage, and help change the future of an individual in a positive way.

Your generosity, no matter how great of how small can help us change the world.

If you cannot give financially...please pass this along to a friend...and spread the word!

Thank you, with many blessings to you.

Marie Plauche'-Gustin, Artistic Director, Bere'sheet Ballet

story:
Our 'Herstory'

In 1983, Paula Franklin, a black woman at Brown, felt the need for more student choreography on campus. That year, she choreographed a piece for the annual Fall Dance Concert, called "Portrait of a Studio." This piece was the precursor to Fusion Dance Company. In the spring semester of the same academic year,  auditions were held to form a diverse company of 23 students. Over the past 32 years, Fusion has tried to uphold this tradition as a multi-cultural, multi-ethnic group of both men and women who perform a variety of styles and do not conform to modern day constraints on body shape, size, dance style or choreography.

What We Do 

Every year, Fusion Dance Company works tirelessly to produce our Annual Spring Show. We give every company member the opportunity to choreograph a piece in any style he or she wishes. The final product is an inspiring, entertaining, and eclectic collection of dances that never fails to move audience members, regardless of their previous background or experience. In addition to our Spring Show, we perform several times throughout the year for fundraisers and charity events and regularly organize workshops open to the entire student body. Every dancer holds a unique leadership position within the company, enabling members to contribute managerially as well as artistically. 

To watch previous performances, check out our Youtube page!

https://www.youtube.com/user/fusiondancebrown

What We Need

Putting on the best show possible isn't free! Certain expenses like renting light/sound equipment and providing housing and food for our dancers during our winter dance camp are covered by ticket sales. Other things we need to raise money to afford:

Costumes: Costumes significantly enhance the overall experience of a dance performance. Fusion choreographers create pieces with specific visual and artistic intentions in mind; costumes play a very important role in this process. But far too often, Fusion has to fall back on borrowing clothing and pulling together improvised costumes. With your help, Fusion will be able to provide costumes for all choreographers. Contributing around $100 will buy costumes for one piece!

Photographer: Every year we hire a photographer to take our promo photos and document our show. Contributing to this campaign will allow Fusion to get the most talented photographer we can!

Videographer: We also create a promo video to advertise our show. Watch past promo videos from 2014, 2013, and 2012! Contributing will help us make the best promo video yet! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute but still want to help out, please let others know about our campaign by telling your friends and sharing it on social media! And like us on Facebook!
story_txt:
Our 'Herstory'

In 1983, Paula Franklin, a black woman at Brown, felt the need for more student choreography on campus. That year, she choreographed a piece for the annual Fall Dance Concert, called "Portrait of a Studio." This piece was the precursor to Fusion Dance Company. In the spring semester of the same academic year,  auditions were held to form a diverse company of 23 students. Over the past 32 years, Fusion has tried to uphold this tradition as a multi-cultural, multi-ethnic group of both men and women who perform a variety of styles and do not conform to modern day constraints on body shape, size, dance style or choreography.
   
What We Do 
Every year, Fusion Dance Company works tirelessly to produce our Annual Spring Show. We give every company member the opportunity to choreograph a piece in any style he or she wishes. The final product is an inspiring, entertaining, and eclectic collection of dances that never fails to move audience members, regardless of their previous background or experience. In addition to our Spring Show, we perform several times throughout the year for fundraisers and charity events and regularly organize workshops open to the entire student body. Every dancer holds a unique leadership position within the company, enabling members to contribute managerially as well as artistically. 
To watch previous performances, check out our Youtube page!
https://www.youtube.com/user/fusiondancebrown   
What We NeedPutting on the best show possible isn't free! Certain expenses like renting light/sound equipment and providing housing and food for our dancers during our winter dance camp are covered by ticket sales. Other things we need to raise money to afford:Costumes: Costumes significantly enhance the overall experience of a dance performance. Fusion choreographers create pieces with specific visual and artistic intentions in mind; costumes play a very important role in this process. But far too often, Fusion has to fall back on borrowing clothing and pulling together improvised costumes. With your help, Fusion will be able to provide costumes for all choreographers. Contributing around $100 will buy costumes for one piece!Photographer: Every year we hire a photographer to take our promo photos and document our show. Contributing to this campaign will allow Fusion to get the most talented photographer we can!Videographer: We also create a promo video to advertise our show. Watch past promo videos from 2014, 2013, and 2012! Contributing will help us make the best promo video yet! Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't contribute but still want to help out, please let others know about our campaign by telling your friends and sharing it on social media! And like us on Facebook!

story:
The ARC is a destination . . . a direction . . .  and a new community moving forward together!

The American Rhythm Center is building a new dance community that looks like, sounds like and moves like Chicago. Celebrating our 3rd anniversary, the ARC is a unique, shared, dance/arts space that is home to more than 25 small and mid-sized companies as well as emerging and independent artists. The ARC provides high quality, affordable space that enables diverse dance artists to teach, rehearse, and create new invigorating work.

We teach, we rehearse, we create and we perform in the ARC. Perhaps most importantly, we dance together . . . we dance to celebrate our common passion for rhythm and movement  . . . we dance to educate a new generation . . . we dance to improve the lives of people of all ages  . . . and we're building a space where everyone is welcome and everyone's traditions are respected.

Our language is rhythm; please help us keep the dialogue going. Help us bring people together through celebration, movement, and rhythm. The current condition of the studio flooring needs some assistance and we are striving to improve this feature. Through your generosity, you will help us keep the American Rhythm Center studios in a safe and clean state. We want you to have a stake in the future. Let’s keep the ARC thriving.

Your support will enable us to carry on, expand and keep the American Rhythm Center open and running . . . providing excellent classes, affordable rehearsal space and an authentically diverse community center for the most vibrant group of dancers anywhere in Chicago. Assist us in keeping the ARC a place for people of all ages to dance and call home. Your donation will help us repair, sustain, and maintain the dance floors for the present and into the future. At the ARC, we dance not only with our feet but with our heart, please step up and donate.

Please consider making a gift of any size to keep the beat alive! Thank you for your consideration and wishes for a prosperous New Year from everyone at the American Rhythm Center!

story:
The New 'F' Word

What it means to be a feminist has been in the news a lot these last few years. Don't Talk to Me Like I'm Your Wife is my newest SummerWorks play that looks back at Mata Hari, infamous femme fatale, exotic dancer, and alleged spy, on her last 12 hours before being executed by firing squad on October 15, 1917. Would a woman like Mata Hari be considered a feminist in 2016? She was unapologetically sexual at a time when one was instructed to just lay back and think of England. This play speaks to the complicated ideals men and women had and have about identity, sexuality, gender and race while disrupting a common narrative about who truly has the power.

  • I am a playwright who focuses on writing plays giving voice to the marginalized and invisible. I have been fortunate enough to have a platform for those characters with my last 2 productions, Eating Pomegranates Naked and Better Angels: A  Parable.
  • People in the theatre would work for free if the project moved them enough. It is my goal to pay everyone a comparable living wage to work on my show because their exceptional skills should be compensated.
  • I will be fundraising to raise enough to pay my 10 person team (4 actors, 5 crew, and me) cover insurance, rent rehearsal space, and market the play. With your help (financial or otherwise) I can bridge the gap between what I raise and the shortfall.

Okay People, Let's Get into Formation

Call Me Scotty Productions needs $23,000 to cover all the expenses. I have applied for several grants, will fundraise, and sell ads in the theatre program to raise the money. What I need from you is enough to cover the set and costumes as some of the play is set during WW 1 in Paris, France.  My costume designer is great but if she doesn't have to sew a French guard uniform and nun's habit from scratch that would be great. Support this production and you'll get:

  • coffee/tea date with me
  • a handwritten letter in the mail
  • help with your OAC grant
  • Homemade cookies
  • Curry chicken made by me
  • to be my date at TIFF
  • to be intellectually stimulated with me at HotDocs

Diversity is not a trending topic

  • I am a producer and a playwright who has been given the opportunity to tell stories that people want to hear. It is my wish to continue to ascend the theatre establishment ladder in order to normalize diversity in positions of power. I should not be considered the exception but the pool of black female producer/playwrights is tiny and I want my contributions to inspire more young women to seize the reins. 
  • This is my 3rd Indiegogo campaign; prior campaigns were for Eating Pomegranates Naked (RBC Arts Professional award), Swings & Roundabouts and Better Angels: A Parable (SummerWorks Award for Best Production). The support I received allowed my productions to reach a greater number of theatre-goers.
  • Had my previous supporters not trusted that I could fulfill what I promised Better Angels: A Parable would not have had its US debut at the Idle Muse Theatre Company in Chicago or made into a downloadable podcast on iTunes (playmepodcast.com) by Expect Theatre http://expect.org/.

Sponsorship & Support

Call Me Scotty Productions' tagline is 'small tings, BIG IDEAS' and that embodies who I am as a creator and businesswoman.  I like supporting small businesses that want to help the arts community and in the past I have been sponsored by Obsidian Theatre Company, Chapman's Ice Cream, Kerr's Candy, the Dairy Farmers of Canada, Annex location of Cobs and 23 Degrees Roastery. For this production I have secured sponsorships from:

  • Romni Wools http://www.romniwools.com/
  • 23 Degrees Roastery http://23degreesroastery.com/
  • No. 7 Hot Sauce http://no7hotsauce.com/
and there's more to come!

Other Ways You Can Help

Come to one of the shows running at SummerWorks from August 4-14, 2016! But if you just can't make it then:

  • Tell people about the campaign and the show.
  • Re-post and tweet about me and the work I do.
  • Support women in the arts no matter what they're doing because it's hard work and they are warriors for getting out there every single day.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
What We Do

We are Cambridge Theatre Company and we put together fully staged musicals, complete with orchestra, choreography and costumes in just over 3 months. The cast of Spamalot started rehearsals on Sunday 10 April and will continue  rehearsals until we open on Wednesday 29 June.

We hold open auditions, casting a mix of professional actors and talented amateurs. Past cast members have included nurses, lawyers, accountants and firemen! We allow people to gain experience, realize their dreams and discover what they are capable of when they pull together.

Our next show will be Monty Python’s Spmalot at the ADC Theatre in Cambridge from Wednesday 29 June – Saturday 9 July 2016. It promises to be a sensational evening of song, dance and showbiz glitz! And we need your help to make it happen...

What We Need & What You Get

Everyone involved in the production works for free, but we still have to pay for set and costumes, rehearsal space, insurance, marketing, performing rights, etc, which comes to a total of approx. £17,000. If we can raise £2,500 here on Indiegogo, that would be enough to cover deposits and other up-front costs for this. 

And that's where you come in . . .

We have a whole host of fabulous perks available in return for your support, including pre-sale Gala Evening tickets (so you can grab the best seats in the house! See instructions to book multiple tickets below*), programmes, t-shirts, posters and a chance to experience the pre-show adrenalin at our dress rehearsal and, if you've ever dreamed of appearing on the stage yourself, this is your chance with a strictly limited number of walk-on parts up for grabs!

Risks & Challenges

We're all about risk and challenge! It's at the very heart of what we do! But that's what makes it so darned exciting! We know we can do it because we've done it before. We're experienced, committed, confident and determined to make this the BEST show ever!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to contribute, it would be amazing if you could help us spread the word! Check us out on Facebook and Twitter and share our posts with your friends and followers. Keep your eye on our Facebook page  for show updates.

Thanks for your support!

story:
Kitty Loves Theater MadCap!


Our First Promo Trailer for True West by Sam Shepard


Robert Fields Loves Theater MadCap!



The Winner of “Staged” 2014 is Robin Lynn Rodriguez!

Congratulations to Robin Lynn Rodriguez﻿, the winner of "STAGED" 2014! Her prize, a fully produced, three week run of "Hedge" at Inner Mission SF in February of 2015. Thank you to all of the amazing playwrights, actors, and directors that contributed to this series. I love you all and can't wait to do this again next year! Stay tuned for more details on the production of "Hedge" and if you like what we're doing at Theater MadCap please consider donating to our Indiegogo Campaign. Your donation will help bring this amazing piece of work to life and keep "STAGED" free for the community.

It's Pepa!



Kevin don't play that...



Mr. Dreamy, Bennett Fisher, loves Theater MadCap too!


Jennifer Lynne Roberts Love Theater MadCap

Piano Fight loves Theater MadCap!

WHO WE ARE
We are Theater Madcap, a San Francisco-based theater company dedicated to our motto of "Deliberately Diverse Theater".  Our focus is on creating new and challenging theater productions that explore the themes of ethnic, sexual, and cultural diversity.

HISTORY
Founded in 2012 by Eric and Annie Reid, Theater MadCap, a minority owned theater company, got off to an exciting start in February of 2013. We co-produced our first show, "Sex Bombe Kabaret" a nouveau Wiemar Berlin cabaret experience which opened at The Night Light in Oakland.  Then it was off to Burning Man for a full length theatrical production of, "Sex Bombe Kabaret" on the Dustfish Stage, which drew a crowd of hundreds for an amazing night of musical theater right on the Esplanade.

WHAT'S NEXT

Theater MadCap is now ready for its next big thing.  What if I told you that Theater MadCap will host an annual staged reading/play development series designed to find unproduced plays by local playwrights that challenge and inspire us to explore cultural, sexual, and ethnic diversity?  What if I also told you that we would select 10 plays from 10 different playwrights and it would run for 10 consecutive weeks, giving exposure to those playwrights and creating opportunity for multi-ethnic actors and directors of the San Francisco Theater community.  That would be pretty exciting, huh?

Well, we're doing exactly that with "STAGED" plus a whole lot more.  "STAGED" began on July 1st, 2014 and runs through September 2nd at Inner Mission SF.  At the end of the "STAGED" series, Theater MadCap will select one of the plays in the series and give it the full treatment; a 3 week, 10 show run to be produced in February of 2015.  There are many models out there for building a successful theater company and Theater MadCap is taking the "give first" approach to theater.  That's why we're offering the "STAGED" series for FREE.  It's our way of saying thank you in advance for supporting local theater and Theater MadCap's future projects.

That's not all.  We have just begun production of our first full length play.  We are excited to announce that we have secured the rights to, "True West" by Sam Shepard to open at Inner Mission SF in November of 2014.  Our production directed by, Robin Fontaine and featuring, Eric Reid as "Lee", Gabriel Montoya as "Austin", Diana Brown as the Mother and, Steven Cloyes as Saul Kimmer, will look at the classic tale of sibling rivalry with one simple but significant shift; as seen through the eyes of two brown men. Not only does this play challenge us to explore our human similarities within the major themes of sibling rivalry, unfulfilled childhood need, abuse, parental abandonment, mental illness and addiction, but gives us a chance to experience these characters circumstances in a new light. 

Run Dates: November 7th - 23rd.  Friday - Saturday  at 8pm, Sunday at 7pm.

WE NEED YOUR HELP!
Our goal of $10,000 will help us finalize the budget for, "True West" as well as fund the production of the winner of "STAGED".  We have locked down our production team, venue, and rehearsal space.  We will call upon our performance community, family, and friends to help with procuring props, costumes, and building sets.  All we lack are the means to pay for lighting and stage rental, major props that we can't obtain through our normal rummaging routine, and a killer marketing campaign for two productions. $10,000 will cover all of these expenses for both productions plus help keep "STAGED" a free offering for the community.

Thank you for supporting Theater MadCap!  We'll see you at the theater!

story:
What is Flashmob?  

A flash mob is a group of strangers who organize themselves, using electronic media such as cell phones or the internet, to gather together in a public place, behave in a predetermined manner for a predetermined amount of time, and then quickly disperse.

  • This time we arrange with a group of flamenco students. We worked together the dance of flashmob. 


  • I am an Industrial designer. I quit the job because I fall in love with flamenco. I have attended many dance classes in Turkey and Spain. I am teaching flamenco in my country and dancing flamenco. 3 years ago I  established an association about culture of Andalucia and Flamenco to make this culture known more in my country. I am trying to organize workshops and flamenco shows with artists from Spain. Also I am preparing the first flamenco magazine in Turkey (For more information you can check my web site Melis Cangüler )

  • The art of Flamenco , due to the philosophy that enables the creation of this art is liberating the people, strengthening, an art that teaches struggle. With my own experience, especially helps women to get their independency and power. You will have a courage to achieve many things you could not try before. 
  • Not only you learn to dance or improve yourself about music but also you start to learn  people, language, eating and drinking habits, history of another culture that improves you a lot.

If you help us to achieve our project, you will also will help  women to get their power and independency with art, with dance, with a powerful culture.  



We have performed this flashmob choreography of Pastora Galvan with my students on the stage in our school show in 29 May 2015


I also organized a workshop with University to teach this flashmob 


What We Need & What You Get

We need your support! Flamenco is very important for women to get their independency and power. I believe that Turkish women needs this so much. If you support us we can have more motivation to organize more flamenco projects for our country and also we can make flamenco known more. 

If flamenco is known more we  would  have a chance to open the doors to the other flamenco artists in our country. Also more Turkish dancer can improve themselves in Turkey. We give our heart to flamenco for long years.  So what we are missing is mostly financial support.


We need your help with the following costs:

Cost of " Video clip of flashmob": 1750 USD

Accommodation costs of the dancer and her asistant for 5 days : 1250 USD




I organized a workshop in Cervantes -İstanbul to teach this flashmob


What you get

To show how grateful we are for your support, we have some gifts for you! 

For example, a thank you video and certificate specially made for you, your name mentioned as our sponsor on our youtube video, photo signed by Pastora Galvan etc,   free tickets to our flamenco concerts. Take this opportunity to show your support and get something memorable in return.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also support us through social media by following, sharing, liking and leaving comments. Here are our accounts:

facebook.com/AzulDernek

facebook.com/azulmavidergi

instagram.com/azulflamenko

instagram.com/revista_azulmavi

twitter.com/azuldernek

We are grateful for all kinds of help from you.


Who is Pastora Galvan ?

I am an Industrial designer. I quit the job because I fall in love with flamenco. I have attended many dance classes in Turkey and Spain. I am teaching flamenco in my country and dancing flamenco. 3 years ago I  established an association about culture of Andalucia and Flamenco to make this culture known more in my country. I am trying to organize workshops and flamenco shows with artists from Spain. Also I am preparing the first flamenco magazine in Turkey (For more information you can check my web site Melis Cangüler )


The art of Flamenco , due to the philosophy that enables the creation of this art is liberating the people, strengthening, an art that teaches struggle. With my own experience, especially helps women to get their independency and power. You will have a courage to achieve many things you could not try before. 
Not only you learn to dance or improve yourself about music but also you start to learn  people, language, eating and drinking habits, history of another culture that improves you a lot.


If you help us to achieve our project, you will also will help  women to get their power and independency with art, with dance, with a powerful culture.  
  

We have performed this flashmob choreography of Pastora Galvan with my students on the stage in our school show in 29 May 2015

I also organized a workshop with University to teach this flashmob 




   What We Need & What You Get
We need your support! Flamenco is very important for women to get their independency and power. I believe that Turkish women needs this so much. If you support us we can have more motivation to organize more flamenco projects for our country and also we can make flamenco known more. 
If flamenco is known more we  would  have a chance to open the doors to the other flamenco artists in our country. Also more Turkish dancer can improve themselves in Turkey. We give our heart to flamenco for long years.  So what we are missing is mostly financial support.

We need your help with the following costs:
Cost of " Video clip of flashmob": 1750 USD
Accommodation costs of the dancer and her asistant for 5 days : 1250 USD



I organized a workshop in Cervantes -İstanbul to teach this flashmob



   
What you get



To show how grateful we are for your support, we have some gifts for you! 
For example, a thank you video and certificate specially made for you, your name mentioned as our sponsor on our youtube video, photo signed by Pastora Galvan etc,   free tickets to our flamenco concerts. Take this opportunity to show your support and get something memorable in return.   Other Ways You Can Help 
You can also support us through social media by following, sharing, liking and leaving comments. Here are our accounts:facebook.com/AzulDernekfacebook.com/azulmavidergiinstagram.com/azulflamenkoinstagram.com/revista_azulmavitwitter.com/azuldernekWe are grateful for all kinds of help from you.Who is Pastora Galvan ?

story:
amor est. love is.

A performance based on the love correspondence of Marina Tsvetaeva “Letters to Helicon”. The premiere is scheduled on the 5th of December, in PLAYGROUND Theatre, Athens.

amor est. αγάπη είναι.

Μια θεατρική παράσταση βασισμένη στην ερωτική επιστολογραφία της Μαρίνας Τσβετάγιεβα "Γράμματα στον Ελικώνα". Η πρεμιέρα της έχει προγραμματιστεί για τις 5 Δεκεμβρίου 2014, στην Αθήνα, στο θέατρο PLAYGROUND.

Α few words on the performance

“I do not even know: Are you in my life? In the depths of my soul – you are not. But right there, in the banks of my soul, in that defined between: earth and sky, soul and body, dog and wolf, before the sleep, after the dream, there where Me is not Me anymore, and my dog is no longer mine, there, you do not only exist, but you solely exist.” (Marina Tsvetaeva)

The performance is a journey encountering love. A dive into the depths of the human soul, which never stopped seeking it. Love is a state of being and a primary need. The archetype of female and male exists in our cells beyond our gender and sexual identity. Beyond our personal story, there is a common place for all of us in love and that is our body and our soul. Body is more identified with personality, the soul with our being. Are those two separate? And this deeper existential human need for union and perfection? With whom do we want to become one? The face is just a start. Who is the other? Is he/she away from us or does he/she reside somewhere within us? We, lovers, crave, ask for exclusivity, duration, confidence, freedom. From whom do we ask of it? How much do we give ourselves, those things we seek from each other? In the performance, the actors sometimes are the narrators and sometimes serve the two main voices of the performance, the masculine and the feminine. They are the ones in Love. Those who want to Love and Be Loved.

Λίγα λόγια για την παράσταση

“Ούτε καν ξέρω: Είστε στη ζωή μου; Στις εκτάσεις της ψυχής μου - όχι. Αλλά εκεί, στις όχθες της ψυχής, σε αυτό το ορισμένο ανάμεσα σε: γη και ουρανό, ψυχή και σώμα, σκύλο και λύκο, πριν τον ύπνο, μετά το όνειρο, εκεί όπου εγώ δεν είμαι πια εγώ, κι ο σκύλος μου δεν είναι πια δικός μου, εκεί όχι μόνο είστε, αλλά είστε μόνο εσείς."  (Μαρίνα Τσβετάγιεβα)

Η παράσταση είναι ένα ταξίδι συνάντησης με τον έρωτα. Μία κατάδυση στα βάθη της ανθρώπινης ψυχής που δεν έπαψε ποτέ να τον αναζητάει. Ο έρωτας είναι κατάσταση της ύπαρξης και πρωταρχική της ανάγκη. Το αρχέτυπο του θηλυκού και του αρσενικού υπάρχει στα κύτταρά μας πέρα από το φύλο και τη σεξουαλική μας ταυτότητα. Πέρα από την προσωπική μας ιστορία, υπάρχει ένας κοινός τόπος για όλους μας στον έρωτα και αυτός είναι το σώμα μας και η ψυχή μας. Το σώμα περισσότερο ταυτισμένο με την προσωπικότητα, η ψυχή με την ύπαρξη. Είναι ξέχωρα αυτά τα δύο; Και αυτή η βαθύτερη υπαρξιακή ανάγκη του ανθρώπου για ένωση και τελείωση; Με ποιόν θέλουμε να ενωθούμε; Ποιός είναι ο άλλος; Είναι έξω από εμάς ή κατοικεί κάπου μέσα μας; Οι ερωτευμένοι ποθούμε, ζητάμε αποκλειστικότητα, διάρκεια, εμπιστοσύνη, ελευθερία. Από ποιον τα ζητάμε; Πόσο δίνουμε στον εαυτό μας όλα αυτά που αναζητάμε από τον άλλο; Στην παράσταση οι ηθοποιοί άλλοτε είναι αφηγητές και άλλοτε υπηρετούν τις δύο κύριες φωνές του έργου, την αρσενική και τη θηλυκή. Είναι οι Ερωτευμένοι. Aυτοί που θέλουν να Αγαπήσουν και να Αγαπηθούν.

The idea

"All from the soul, and all in the soul." (Marina Tsvetaeva)

The idea for this performance was born from the correspondence of three great poets: Rainer Maria Rilke, Marina Tsvetaeva and Boris Pasternak. A portrait-correspondence of the sacred delirium for poetry, that only exudes love. After a deep study of the work of the three poets, we selected the text that would become the vehicle for the rehearsals and finally the performance itself. This text is a love correspondence by Marina Tsvetaeva and its greek translation was brought to life as "Letters to Helicon" by Dimitra Kondylaki. It was a gift, that this wonderful translation, would pave the way for the poetry to be brought on stage with immediacy and in theater terms. The love correspondence of the "soul" (which is the only place that deeply moves the poet), became for us a story behind all love stories. Guided by her own folly feelings, our own personal stories and confessions were born.

Η ιδέα

"Όλα από την ψυχή, κι όλα μες την ψυχή." (Μαρίνα Τσβετάγιεβα)

Η ιδέα για αυτή την παράσταση γεννήθηκε μέσα από την αλληλογραφία τριών σπουδαίων ποιητών: του Ράινερ Μαρία Ρίλκε, της Μαρίνας Τσβετάγιεβα και του Μπόρις Πάστερνακ. Μια αλληλογραφία-πορτρέτο του ιερού παραληρήματος για την ποίηση που μόνο έρωτα αποπνέει. Μετά από βαθιά μελέτη του έργου των τριών ποιητών, έγινε η επιλογή του κειμένου που θα γινόταν το όχημα για την πρόβα και τελικά την ίδια την παράσταση. Το κείμενο αυτό είναι μια ερωτική επιστολογραφία της Μαρίνας Τσβεταγιεβα, με τίτλο της ελληνικής μετάφρασης "Γράμματα στον Ελικώνα", από την Δήμητρα Κονδυλάκη. Ηταν δώρο που η υπέροχη αυτή μετάφραση, άνοιξε το δρόμο για την μεταφορά της ποίησης επί σκηνής με αμεσότητα και όρους θεάτρου. Η ερωτική επιστολογραφία της “ψυχής”(που είναι και ο μόνος τόπος που συγκινεί την ποιήτρια), έγινε για μας η μία ιστορία πίσω από όλες τις ερωτικές ιστορίες. Με οδηγό τα δικά της παράφορα συναισθήματα γεννήθηκαν οι δικές μας προσωπικές ομολογίες και αφηγήσεις.

What we want to share with the audience

“Our alienation of anything spiritual, can only give birth to monsters.” (Andrei Tarkovsky)

We people, vibrate in contrasts. Within us, the light is inseparably connected to shadow, flying to the fall, love to fear. In love, everything is two and all tend to become one. Love is the bridge that connects. It contains all the energy of creation and destruction. In love, we are called to take risks and live, to trust. How much prepared are we to see that the other person is our reflection? How much do we stand to take responsibility of ourselves in a relationship? In our own lives? Who we are truly?

Τί θέλουμε να μοιραστούμε με το κοινό

"H αποξένωση μας από καθετί πνευματικό, μόνο τέρατα μπορεί να γεννήσει." (Αντρέι Ταρκόφσκι)

Οι άνθρωποι δονούμαστε στις αντιθέσεις. Μέσα μας, το φως είναι άρρηκτα συνδεδεμένο με τη σκιά, το πέταγμα με την πτώση, η αγάπη με τον φόβο. Στον έρωτα όλα είναι δύο και όλα τείνουν να γίνουν ένα. Είναι η γέφυρα που ενώνει. Εμπεριέχει μέσα του την ενέργεια της δημιουργίας και της καταστροφής. Στον έρωτα καλούμαστε να ρισκάρουμε να ζήσουμε, να εμπιστευθούμε, να αγαπήσουμε. Πόσο έτοιμοι είμαστε να δούμε ότι ο άλλος είναι ο καθρέφτης μας; Πόσο αντέχουμε να πάρουμε την ευθύνη του εαυτού μας μέσα σε μια σχέση; Μέσα στην ίδια μας τη ζωή; Ποιοι πραγματικά είμαστε;

Why do we ask for your support

This alternative form of financing brings us close to you and closer to our dream! Your financial support at this point of our journey is valuable. It serves the basic costs of the production and implementation of our performance: theater rental, lighting, sets and costumes, publicity, posters and programs.

And if you can’t support us financially, just spread the word!

Thank you for being a support in fulfilling our deep need of serving our work and our lives, through this performance.

Deep gratitude from all the creative team of amor est. love is.

Γιατί ζητάμε τη στήριξή σας

Η εναλλακτική αυτή μορφή χρηματοδότησης μας φέρνει κοντά σας και κοντά στο όνειρο μας! Η οικονομική σας στήριξη σε αυτό το σημείο του ταξιδιού μας είναι πολύτιμη. Υπηρετεί τα βασικά έξοδα παραγωγής και υλοποίησης της παράστασης: ενοικίαση θεάτρου, φωτισμους, σκηνικά και κοστούμια, επικοινωνία και έντυπο υλικό.

Και αν δεν μπορείτε να μας στηρίξετε οικονομικά, απλά διαδώστε το!

Ευχαριστούμε που γίνεστε στήριγμα για την εκπλήρωσης της βαθιάς μας ανάγκης να υπηρετήσουμε την τέχνη μας και τη ζωή μας μέσα από αυτήν την παράσταση.

Ευγνωμοσύνη από όλη την δημιουργική ομάδα του amor est. αγάπη είναι.

The team

Words: Marina Tsvetaeva

Translation: Dimitra Kondylaki

Concept / Direction / Dramaturgy: Despina Sidiropoulou

Performance / Co-creation: Vasiliki Kakosaiou, Stratos  Palaiologos, Konstantinos Repanis, Despina Sidiropoulou, Elli Hatzeipidou

Choreography: Fotis Nikolaou

Vocal Coaching: Chrysanthi Zertopouli

Assistant Director: Stratos Palaiologos

Artwork: Padelis Frantzis

Publicity / Communication: Yorgos Katsonis

Theatre: PLAYGROUND for the Arts

Οι συντελεστές

Κείμενο: Μαρίνα Τσβετάγιεβα 

Μετάφραση: Δήμητρα Κονδυλάκη 

Σύλληψη / Σκηνοθεσία / Δραματουργία: Δέσποινα Σιδηροπούλου 

Ερμηνεία / Συνδημιουργία: Βασιλική Κακοσαίου, Στράτος Παλαιολόγος, Κωνσταντίνος Ρεπάνης, Δέσποινα Σιδηροπούλου, Έλλη Χατζεϊπίδου 

Κίνηση: Φώτης Νικολάου

Μουσική Διδασκαλία: Χρυσάνθη Ζερτοπούλη

Βοηθός Σκηνοθέτη: Στράτος Παλαιολόγος

Artwork: Παντελής Φραντζής 

Προβολή / Επικοινωνία: Γιώργος Κατσώνης 

Θέατρο: PLAYGROUND for the Arts

story:
Did you know that less than 20% of the plays produced or presented in workshops or readings over a ten-year period (2000-2009) were written by women? In Washington D.C. that number is a little higher...27%.

I think we can do better. 

This July, we will take a stab at the statistic by self-producing an original play written by Casey Bauer titled Half Past What?, a female-centric dark-comedy that will be presented as a part of the 2015 Capital Fringe Festival.

Self-producing is a fantastic way for emerging playwrights to get their work seen. However, it's not an easy task to launch an entire production on a couple of recent college-grads' budgets. It takes the support of friends, family, colleagues and theater enthusiasts like you who want new stories to be told! 

If you've landed on this page then you probably know me or one of my teammates and are familiar with work we've done in the past. Let me take a moment to say thank you, from us to you. The fact that you've shown up to our performances, whether it was that really cringe-worthy high school production of Cats or a silent adaptation of The Magic School Bus that you found truly disturbing, you were still there with cheers and smiles when we reunited in the lobby. 

You empower us to do great work and we ask that you help us to launch this production so we may reach and inspire our audiences, new and veteran. 

This production is presented as a part of the 2015 Capital Fringe Festival, a program of the Washington, DC non-profit Capital Fringe.

What We Need 

For this production we have set a fundraising goal of $2,000. These are our projected costs:


The Impact

  • You get to help create new theater! You're giving a voice to emerging artists and in doing so, contribute to the artistic dialogue in Washington, D.C. 
  • This production and one's like it encourage other female writers and artists to put their stories out there
  • By supporting 'Half Past What?' you also support Capital Fringe Festival, a great non-profit that gives new artists the chance to explore theater and performance.

  • Though our team is new to self-producing, we are not new to independent, creative projects. Visit our website to find out more about our cast and crew! 

Risks & Challenges

. Here are some of the hurdles we will have to jump:

  • Profits: With a small house (max 45 seats) and only 4 performances we really want to sell out, as often as possible, every night if we can! We believe in paid actors so after Fringe and our venue get their cuts we would like to pay our talented cast and crew for their hard work
  • Standing Out: With over 100 performances featured all over DC for Fringe Festival, we have to make sure ours is a top pick. With only one weekend of performances we will have a short amount of time to make a great impression.
  • Production Costs: As a group of young, independent theater artists  it's necessary that most of our budget come from fundraising, But If we don't reach our goal the show still must go on. 
  • Time & Talent: Fringe Festival runs July 9-26th. Starting in May that gives us a little over 2 months to rehearse the show, design and acquire all of our production materials, raise our budget, launch a great marketing and social media campaign, and promote, promote, promote! 

How we'll make the jump: 

  • A strong social media & marketing campaign: Fringe Festival is heavily shared and documented through Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. With a presence on all three of these sites where we will share original content from our website blog we plan to keep our fans and followers engaged with our production as well as the entire festival. 
  • Advertising: Our $500 advertising budget will go towards print and online ads with DC publications that heavily cover Fringe.
  • Printed materials: Our production team and cast will act as ambassadors for our project, distributing postcards, posters, and business cards around the DC Metro area.
  • Pre-festival coverage: We will actively pursue opportunities for pre-festival press pieces and exposure to increase audience interest and attendance.
  • Volunteer opportunities: We are offering a volunteer costume designer position for a student design student looking to gain experience in their field. In addition, we will be recruiting other theater enthusiasts to assist during tech week and performances. 
  • A diversified team: To support the management of our project we have brought on Katie Morgan, an experienced project management professional with experience in the political and non-profit fields. Find out more about her background here. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone is able to contribute monetarily but it doesn't mean you can't help in other ways to make our project a success! Here's what you can do:

  • Share the video and this page! Check out the Indiegogo share tools to post to all of your favorite social media pages.
  • Like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter & Instagram.
  • When you come to a performance share a photo on Instagram or mention us in a tweet and be sure to tag Fringe: #Fringefest2015

story:
Cupcake Lady Productions' Inaugural Season


Help Us Create Delicious Theatre! 

Cupcake Lady Productions has already begun - in our offbeat way - to create entertainment that explores relatable emotions and situations, and challenges preconceptions. As we continue to produce smaller live events and multimedia, we would love to get a season of theatre off the ground. We are hoping to kick things off with an unconventional production of Sam Shepard's True West.

And to make it all happen, we need your help...

Where Your Money Goes

To do these shows right, we're seeking funds for the following:

  • A Theatre! We're looking for a full week's rental in a central, well-maintained New York theatre space. Time enough for load-in, tech, and Thurs-Sun performances.
  • Rights - Paying for the permission to do these incredible and copywrighted plays
  • Costume, Sets, Lights and Sound - Good design will help our actors and audience be transported into the world of the play. For True West, sets will likely be the biggest design expense: a realistic approximation of a kitchen!
  • Toasters - Seriously, guys. We need like, fifty toasters. And other props, too.
  • Postcards, posters, etc. - Promotional material! We want to fill those seats so as many people as possible will see the show!
  • And, hopefully, if we have a surplus, we can provide a stipend to a pro Stage Manager (at the least), fund unexpected incidental expenses, and of course, put money into growing the company and putting up the next shows!

Your Motivation

In return, you can get these VERY COOL things (please see "perks" for the full breakdown):

Cupcake Lady Productions Swag - brand-new magnets and even t-shirts!

Complimentary tickets to True West*

A custom video

Our eternal love and gratitude

CUPCAKES

 *If you will be out of town during the performances, please contact us at cupcakeladyproductions@gmail.com

The Impact

This campaign will truly get the ball rolling for Cupcake Lady Productions. Our first few shows will help establish us as a company, and from there we can get on our way to acheiving Not for Profit status, producing more of our brand of entertainment, and reaching more people. Every single dollar makes a world of difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

For those who are unable to help us financially, there are other ways to get involved:

  • Volunteer - we'll always need extra hands, whether it be at the box office the night of the show, or simply passing out our postcards
  • Like us! Cupcake Lady Productions is all over social media. you can like us on Facebook (/cupcakeladyproductions), follow us on Twitter (@CupcakeLadyProd) and subscribe to our YouTube channel (/CupcakeLadyProd).
  • Share - Link this campaign wherever you can: social media, email, word of mouth...everything helps.

story:
We’ve got 30 days to pay our actors and production staff!

The Project

An ALL-FEMALE production of William Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night being performed for FREE in four parks around New York (all performances at 6:00pm):

  • Summit Rock in Central Park - Thurs - Sun May 30 - June 9

  • St Nicholas Park in Harlem - June 13 & 14

  • Prospect Park in Brooklyn - June 21-23 (includes 17 four year olds!! Let the mayhem ensue!)

  • Sunset Park in Brooklyn - June 27-30

 

The Company

Since 2010, Manhattan Shakespeare Project – Manhattan’s All-Female Shakespeare Company has been dedicated to fostering the growth of the female artist and using Shakespeare as an educational tool (like our Prospect Park “Knavish Sprites”!) to empower and reach diverse communities, especially those marginalized as a result of socio-economic status and geographic location.

We’re making the world a better place! Come and help us!


How You Can Help

Your donation goes directly to paying our fabulous cast and crew of 12 women:

(7 actors, 1 director, 1 stage manager, 1 choreographer, 1 publicist, 1 dramaturg) 12 artists x $200 stipend = $2400


Twelfth Night total budget breakdown:
Rehearsal Space Rental (TheatreLab NYC, they are so awesome!) $1,114
Park Permit Application Fees $100
Insurance $175
Costume Rental/Purchase $400
Props Rental/Purchase $350
Artistic Fees for 12 artists $2400
Advertising - Postcards $169.59
T-shirts $500
Emergency Fund $300
TOTAL $5508.59

THANK YOU!!

We thank you so much for your time, consideration, and generosity in helping make this project a reality. Every dollar helps, is greatly appreciated, and gets us one step closer to making Shakespeare physically and financially accessible to everyone...and changing the world.

Spread the Word! And Come See The Shows!!

Even spreading the word about our campaign goes a long way to help. Like us on Facebook. Do the Tweety thing. We've made it easy as pie. (mmm, pie...) You can share right from the Facebook/Twitter buttons below, but here are some pre-made tweets to save you some precious keystrokes!

  • Support @manhattanshakes as they change the world one Shakespeare production at a time! igg.me/at/msp12thnight 

  • Help @manhattanshakes pay the cast and crew of their ALL-FEMALE 12th Night! igg.me/at/msp12thnight 

  • Shakespeare chicks are hot! @manhattanshakes brings ALL-FEMALE 12th Night to a NY park near you! igg.me/at/msp12thnight

And don’t forget to grab your blanket, lawn chair, and favorite cheese and crackers and catch us at a park near you!

For more information about Manhattan Shakespeare Project and this summer’s production of Twelfth Night please visit our website: http://manhattanshakes.org/

 

CAST

  • Sarah Bowles*: Feste, Fabian, Officer, Curio

  • Sarah Eismann: Viola

  • Arielle Harding: Orsino, Malvolio

  • Amy Jo Jackson*: Sir Toby Belch, Priest

  • Leah Reddy: Maria, Sebastian, Valentine

  • Amanda Tudor*: Captain, Sir Andrew Aguecheek

  • Folami Williams: Olivia, Antonio

CREW

  • Director: Reesa Graham

  • Stage Manager: Jacob Halpern Weitzman 

  • Choreographer: Whitney Rowlett-Senn

  • Publicist: Alessandra Alma

  • Dramaturg: Chelsea Phillips



*These Actors are appearing courtesy of Actors’ Equity Association.

Equity Approved Showcase

story:
Rescue the historic Hardacre Theater before its 100th birthday!

1-30-14 UPDATE: WE DID IT! 

The Hardacre Theater Preservation Association has managed to raise $114,000 to save the Hardacre! In addition to Indiegogo funds, donations were sent to the HTPA via check and cash—including two $40,000 donations that made up the bulk of our total. 
ALL funds raised via Indiegogo will go directly toward Phase 2 of our campaign—renovating the theater!
THANK YOU for supporting our cause!
--
In the early 1900s, Jacob Hardacre had a vision. He wanted a community space in Tipton, Iowa, that could be used to celebrate culture and improve the quality of life for its residents. His estate left funds to build a theater, and in 1916, his vision became a reality. The Hardacre Theater opened in downtown Tipton.


The Hardacre Theater is a 375-seat venue that has entertained generations with live and filmed entertainment.

Flash-forward to August 2013. After a 97-year run as a mainstay entertainment venue within the small town—first as an opera house, then as a movie theater—the movie industry's rapid switch from 35mm film to digital projection has left small theaters like the Hardacre in a bind. Unable to obtain the 35mm prints and falling into disrepair, the theater's owners decide to close the Hardacre. A small town is left without a cultural touchstone. 

Welcome to Phase 1 of our efforts to save the Hardacre Theater.

Hardacre history

Construction on the Hardacre Theater started in 1914, and the doors opened in 1916. Jacob Hardacre, its benefactor and a longtime member of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows, stipulated that the building be used for Odd Fellows functions. (The theater is still decorated with an IOOF sign on its exterior.) Three years later, it screened its first silent film and remained a movie theater (while still hosting live theatrical events) until its closing.

A poster announcing upcoming shows at the Hardacre in 1968.

In 1936, the theater received a new "washed-air air-conditioning system," which is still intact within the building. In December 1948, the building underwent a significant renovation that included a new marquee and remodeling of the interior, continuing its Art Deco style. The IOOF sold the building in 1978 to a local family, who remain its current owners. 

In 1996, a local resident with ties to the film industry started the Hardacre Film Festival—Iowa's first film festival and one of the oldest in the Midwest. Held every August, the festival draws independent filmmakers and fans from all over the world to Tipton.

Under new management—hopefully

The Hardacre Theater is located right in the middle of downtown Tipton, Iowa.

When the theater's most recent owner made it clear he was about to retire from the theater business, a group of Tipton residents stepped forward to save the theater from oblivion. In 2012, the Hardacre Theater Preservation Association (HTPA) was formed. In October 2013, the HTPA achieved 501(c)(3) nonprofit status. 

The HTPA's mission is to provide an affordable and enriching moviegoing and theatrical experience for our local and surrounding communities. Its vision is to create a multi-use performance space that enhances the quality of life for those it serves. The goal is to create a community-run venue, enhanced by the soul of the town.

The next step: purchasing the theater. That's what Phase 1 of our fundraising campaign is all about.

Fundraising goals

Phase 1 of the HTPA's fundraising campaign has one goal: purchasing the theater. The assessed value and agreed-upon purchase price is $96,100. An anonymous donor has pledged a $40,000 matched donation, which gets us considerably closer to our fundraising goal. 

 The theater has 375 seats, including the balcony.

The HTPA needs to raise $60,500 (we added $4,400 to cover this campaign's fundraising costs) by January 31, 2014, to purchase the building.Your tax-deductible donation will help us get there! Once this goal is accomplished, Phase 2 (renovating the theater inside and out, and upgrading to a digital projection system) will begin.  

Your role in saving the Hardacre

Tipton, a small town of 3,200 residents, has supported the Hardacre Theater for generations. Through its history as one of the last Midwestern opera houses, it has gained widespread support. As the home of Iowa's first-ever film festival, it has become known all over the world as a base for quality filmed entertainment.

The Hardacre Theater Preservation Association needs the help of the Indiegogo community to bring our vision to life. Through small and large donations, a collective fundraising effort will resurrect a Midwestern Art Deco treasure. We have seen the results of several Indiegogo campaigns help theaters adapt to 21st century technology, and we're confident the Indiegogo community will help us get there.

Risks and challenges

WE'RE DOWN TO THE WIRE. The Hardacre Theater Preservation Association is facing a January 31, 2014, deadline to purchase the theater. It was a long road for the HTPA to attain 501(c)(3) nonprofit status, and our fundraising efforts are facing a very strict deadline.

WE'RE A SMALL COMMUNITY. The Hardacre Theater is a 375-seat venue in a small, rural community of 3,200 residents. Although the community has supported the theater for generations, we need the help of a wider, worldwide community before the multimillion-dollar renovation can happen.

WE'RE RACING TO MEET A MILESTONE. In 2016, the Hardacre Theater will celebrate its 100th birthday. What a great story it will be to have a refreshed, state-of-the-art theater all set to go by the time we reach this milestone.

Tipton, Iowa's motto is "Where Dreams Happen." We're hoping Indiegogo will help this very big community dream come true.

In October 2013, the HTPA achieved 501(c)(3) nonprofit status. The HTPA's mission is to provide an affordable and enriching moviegoing and theatrical experience for our local and surrounding communities. Its vision is to create a multi-use performance space that enhances the quality of life for those it serves. The goal is to create a community-run venue, enhanced by the soul of the town.The next step: purchasing the theater. That's what Phase 1 of our fundraising campaign is all about.Fundraising goalsPhase 1 of the HTPA's fundraising campaign has one goal: purchasing the theater. The assessed value and agreed-upon purchase price is $96,100. An anonymous donor has pledged a $40,000 matched donation, which gets us considerably closer to our fundraising goal.  The theater has 375 seats, including the balcony.The HTPA needs to raise $60,500 (we added $4,400 to cover this campaign's fundraising costs) by January 31, 2014, to purchase the building.Your tax-deductible donation will help us get there! Once this goal is accomplished, Phase 2 (renovating the theater inside and out, and upgrading to a digital projection system) will begin.  Your role in saving the HardacreTipton, a small town of 3,200 residents, has supported the Hardacre Theater for generations. Through its history as one of the last Midwestern opera houses, it has gained widespread support. As the home of Iowa's first-ever film festival, it has become known all over the world as a base for quality filmed entertainment.The Hardacre Theater Preservation Association needs the help of the Indiegogo community to bring our vision to life. Through small and large donations, a collective fundraising effort will resurrect a Midwestern Art Deco treasure. We have seen the results of several Indiegogo campaigns help theaters adapt to 21st century technology, and we're confident the Indiegogo community will help us get there.Risks and challengesWE'RE DOWN TO THE WIRE. The Hardacre Theater Preservation Association is facing a January 31, 2014, deadline to purchase the theater. It was a long road for the HTPA to attain 501(c)(3) nonprofit status, and our fundraising efforts are facing a very strict deadline.WE'RE A SMALL COMMUNITY. The Hardacre Theater is a 375-seat venue in a small, rural community of 3,200 residents. Although the community has supported the theater for generations, we need the help of a wider, worldwide community before the multimillion-dollar renovation can happen.WE'RE RACING TO MEET A MILESTONE. In 2016, the Hardacre Theater will celebrate its 100th birthday. What a great story it will be to have a refreshed, state-of-the-art theater all set to go by the time we reach this milestone.Tipton, Iowa's motto is "Where Dreams Happen." We're hoping Indiegogo will help this very big community dream come true.

story:
The Play

Equal parts black comedy and psychological drama, THE WIFE centers around Ruth, a Hasidic woman who befriends her white neighbors. What seems at first an innocent relationship quickly escalates, and the play spirals into a series of events which unravel an entire community. With wit, humor, and wisdom, Smith’s play exposes the best and worst parts of humanity, kind people turn venomous, and cruel people act with compassion.

After developing THE WIFE with Page 73 Productions and The Lark Play Center, the artistic team put the play on its feet in workshop at IRT Theater, April 2010. Now we are so please to announce it is getting a full production at The Gallery at Access Theater December 2nd - 19th.


Some Background

a note from the playwright...

Over the last decade, neighborhoods like south Williamsburg have experienced the ambient waves of cultural isolationism butting heads with the New Order that is springing up around the city in spurts of condos and Whole Foods. People who have lived in the same four block radius for generations are now seeing their neighborhoods infested with artists, marketing employees, young gentried families and bars/restaurants with themes of rustic simulation (fake English bars, fake sailor bars) that would make Baudrillard weep. Recently the Hasidic neighborhoods of South Williamsburg have organized against what they call "a plague of artists", passing city ordinances blocking other ways of life in their public urban areas.

Through the course of the play, every character shows off a radically different side of their being, based on the (sometimes random) person they are talking to. Kind people turn venomous; cruel people are reduced to acts of compassion. The point is to say that at the core of our humanity is also the need to suppress our best qualities in the face of other people whose appearance is different than ours. I don't really know why people (myself included) do that, but I do hope people think about it as they're leaving the production.


What We Need & What You Get

This is the final $2000 that we need to make THE WIFE a reality. With your support this truly stunning piece of theater can reach it's true potential. Large donations ($500 +) will be thanked with exclusive access to the creative team.

story:
Short Summary

For over a decade, we have been passionately working on a performance piece that would combine the elements of a modern day pop concert with a character-driven, theatrical storyline exploring the psychology of a moment in time. We took our inspiration from the groundbreaking concert stagings of the early 90s, like those of Madonna and Janet Jackson. The song, dance and multimedia elements combined with the social provocations that go hand in hand with these mega dance concerts has always been a point of fascination for us. Add into the mix our love of the theater and nostalgia for the innocence of the 1990s, and The Groove Factory was born: a musical that looks at the last glory days of New York City's mega-dance clubs through the filter of the impending turn of the Millennium accompanied by global Y2K paranoia. We are ecstatic to share that The Groove Factory has been chosen as an official selection of New York Musical Theatre Festival 2012*, a highly competitive platform to showcase original musicals- in other words the "Sundance" of Musical Theater.  

With an official opening night set of July 24th, we ask for your support! 

Your contributions will help make The Groove Factory not only the biggest hit of the festival, but will lay the foundation neccesary for the next step - a commercial run.  Our goal is to mount the professional quality production that will get high powered theater producers and investors attention.  Please help us make this goal a reality.

What We Need & What You Get

To date we have raised approximately 50% of what we need to get into rehearsals and start bulding the sets.  We need to raise the other 50% by mid -June to stay on track.  This is where you come in. Please see our levels to the right and contribute in whatever way you can. Through Fractured Atlas, our fiscal sponsor, donations are tax deductible! If you are able to help with a donation at a level greater than is outlined here (or would prefer to forgo the "perk" and receive full tax deduction) please visit www.fracturedatlas.org/site/contribute/donate/485 or contact Chad Kessler directly at chad@thegroovefactorymusical.com. We would be happy to discuss higher end "perks" or tax deductible opportunities with you personally. 

The Impact

This will be ground breaking for the Musical Theater world, with its all-electronic Dance/Pop score it will be the first of its kind (think about what Rent did for Rock musicals). Produced entirely at BetBoyz studio, several tracks have already developed a cult following and have become dance floor staples in clubs from New York to Singapore.  In addition, Kim Sozzi, one of the true leading ladies of the Billboard Dance Charts, is slated to play the female lead, Melody McPlanet!

Socially, the story will transport an audience to an America right before the War on Terror, economic recessions and iPhones.  For one night, the theater will be filled with the innocence of the decadent 90s, and let's be honest- who couldn't use that sort of escape.  Check your iPhone at the door and grab your beeper!  Better yet, leave it all behind. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can’t contribute financial, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Make some noise, join us on Facebook and help us a build our Groovehead community at www.facebook.com/thegroovefactorymusical.

Use the Indiegogo share tools!  Please send to all your friends and contacts.

See you at the show! Tickets go on sale to the public on June 15th.  Dont miss your opportunity to be among the first to be part of the next great musical theater experience!

*NYMF is a vital launching pad in developing and introducing new musicals to audiences, peers, and leading industry professionals.  Learn more about the festival at www.nymf.org/Page.347.Mission.
