story:
Who We Are

Outcast Theatre Company is a repertory company devoted to the presentation and exploration of live performance to encourage dialogue on social topics, the human condition, and the nature of connection. This mission is achieved through the production of top-quality mainstage productions, augmented by opportunities for social dialogue and interaction.

Valentine is our first official mainstage production and has been a labor of love for both Artistic Directors, Michelle Maccarone and Joshua Robinson for a long time.  Josh has been deeply involved with this case from the time it occured in 2008; it is this event that prompted the writing of Valentine.  

It is an important case because of what it can teach.  This is not a simple case of one child bullied and killed by the other.  These are two children who are in deeply dire situations.  

Even more than the specific case this play hits upon something even more general: In an age where a child's sexuality becomes a natural part of their adolescence, how do we mediate to these children so that situations such as Larry's case do not happen?

Why We Need Your Help

The money you provide for this campaign will go several places:

  • Most money will go to our rental of the 133rd Street Arts Center.  Other funds will go to small stipends for our cast and crew and budgets for costumes, set and lights.
  • We have some great perks for those interested in donating $35 or more.  They range from a beautiful home made valentine signed by the cast to a signed script of Valentine.  Each perk, of course, includes a ticket to come see our production!
  • If we do not reach our goal, the funds raised will go predominately to funding our NYC space for the production.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute, that's ok!  We understand and are thankful for any type of support you can provide!
  • Social media and word of mouth are AWESOME things, please let people know about our project!
  • There are some amazing Indiegogo Share tools, consider using them to get the word out!
Thank you for taking the time to check our project out!  We sincerely hope you are able to donate to what we think will be a really exciting production!

story:
Video directed, filmed, and edited by Tyler Mitchell. Illustration by Simon Winheld. Music provided by The Midnight Hollow. 

Summary

The Cake Shop Theater Company was founded by Katie Lupica and Casey Hayes-Deats to produce new works, forgotten texts, and reimagined classics that give an uncensored voice to characters and creators coming of age - particularly women.

Martin Crimp's new English version of Bruckner's Pains of Youth speaks directly to our mission. Set in 1920s Vienna, Pains of Youth tells the story of medical students coming of age in a post-WWI world they did not intend to inherit. Much like young Americans today, they are struggling to find their way in a socially, economically, and politically changed landscape. (Think Girls meets The Great Gatsby.)

Crimp's version of Bruckner's breakout drama premiered at London's National Theatre in 2009 but has yet to see the New York stage. After a 3-month-long effort to secure the rights to produce the premiere, The Cake Shop is delighted to be sharing not only a phenomenal script but also the story, language, and ideas unique to two extraordinary non-American writers rarely produced in the US.  This production is an opportunity to bring a terrific play to the right audience at the right time, and an opportunity to professionally showcase a talented group of emerging artists and theater-makers consisting of 1 director, 7 actors, 1 dramaturge,  1 stage manager, 4 designers,  4 creative producers, and others.

With your help we will be able to make our production the very best that it can be. Your contribution will make a significant difference in the careers of emerging artists as well as significantly contribute to the vitality of the New York theater-scene.

What We Need

It costs a lot of money to independently produce a play. Here is a glimpse at some of our expenses: $6,090 - Venue Rental; $1,525 - Design Materials; $3,000 - Rehearsal Space Rental; $4,000 - Artist Salaries; $1,200 - Programs and Marketing Materials. 

We are committed to opening Pains of Youth on February 15th, and we guarantee that every dollar raised from this campaign will go towards our production. The show will go on, but with the funds from this campaign we will be able to compensate all artists for their countless hours of work; we will be able to grant our set and costume designers full creative freedom; and we will be able to fully market the show and attract professional critics. By joining our campaign you will be part of taking our production from bare bones to the professional level we are aiming for.

If we meet our fundraising goal, we will be able to fully execute our plans for this production. If we do not meet our goal, we will move ahead while making necessary sacrifices.

What You Get

In addition to the perks listed to the right, we also invite you to join our community. We will offer you many opportunities to meet our team and celebrate what we are able to create together. 

This is an opportunity to support a talented and ambitious group dedicated to bringing high-quality, relevant, and innovative theater to life. We have the skills to produce a wonderfully vital production, and you will have the satisfaction of knowing that you played a critical role in this project's success. 

*Please note that the Special Opening Night Performance will be Saturday, February 15th at 8pm.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate at this time, you can help us in the following ways:

  • Share our  campaign and encourage your friends to donate. 
  • Like The Cake Shop Theater Company on Facebook and invite your friends.
  • Come see our show in February. And, of course, bring your friends. 

Thank You From the Bottom of our Hearts!

story:
The O.C.: The Musical is making its world premiere at the Vancouver Fringe Festival this September and we need your help to make it happen! Written by the creators of Riverview High, winner of the 2012 Pick of the Fringe in Vancouver, The O.C.: The Musical parodies the popular TV teen drama series, The O.C., in an over-the-top, unauthorized retelling of the Primetime hit.

The Synopsis

Like the TV show it parodies, The O.C.: The Musical follows the bad boy with a heart of gold, Ryan Atwood, as he faces the trials and tribulations of growing up, falling in love and learning to live in the cut-throat, over-privileged world of Orange County (O.C.).

Growing up on the wrong side the tracks surrounded by alcoholic parents and car-stealing thugs lands Ryan in juvie after a split moment’s decision to cover for his brother turns sour. Luckily for Ryan, his Public Defender, Sandy Cohen, sees the good in him and brings him to live with his family in Newport, Orange County. Soon after arriving in the O.C., Ryan develops a lasting bromance with Sandy’s son Seth Cohen, becomes enamoured with girl-next-door Marissa Cooper, gets in a fight with the popular water polo jocks at school, and becomes the target of sexy widower Julie Cooper’s vengeful hatred as she tries to stamp out threats to her privileged life in the O.C. As tensions rise to an action-packed climax, the characters learn how to express their teenage angst, accept each other’s differences, and get away with murder(?). The O.C. The Musical is a coming of age story like you’ve never seen it before.

The O.C.: The Musical History

Few could have predicated the popularity and cultural influence the hit primetime drama, The O.C., would achieve when it premiered on FOX in 2004. In just 4 seasons, The O.C. developed a large, cult-like following that still re-watch and talk about the show to this day.

Stewart Yu and Angela Wong began writing the unauthorized musical parody of The O.C. in April 2014 after discussions for their mutual love of the show developed into a reflection on how ridiculous the Primetime teen soap opera actually was. The O.C. seemed made to be parodied. As they began to layout the story, think of songs to develop characters and workshop their ideas with friends, The O.C.: The Musical quickly formed into the 90-minute musical that was later accepted by the Vancouver Fringe Festival as a 2015 BYOV artist.

With your help, The O.C.: The Musical will make its world premiere on September 11th at 10:15 pm at the Firehall Arts Centre in the Vancouver Fringe Festival!

What We Need & What You Get

We need $2,000 to help us get this show off the ground. It takes a lot of money to produce a big-budget show on a Fringe budget, and so we're asking for your help to make our dream become a reality. 

Your donation helps us to:

  • Build sets;
  • Buy costumes;
  • Develop a full, original orchestration of the score;
  • Pay for rehearsal space;
  • Pay for our bring-your-own venue; and
  • Print lots of posters, postcards, etc. to help us market the show.

We have come up with some amazing perks for you, our wonderful donors, friends and supporters, including tickets to the show, autographed merchandise, and of course, the album itself!! 

The Impact

In the high-stakes world of pop culture parody musicals, every little bit helps and there is no donation too small. Everything that is donated to this campaign will be lovingly used to realize our dream of having this show come to life. We feel like it is our duty to our generation to make this original musical a reality, and need your help to make it happen. As the ancient proverb goes: It takes a whole online community to develop an original musical!

There have been TONS of Fringe musicals to go onto bigger and better things (The Drowsy Chaperone, Evil Dead, etc...) and who knows what will happen with our little show? First, Vancouver, next THE WORLD!

Who we are

Stewart Yu – Writer (Music and Lyrics)/Music Director: Stewart made his composer/lyricist debut with Riverview High: The Musical.  He has since worked on Indie hit film Shooting the Musical and is excited to be back working on his second stage musical. He earned his ARCT diploma in Piano Performance in 2000 and has since gone on to study conducting at UBC and voice with Spencer Welch. He previously music directed [title of show] (Ovation Award nominee for Outstanding Music Direction) and Aladdin, and conducted A New Brain. You may have seen him onstage in Shrek, RENT and bare: a pop opera. Stewart is also a front-end engineer at Mobify and holds a B.Sc in Computer Science from UBC.

Dawn Ewen – Director/Choreographer: Since moving to Vancouver Dawn has worked with numerous theatre companies as a performer, choreographer and director. Select credits: Fiddler on the Roof & The Sound of Music – Gateway Theatre, Fosse, Fosse, Fosse - NY Jazz Co, The Wiz  – FCP (CTC Award), Anything Goes -  Metro Theatre (CTC Award & Ovation Nominee) and 42nd Street  - Metro Theatre (Ovation Award). Dawn trained at the Canadian School of Ballet for 12yrs, is a CCPA graduate, and was fortunate enough to work with Enpoint ENT in Tokyo Japan. She performed with Ballet West in Oban Scotland as a company member and soloist. Dawn was nominated for the Ethel Tibbits Women of Distinction Award in 2010, 2011, 2012 & 2014. She is currently the Artistic Associate at Gateway Theatre.

Angela Wong – Writer (Book and Additional Lyrics): Angela feels incredibly fortunate that she has an amazing writing partner and a wonderful cast and crew, who are all working tirelessly on bringing this show to life. Angela is the co-creator and librettist of Riverview High: The Musical, which premiered at the Vancouver Fringe Festival in 2012 and was voted Pick of the Fringe. She is also an avid photographer specializing in portrait and travel photography. She holds a B.A.(Hon.) in History and a M.A. in Asia Pacific Policy Studies from UBC, and a J.D. from the University of Alberta.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that times are tight, and so if you can't help us financially, there are still ways you can help us reach our goal! 

-  Share this link/project on Facebook, Twitter, email, poster, anything! Every little bit helps. 

-  Come see our show! Tickets available at www.theocmusical.com. 

 See you in September!

Like the TV show it parodies, The O.C.: The Musical follows the bad boy with a heart of gold, Ryan Atwood, as he faces the trials and tribulations of growing up, falling in love and learning to live in the cut-throat, over-privileged world of Orange County (O.C.).
Growing up on the wrong side the tracks surrounded by alcoholic parents and car-stealing thugs lands Ryan in juvie after a split moment’s decision to cover for his brother turns sour. Luckily for Ryan, his Public Defender, Sandy Cohen, sees the good in him and brings him to live with his family in Newport, Orange County. Soon after arriving in the O.C., Ryan develops a lasting bromance with Sandy’s son Seth Cohen, becomes enamoured with girl-next-door Marissa Cooper, gets in a fight with the popular water polo jocks at school, and becomes the target of sexy widower Julie Cooper’s vengeful hatred as she tries to stamp out threats to her privileged life in the O.C. As tensions rise to an action-packed climax, the characters learn how to express their teenage angst, accept each other’s differences, and get away with murder(?). The O.C. The Musical is a coming of age story like you’ve never seen it before.
The O.C.: The Musical History
Few could have predicated the popularity and cultural influence the hit primetime drama, The O.C., would achieve when it premiered on FOX in 2004. In just 4 seasons, The O.C. developed a large, cult-like following that still re-watch and talk about the show to this day.
Stewart Yu and Angela Wong began writing the unauthorized musical parody of The O.C. in April 2014 after discussions for their mutual love of the show developed into a reflection on how ridiculous the Primetime teen soap opera actually was. The O.C. seemed made to be parodied. As they began to layout the story, think of songs to develop characters and workshop their ideas with friends, The O.C.: The Musical quickly formed into the 90-minute musical that was later accepted by the Vancouver Fringe Festival as a 2015 BYOV artist.
With your help, The O.C.: The Musical will make its world premiere on September 11th at 10:15 pm at the Firehall Arts Centre in the Vancouver Fringe Festival!
What We Need & What You Get
We need $2,000 to help us get this show off the ground. It takes a lot of money to produce a big-budget show on a Fringe budget, and so we're asking for your help to make our dream become a reality. 
Your donation helps us to:


Build sets;


Buy costumes;


Develop a full, original orchestration of the score;


Pay for rehearsal space;


Pay for our bring-your-own venue; and


Print lots of posters, postcards, etc. to help us market the show.


We have come up with some amazing perks for you, our wonderful donors, friends and supporters, including tickets to the show, autographed merchandise, and of course, the album itself!! 
The Impact
In the high-stakes world of pop culture parody musicals, every little bit helps and there is no donation too small. Everything that is donated to this campaign will be lovingly used to realize our dream of having this show come to life. We feel like it is our duty to our generation to make this original musical a reality, and need your help to make it happen. As the ancient proverb goes: It takes a whole online community to develop an original musical!
There have been TONS of Fringe musicals to go onto bigger and better things (The Drowsy Chaperone, Evil Dead, etc...) and who knows what will happen with our little show? First, Vancouver, next THE WORLD!
Who we are
Stewart
Yu
– Writer (Music and Lyrics)/Music
Director: Stewart made his composer/lyricist debut with Riverview
High: The Musical.  He has since worked on Indie hit film Shooting the Musical and is excited to
be back working on his second stage musical. He earned his ARCT diploma in
Piano Performance in 2000 and has since gone on to study conducting at UBC and
voice with Spencer Welch. He previously music directed [title of show] (Ovation
Award nominee for Outstanding Music Direction) and Aladdin, and
conducted A New Brain. You may have seen him onstage in Shrek, RENT and bare:
a pop opera. Stewart is also a front-end engineer at Mobify and holds a B.Sc in Computer Science from
UBC.

Dawn Ewen – Director/Choreographer:
Since moving to Vancouver Dawn
has worked with numerous theatre companies as a performer, choreographer and
director. Select credits: Fiddler on the
Roof & The Sound of Music –
Gateway Theatre, Fosse, Fosse, Fosse
- NY Jazz Co, The Wiz  – FCP (CTC Award), Anything Goes -  Metro
Theatre (CTC Award & Ovation Nominee) and 42nd Street  - Metro Theatre
(Ovation Award). Dawn trained at the Canadian School of Ballet for 12yrs, is a
CCPA graduate, and was fortunate enough to work with Enpoint ENT in Tokyo
Japan. She performed with Ballet West in Oban Scotland as a company member and
soloist. Dawn was nominated for the Ethel Tibbits Women of Distinction Award in
2010, 2011, 2012 & 2014. She is currently the Artistic Associate at Gateway
Theatre. 

Angela
Wong – Writer (Book and Additional Lyrics): Angela feels incredibly fortunate
that she has an amazing writing partner and a wonderful cast and crew, who are
all working tirelessly on bringing this show to life. Angela is the co-creator
and librettist of Riverview High: The
Musical, which premiered at the Vancouver Fringe Festival in 2012 and was
voted Pick of the Fringe. She is also an avid photographer specializing in
portrait and travel photography. She holds a B.A.(Hon.) in History and a M.A.
in Asia Pacific Policy Studies from UBC, and a J.D. from the University of
Alberta. 
Other Ways You Can Help
We
know that times are tight, and so if you can't help us financially, there are
still ways you can help us reach our goal! 
- 
Share this link/project on
Facebook, Twitter, email, poster, anything! Every little bit helps. 
- 
Come see our show! Tickets available at www.theocmusical.com. 
 See
you in September!

story:
What is Tomfoolery?

Tomfoolery Theatre Inc. began as a small group of young people with a passion for the performing arts & a desire to make musical theatre accessible to more people in all walks of life with all levels of experience. By rehearsing just twice a week and keeping costs and resources to a minimum, year after year we manage to create theatre that comes straight from our hearts and touches many others'. 

Visit our website to view more.

What We Need & What You Get

Guardian Angel Parish in Allendale, NJ has been kind enough to house Tomfoolery Theatre free of charge since our inception in 2009. However, there are many other costs associated with putting on a musical:

  • Theatrical licensing fees
  • Rental materials
  • Insurance costs (which have increased this year!)
  • Costumes
  • Scenery
  • Props
  • Marketing
  • A million little unforeseen disasters.

Every donation gets us closer to being able to cover one of these areas. Your support is what will make this show a success.

Thus, we want to recognize you for your contribution! See "Perks" for an array of ways we'd like to honor you for your generosity.


The Impact

Tomfoolery is not just a theatre group. After the devastating earthquake in 2010, we adopted The Rose Foundation of Haiti as our charity of choice. Since then, proceeds from each Tomfoolery production have gone toward aiding the impoverished people of Haiti. The more costs we can cover up front, the more we can ultimately give The Rose Foundation. Learn more about The Rose Foundation at rosefoundationofhaiti.org.

Other Ways You Can Help

Use the share buttons to tell your friends and family about us, pass around the link to your email contacts, or just talk about us! Spreading the word helps turn $1 into $1000--and we will be eternally grateful for that.

story:
Our Story

Hello, My name is Shakera Blackmon and I am a sophomore at The College of Wooster, majoring in Dance/Theatre and Communication studies. I was first introduced to dance at the age of three and I have been dancing ever since. Since then I have been involved in many performing arts programs, including studying dance and theatre for twelve years at Dekalb school of the Arts. Last year I got invited by the dance department at The College of Wooster to study dance and theatre in India. The trip is on December 27th, and we will be there for three weeks. In this time I will be studying "The Natyasastra" which is a combination of dance,theatre, and music. Please help me so that I can take my passion for dance and the arts to the next level.

.

The Impact

My dream is to share my passion for dance and the arts with others through performance and teaching. As a child/teenager, dance became a outlet for emotions and feelings. Often times I felt as if I could not talk about certain things, but through music and dance I was allowed to leave my emotions on the dance floor. Now as a young woman I hope to use my dance to tell stories through my body that literally change others lives or that at least leaves a person feeling happy. I want to bring real issues to the dance floor. I want to dance about love, pain, faith, passion and anything that means something to someone. I will no longer dance just to dance, or act just to act. I will use my talent, my body, and my voice to change the world.


What We Need & What You Get

I am looking to raise $5000 dollars. The cost of the trip including plane ticket, hotel, and special events in India $4000. I will need a extra $1000 for passport, visa, vaccinations, and other medications and health tools that will be need in travel. Please give what you can. 5dollars or 500dollars your donation is appreciated.   


Other Ways You Can Help

Please tell everyone you know! Time is running out! THANKS!!!

story:
Short Summary

Hello! We are the collaborators of "DIE WEIßE ROSE" (or "The White Rose" in English) and we are a group of young professional theater artists based in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Our theater production is one which explores the lives and deaths of the non-violent resistance group called "Die Weiße Rose," who was comprised of University students in Nazi occupied Munich during World War II. 
We believe that by creating a performance about these individuals, we are showing what a great example they were of effective non-violent protest and how large of an impact a small group of students can have on a society. The members of Die Weiße Rose proved that ideas and art can change the course of a country.

What We Need & What You Get

For our production, we will need a space to perform in and those are rarely free. A majority of our funds will be going the cost of renting a performance space. With that in mind, any money we receive above our goal will allow us to add additional performances. Our overall price breakdown is as follows:

PERFORMANCE SPACE:
~$300 per day; ~$1000 per weekend
This price includes both space costs and the cost of liability insurance.

ACTOR & DESIGNER COMPENSATION:
~$450 for the tremendous amount of artist expertise and to reimburse transportation costs

TECHNICAL NEEDS/COSTUMES:
$300 or whatever left over money we have available.
Specific technical needs are as follows:
- Video or overhead projectors
- Sound and audio equipment
- Necessary set pieces, such as chairs, tables, and ladders
- Stage properties

The Impact

We believe in what Die Weiße Rose stood for; non violent protest and changing the political world by using the vehicle of art and distribution. We also believe that what they stood for is important for all people to realize, especially now. In our current decade of struggle and protest, art and history are vital weapons for changing an unjust system. With this production, we are using those weapons.

Risks & Challenges

This is the premiere effort of this new company of performers to fund a project of this scale.  What we lack in raw experience, we make up for with a fierce amount of determination and an appetite to learn at every opportunity.   

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the love and SHARE our campaign with all your friends and family. If you would like additional ways to help or become more involved, please email Josie Lampone.

THANKS!

story:
Our Story

Cafe Extraordinaire is the latest project by Champaign-based Psychic Joker Entertainment. All performers ourselves, we wanted an accessible place for local talent be able to come and play. We also wanted to create a comfortable late-night gathering place with plenty of entertainment choices all night long.


Psychic Joker Entertainment was created in the spring of 2009 by Lisa & Jason Cerezo and Jace Hoppes. Our goal is to give local audiences the opportunity to create and experience unique choices in entertainment. We prefer to give our own personal focus to the art of magic, but all are welcome on our stage!


The Impact

Cafe Extraordinaire will play a part in the continuing growth and revitalization of not only the local performing arts community but also the economics of downtown Champaign. The city of Champaign recognizes the community need for an intimate, accessible performance space for entertainers who don't fit as well in a larger theater or a bar or pub. Cafe Extraordinaire would offer an 80-seat venue complemented by built-in food and beverage service, and would also re-purpose one of the unused buildings in the downtown Champaign area.


Ideally, we would like to network with local performance groups who need a place to call "home". Combining our efforts, both in volunteers and in resources, can only help us all reach our goals faster.


What We Need & What You Get

This funding campaign is geared toward simply getting the ball rolling on our final dream project. We have a unique and specific vision of a beautiful space that can be open nearly around the clock, where unique entertainment might be discovered at any moment. We also envision a full-service cafe where we can introduce our customers to beverages and culinary delights from around the globe. But for now, we want to get those doors  open and get that stage set.


By spring of 2011, we plan to secure our building and begin the design of our space. The environment won't be quite as glamorous as we envision in our final result, but it will be comfortable and inviting. We might start out with pour-it-yourself coffee blends so you'll have something to enjoy while taking in our entertainment offerings, while eventually we'll be able to offer a variety of coffee and tea beverages and specialty food items. We might be open only on occasion to start out--when we have entertainers scheduled--but we look forward to being open each and every night. We will continue to look for donors after this campaign ends, as well as put our own money into the project to see it succeed. In the meantime, we're looking for seed money to at least get the doors open.


Other Ways You Can Help

Remember, the power of networks is every bit as important as the power of cash. Someone out there knows someone else who has the desire and the ability to help us bring this project to its full completion. So if you believe in our project, spread the word! Like us on Facebook (www.facebook.com/cafeextraordinaire) and Follow us on Twitter (www.twitter.com/pjcafe). Come to events like our Rocky Horror Picture Show screening and help us get the funding we need to make your new favorite hangout a reality!

story:
About Us

Raas is an Indian cultural dance originating from the state of Gujarat. It is a high energy dance that is done in pairs with sticks called ‘dandiya.’ While following the beat of the music, performers use these dandiya and their bodies to put on a fascinating performance for huge audiences. This performance helps summarize why the Indian culture is so beautiful and allows teammates from diverse backgrounds to promote its widespread exposure.

GatoRaas is a national collegiate dance team that competes throughout the Fall and Spring in Florida and around the country. The team was founded in the early 2000’s and began competing in the National Raas circuit during the 2006-2007 season. In 2010, GatoRaas placed 1st at the national bid competition, Miami Mayhem, propelling them into nationals that year to win the Raas All-Stars National Championship. Our team is striving to find our way back to nationals this year and we need as much help as we can get.

This season, we are travelling to various competitions, both in-state and out-of-state, and thus funds are required to help us compete with other national teams. These funds are important to us as a dance team so that we can display our cultural diversity within a reasonable cost.

         


Competitions/Performances

Orlando Magic Game India Day: January 31st, 2016

Zahara Competition (Chicago): February 12th-February 14th

Miami Mayhem Competition: February 19th-February 21st

TedxUF: March 25th, 2016

R2B2 (Dallas, Texas): February 26th-February 28th


                      


Use of Funds: 

Costumes: In Raas, we use traditional Indian outfits that are custom made in order to make our performance eye catching. 
Travel Accommodation: As mentioned, we will be traveling out of state for our competitions, which requires hotel fees and airfare tickets.
Registration Fees: For every competition that we attend, members are required to pay individual registration fees that cover lodging, transportation, and etc.

story:
Short Summary

We are a brand new theater company making our debut theatrical performance here in New York City. We intend on producing cutting edge riveting theater, both with established works and new ones.  We are are a group of local New York actors looking to establish our own voice in this crazy world. Our debut begins on August 23-25 with the production of Sam Shephard's True West.  See you all there.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $3,000 in the next month.  This will cover the costs of the following.....

  • Cost of renting the Beckmann Theater (314 West 54th Street)
  • Cost of rights for True West by Sam Shephard
  • Sets, Costumes, and Props
  • Marketing and Publicity costs
  • Printing Costs for programs

All contributions no matter how big or how small are greatly appreciated.  No amount is too small, or too big for that matter.  If you contribute the following amounts you do get something besides our ever-lasting gratitude. 

  • $25 contribution - and you will have your name listed in our program as one of our supporters
  • $100 contribution - and you will recieve two complinetary tickets to the performance of your choosing, plus separate credit in the program as one of our patrons

Other Ways You Can Help

IF you cannot contribute that does not mean you cannot help, or that we do not appreciate you.  If you cannot contribute, please spread the word to other people you know that may be able to.  At the very least make sure you come to the performance of True West.  It will be a momentous occasion, one filled with laughter, tension-filled drama......and of course....THERE WILL BE TOAST!

story:
We are Manic Productions and our mandate is to create theatre that is engaging and thought-provoking from the perspective of female characters with mental illness. 

What We Need & What You Get

Money raised from this campaign will help us take Asylum by the Lake to Edmonton Fringe this summer.  The money raised from this campaign will help us cover travel costs to and from Edmonton, advertising and promotion, and rehearsal space. .

Each of our perks is named after a part of the former Lakeshore Psychiatric hospital. The last perk is named after the secret tunnels below the hospital. 

Each of our perks is designed to thank our contributor, through simple thanks either through email or in our show programmes, as well as by providing exclusive content that we offer to no one else, like a full cast signed poster.  

The Impact

A few years back we learned about the existence of the former Lakeshore Psychiatric Hospital in Toronto. This forgotten institution sparked our imagination. After reading about a mysterious accident that happened there - two female patients’ bodies washed ashore on the banks of Lake Ontario - we were inspired; we wanted to know more.  Experimenting with time, place, and perspective; Asylum by the Lake explores each women's unique illness and treatment.  These women don`t look at the world in a linear way and the story plays out from their point of view; mystifying, unbalanced, uncomfortable.  

Creative Team

Dana Fradkin: Co-Writer/Co-Producer/Actor "Nellie" 

Melissa Morris: Co-Writer/Co-Producer

Bonnie Anderson: Director

Lindsay Dagger: Stage Manager/Props and Costumes

Matt McGeachy: Dramaturge

Molly Flood: Actor "Leanne"

Samantha Madely: Actor "Kat"

Rick Kunst: Actor "Doctor Morkin"

Claire Frances Muir: Actor "Honey"

Vanessa Schmit-Craan: Actor "Dot"                                                                                        

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, then please help by getting the word out. Use the IndieGoGo share tools to spread the word through your social network and help us take Asylum by the Lake to Edmonton this summer.
story_txt:
We are Manic Productions and our mandate is to create theatre that is engaging and thought-provoking from the perspective of female characters with mental illness. 
What We Need & What You Get
Money raised from this campaign will help us take Asylum by the Lake to Edmonton Fringe this summer.  The money raised from this campaign will help us cover travel costs to and from Edmonton, advertising and promotion, and rehearsal space. .
Each of our perks is named after a part of the former Lakeshore Psychiatric hospital. The last perk is named after the secret tunnels below the hospital. 
Each of our perks is designed to thank our contributor, through simple thanks either through email or in our show programmes, as well as by providing exclusive content that we offer to no one else, like a full cast signed poster.  

The Impact
A few years back we learned about the existence of the former Lakeshore Psychiatric Hospital in Toronto. This forgotten institution sparked our imagination. After reading about a mysterious accident that happened there - two female patients’ bodies washed ashore on the banks of Lake Ontario - we were inspired; we wanted to know more.  Experimenting with time, place, and perspective; Asylum by the Lake explores each women's unique illness and treatment.  These women don`t look at the world in a linear way and the story plays out from their point of view; mystifying, unbalanced, uncomfortable.

Claire Frances Muir: Actor "Honey"
Vanessa Schmit-Craan: Actor "Dot"                                                                                        
Other Ways You Can Help


If you can't contribute, then please help by getting the word out. Use the IndieGoGo share tools to spread the word through your social network and help us take Asylum by the Lake to Edmonton this summer.

story:
Becoming Conocido follows Jennifer’s journey through self-awareness when the ethnicity choices on a college application challenges her ideas about identity. Confronted by memories she wishes to forget, Jennifer discovers checking a box won’t be as easy as she thought.

Awarded Best of Fest at Frontera Fest Short Fringe 2006 (Austin, Tx), Becoming Conocido has been accepted into the 2012 Edinburgh Fringe Festival, the largest arts festival in the world held annually in Edinburgh, Scotland.

Who I Am:

My work comes from an experience of blue skies and rusty dirt.  Where stories are whispered languages revered with the sunrise and Fate is constantly challenged by women burning to create a destiny of their own.  A native Tejaña, I also work in photography, movement and site specific performance.   Currently, I study in the MFA Writing for Performance program at California Institute of the Arts.  

How Your Contribution Helps:

Your donation toward my $2700 goal will assist in travel costs, housing and marketing materials for Becoming Conocido at Edinburgh Fringe Fest.

               The Break Down:
                                        $1250 Airfare
                                        $1200 Room/board
                                        $300 Show posters and flyers
                                                                       $2750 TOTAL NEED

What You Can Receive for Your Contribution:

  • Becoming Conocido Magnet
  • Becoming Conocido Postcard sent from Edinburgh, Scotland
  • 4 X 6 matte signed Personal Portrait (used in show) photograph by Isabel Salazar
  • 5 X 7 matte signed Personal Portrait (used in show) photograph by Isabel Salazar
  • 8X10 matte signed photograph (used in show) by Isabel Salazar
  • 8x10 matte signed Personal Portrait (used in show) photograph by Isabel Salazar

Other Ways You Can Help:

Can’t donate more but still have an urge to support Becoming Conocido?  Órale!  Please get the word out to others by posting on your Facebook, Twitter, Tumbler, websites and email blasts.  Becoming Conocido was born from the help of friends and family in 2006.  Let’s keep that momentum present in 2012.  Share, share, share!


Special Thanks to:
Abraham Osuna
Maneja Beto, www.manejabeto.com
Austin Script Works, www.scriptworks.org

story:
About me

My name is Sommer Schoch; it is my vision to bring a theater that speaks to the soul to Somerset, Kentucky and the surrounding area. Here's a little about me:

  • Started in community theater at the Star Theater in Russell Springs
  • Continued acting, directing, and volunteering with the Lake Cumberland Children's Theatre in Somerset
  • Studied theater and entrepreneurship at Northern Kentucky University
  • Most recently received Master's of Arts Administration from the University of Cincinnati
  • Worked with: Arena Stage in Washington D.C., Cincinnati Shakespeare Company, and the Commonwealth Theater Company

I've always wanted to return home after graduating and bring my love of theater back to the community that I grew up in. This is my chance, and your contribution will help make that dream come true! 

Our first production

The first play I want to produce in Somerset is a play by Arlene Hutton called Last Train to Nibroc. You may be familiar with the Nibroc festival that takes place in Corbin, Kentucky - this is a play that follows the relationship of two people who meet on a train and discover they are from the same small area of Kentucky. It is witty and smart, but most of all I think it reflects the spirit of our region. 

By contributing to this Indiegogo campaign, you will be covering costs associated with the first production, including:

  • Scripts & Production Rights
  • Set Pieces
  • Costumes & Props
  • Lights & Sound
  • Venue Rental

Flashback Theater Co.

Last Train to Nibroc will be the launching production for a new theater company called Flashback Theater Co. I know through my previous work in the surrounding community theater that the region has a lot of talent - this company will be an avenue for some of that talent to shine. Your donation will be going to the first production and it will also have the lasting impact of creating a new company that could be around for years.

Obstacles

There are several obstacles to overcome before this production can open:

  • Finding and securing a space
  • Getting the word out
  • Finding volunteers
  • Initial funding

I am working diligently on acquiring an auditorium space. You've made it to this page so the word is getting out. As I meet supporters, I find willing volunteers. Your donation helps to overcome the final obstacle. The best part: your donation will be tax-deductible.

Flashback Theater Co. is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Flashback Theater Co. must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

How you can help (yes, you!)

Giving to this campaign addresses one major obstacle. But if you can't donate, there are other things you can do to help us out:

  • Share us with your friends on Facebook and Twitter.
  • For those more hands-on, go to our website and fill out the volunteer form on our Get Involved page.
  • Tell your friends about us! Make plans to come see the show with a group of your friends or family. Sign up for our email for an announcement of when tickets go on sale.

One last thing

Thank you! Just by taking the time to consider this campaign you have shown you are interested in its success. I look forward to giving you updates as the campaign and production progress!

story:
Short Summary

Daughters of Leda is a new play that gives the women in ancient mythology a chance to tell their side of the story.  It is an effort re-envision the role of women in society in an empowering and exciting way, through the stories traditionally used to instill us with fear of feminine knowledge. Originally conceived as a response to media narrative for the Women Center Stage Festival in 2013, and since developed at Dixon Place and Theatre for the New City over the past year, this month long residency at IRT will culminate in two weeks of performances open to the public Dec 11-21st. 

  • We are raising money toward the cost of Sets, Lights, Costumes, Sound, etc.
  • It is important that this production be fully realized in a way that can reach the most people. It is rare that this many women get to play strong characters onstage or that we are provided with the opportunity to rethink what history we are told. 
  • Without our indiegogo supporters this production will not be possible. 


What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to raised $5,500 to cover production costs. 
  • If we pass that goal we get to start paying everyone, which is even more exciting!!!
  • If we don't reach our goal, the funds will still go toward the production.

The Impact

You are fully realizing a story that changes the stage narrative for women.

  • The is a collaborative project created, designed, and performed by strong intelligent women, in honor of the women who never got to tell their stories, and in the hope that women will continue to. 
  • We have been volunteering countless hours to create this show since July 2013. This is our chance to share it with you. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are interested in volunteering to support the production, there are tons of other ways to help out! 

  • Spread the word about this production and fundraising campaign!
  • Volunteer to be an usher at the show!
  • Like us on facebook!

story:
NatsuWeen is

NatsuCon's Halloween cosplay dance. We hosted it last year at the Maryland Heights center and we want to do it again, this time at the St. Louis Skatium on October 24th! In case you didn't know:

  • NatsuCon is run purely by volunteers and donations from fans like you.
  • After not hosting a convention this year, we want to do something for the community again!
  • With this campaign we can host a fun dance complete with DJ's, games, prizes, and a greater sense of the anime community that we want to become more integrated with!
  • Essentially, a fun anime convention-style dance with extra activities and lots of fun!

NatsuWeen has Contests!

  • We are hosting a cosplay contest with a donated $40 Visa pre-paid card
  • We are hosting pumpkin carving again best pumpkin gets ad donated $20 Pizza Hut gift card!

What We Need & What You Get

In order to host NatsuWeen we need:

  • To cover the venue costs
  • To rent equipment for lights and sound
  • Organize activities and get fabulous prizes
  • In exchange for donating we will  offer wristbands, drawstring bags, T-shirts, and even mascot plushies! [see perks]

The Impact

We feel it's important to hold events such as NatsuWeen to keep our community tightly knit, active, and connected. NatsuWeen is also a good "introductory experience" for those who are new to the convention scene.

    Risks & Challenges

    If we do not make our $1000 goal, we will not be able to purchase or rent everything need to have an awesome NatsuWeen, however:

    • We believe in our fan base for the support over the years
    • We believe that YOU want NatsuWeen to happen too
    • A successful NatsuWeen will be the first step in planning an exciting return for NatsuCon in 2015!

    Promo items and t-shirts will be given to donors if this campaign does not meet the target goal.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Even if you can't donate you can still help the NatsuCrew's mission to bring fun!

      • Share the campaign on social media! 
      • Talk about NatsuWeen with your friends!
      • Like us on Facebook and share our posts!

story:
We're Going to Scotland!

REED DANCE has been invited to participate in the "BOOKING DANCE FESTIVAL EDINBURGH 2014!" Which means we need your help!

        Under the direction of Greer Reed, REED DANCE brings the multicultural community together in a professional, educational environment. With such an engaging and spirited group of dancers, REED DANCE is known for setting the audience ablaze with energy. Not only versatile in their shape, size and color; the company has a powerhouse of repertory that features the beauty of athleticism. REED DANCE is committed to staying on the pulse of contemporary dance through its world-class repertory with choreographers such as: Kyle Abraham, Sidra Bell, Camille A. Brown, Terence Greene, Christopher Huggins, Kevin "Iega" Jeff, Kiesha Lalama, and Darrell Grand Moultrie, to name a few. 

        Previously of 2014, REED DANCE was formally known as August Wilson Center Dance Ensemble. In transitioning with the same intent, vision and mission, REED DANCE is continuing its excellence and standard that it has already set and pushing to new heights and goals with determination to spread the love of dance to all.

        REED DANCE will be sending dancers Rebekah Kuczma and Kaylin Horgan (both founding members), and lighting designer Bob Steinek to represent the company in Scotland in August 2014. Rebekah and Kaylin will be performing an excerpt of "Now You Can Let Go," a duet choreographed by New York City choreographer Sidra Bell that premiered in Pittsburgh, March 2014. The purpose of this festival is to book tours abroad for future seasons. 

       

We Need $ 5,000.

We have been raising money since hearing the great news of the festival! However, we are not quite there yet. REED DANCE will be inspiring the streets of Scotland from August 9, 2014 - August 18. The $5,000 will go towards: 

  • Our housing
  • Food
  • Transportation within Scotland
  • Fees of the Festival


Sharing Pittsburgh. 

REED DANCE is success Pittsburgh can call its own. Artistic Director: Greer Reed, Rebekah, Kaylin, and Bob are all born and raised in the Steel City. The company takes pride in representing the city and believes it is our duty to give back to our community. The invitation to perform in the EDINBURGH BOOKING DANCE FESTIVAL is a reflection on YOU, Pittsburgh! 

By seeding into this trip, you will be investing into the dance community of Pittsburgh, as well. As a company, it is our desire to put Pittsburgh on the map for dance. We are certainly taking strides in that direction, but we could use help from our neighbors.

With that said, No donation is too small! 

From the bottom of our hearts, we say "THANK YOU" in advance for your contribution!

Risks & Challenges

With any company transition, financial struggles occur. This past year has been full of highs and lows. Through it all, our momentum has never stopped. As we continue to book shows locally and abroad, we are focusing on building a strong foundation as REED DANCE. 

Though the August Wilson Center Dance Ensemble as been around since 2010, REED DANCE is only one year old. Being recognized enough to go to Scotland is an honor, but the cost trip could also be considered a risk. We are doing our part to ensure the company, the city, and the country will all be represented well. We are investing money into this trip with eyes set for the future. 

Support from YOU is extremely important and necessary for us to continue to move forward. We are positive our experience in Scotland will be fruitful.

If we do not reach our goal of 5,000, we will be limited in our necessities. We would like to take comfort and be confident in knowing our hospitality and traveling costs will be taking care of before we start our journey to Edinburgh, Scotland. 


There's Other Ways to Help Us!

We know the struggle is REAL! (that's why we made this beautiful indiegogo). If you can  not contribute to this project, but would like to support REED DANCE as we journey to the festival in Scotland, please SHARE WITH EVERYONE YOU KNOW! Or, even if you can contribute to this project, please SHARE WITH EVERYONE YOU KNOW! 

THANK YOU!

story:
1. What is Shook Ones?


Shook Ones is a multimedia dance theater company based in New York City. We use spoken word, movement and projection to create live experiences that are visually stimulating, emotionally impactful and socially relevant.


2. What's the purpose of this campaign?

Shook Ones is in the process of building our first evening-length production and we can't do it without the support of our extended family.  We are hoping to raise $15,000 through the campaign, though we've only listed a $10,000 goal; this is because the good folks at Indiegogo will take a larger percentage of our donations if we fail to reach our stated goal.  So we’re playing it safe, though we encourage you not to! We're extremely fortunate to have an anonymous donor who will kick off our campaign by matching all funds up to $1,000 before December 31st.  That means if you donate before December 31st, your donation will automatically be doubled, up to $1,000!

We have already received a huge amount of support from the LaGuardia Performing Arts Center. They’re providing us with both a creation residency and a technical residency, as well as two work-in-progress showings at the end of May.  In order to make this all happen, however, we still need to transport, house, and compensate our primary collaborator, Crazy Smooth. We also need your help to support the rest of our incredible team of artists: our lighting/set designer, our composer/DJ,  our poet/MC, and so on. You’ll notice all those slashes; that's because everyone involved in Sorry is wearing multiple hats in order to create this ambitious piece in as resourceful a way as possible! Finally, we need donations to help us purchase projection equipment, costumes, and set pieces in order to bring our vision to life.  We just received word that our fiscal sponsorship through Fractured Atlas has been approved, so your donation is now officially tax deductible.  It takes a village to raise a child, and Sorry is definitely our baby, so please consider showing your support!


3.  What's Sorry about?

Sorry is about two artists from vastly different walks of life -- both culturally and stylistically -- who find common ground in dance. Through their shared passion for movement, education and social justice, a deep bond grows between them. They're soon forced, however, to confront their differences head on, and to acknowledge that no matter how little they themselves make of what they look like or where they come from, these things continue to exert an influence on their lives. The other half of our exploration will connect the dancers’ story to a larger population of Americans who experience discrimination or privilege based on their race, sex, or economic status. We’ll engage this broader discussion throughout, using live spoken word and video projection to reflect, enhance, and expand upon our lovers’ story as it unfolds.

Sorry is a tale of good intentions and missed opportunities. It's a story of love, hustle music, and the transformative power of forgiveness.


4.  Who's on the team?


Born in Sunnyvale, California, Cindy Salgado started dancing at the age of 3. After graduating from the Juilliard School with the Princess Grace Award in 2005, she began freelancing in New York. She danced for Aszure Barton & Artists on projects such as Busk and Mikhail Baryshnikov’s Hell’s Kitchen Dance Tour.  She has assisted in preproduction for Andy Blankenbuehler on multiple Broadway shows and assisted and performed for Mia Michaels in various concert and commercial projects.  She is currently on faculty with New York City Dance Alliance and was recently Assistant Rehearsal Director for Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet. Cindy was a cofounder and volunteer teacher for Artists Striving To End Poverty.  She has choreographed for various performances around New York and Frankfurt and has started a collective called Shook Ones.  Cindy has been a proud member of Kidd Pivot since 2009.


Born in Benin in West Africa, Yvon Soglo (B-boy Crazy Smooth) was raised in Aylmer, Quebec. He has been dancing for over ten years during which he has come to be one of Canada’s top street dancers. Like many of the world’s street dancers, Smooth is an autodidact, although his passion and respect for the history of the art form has led him to study with some of New York’s top street dancers including Ken Swift, Brian Green, Shannon (Which Way Sha), Mr. Wiggles and Breaks Kru to name a few. He is also the first B-boy to receive a full grant from the Canadia Arts Council to study B-boying and other forms of street dance in New York and also Philadelphia and Orlando. Smooth has been a main participant in Blueprint for Life’s “Connecting with Inuit Youth through Hip-Hop”, and was invited to be a keynote speaker at the United Nations Youth Conference in Edmonton. In 2004, Smooth founded the award-winning, Ottawa-based Bboyizm, a professional street dance company that has toured across Canada.

Born and raised in Miami, FL, Alejandro Rodriguez moved to New York City in 2005 to attend The Juilliard School (Group 38). Since graduating, he’s created numerous roles Off-Broadway, including the part of Charlie Rosa in Ghetto Babylon at 59E59 (National Latino Playwrights Award),  and the character of Gabriel in the New York Times Critics’ Pick Bird in the Hand at Theater for the New City. He played the title role in The Acting Company's national tour of Romeo and Juliet, and the part of Edgar opposite Billy Porter in King Lear, directed by Drama Desk Award Winner Ed Sylvanus Iskandar. Regionally, he's performed at The Kennedy Center, the Guthrie Theatre, Denver Center Theater Company,  and the Los Angeles Theater Center, among several others. His film and TV credits include Nurse Jackie (Showtime), Dates from Hell (Discovery ID), and the feature film Emoticon. By day, he is the Associate Director of Programs for Artists Striving to End Poverty (ASTEP), where he helps emerging and established artists harness their talents to empower youth around the world.


Born in Boston, Yazmany Arboleda grew up in Colombia and then Miami.  He studied architecture at The Catholic University of America in Washington, D.C. and completed art and design programs at Parson's School of Design in New York City, Universitat Politecnica de Catalunya in Barcelona, and Istituto Marangoni in Milan and London. His first solo exhibition, "The New Vitruvians", debuted in New York in May 2007, before traveling to London later that year.  In 2008, he founded The Glassless Glasses Studio, an art activation collaborative based in Brooklyn. His work has been written about in the New York Times, the Washington Post, and the UK's Guardian, and he was recently named one of Good Magazine's 100 People Making Our World Better.


5.  What's the timeline for production?


December 16th - January 16th:

Collecting donations via Indiegogo to make Sorry possible

February 9th - March 7th:

Laguardia Performing Arts Center Residency (First Creation Period)

March 9th - March 20th:

Further development and two workshop performances as participants in the InterArts seminar at The Juilliard School

April 8th - April 17th:

Laguardia Performing Arts Center Residency (Second Creation Period)

May 25th - 29th:

Technical Rehearsals at LPAC

May 29th and May 30th, 2015:

Sorry Work-in-Progress Performances
story_txt:
1. What is Shook Ones?


Shook Ones is a multimedia dance theater company based in New York City. We use spoken word, movement and projection to create live experiences that are visually stimulating, emotionally impactful and socially relevant.

2. What's the purpose of this campaign?
 
Shook
 Ones is in the process of building our first evening-length production 
and we can't do it without the support of our extended family.  We are 
hoping to raise $15,000 through the campaign, though we've only listed a
 $10,000 goal; this is because the good folks at Indiegogo will take a 
larger percentage of our donations if we fail to reach our stated goal. 
 So we’re playing it safe, though we encourage you not to! We're 
extremely fortunate to have an anonymous donor who will kick off our 
campaign by matching all funds up to $1,000 before December 31st.  That means if you donate before December 31st, your donation will automatically be doubled, up to $1,000!
We
 have already received a huge amount of support from the LaGuardia Performing Arts Center. They’re providing us with both a creation 
residency and a technical residency, as well as two work-in-progress 
showings at the end of May.  In order to make this all happen, however, 
we still need to transport, house, and compensate our primary 
collaborator, Crazy Smooth. We also need your help to support the rest 
of our incredible team of artists: our lighting/set designer, our 
composer/DJ,  our poet/MC, and so on. You’ll notice all those slashes; 
that's because everyone involved in Sorry is wearing multiple 
hats in order to create this ambitious piece in as resourceful a way as 
possible! Finally, we need donations to help us purchase projection 
equipment, costumes, and set pieces in order to bring our vision to 
life.  We just received word that our fiscal sponsorship through 
Fractured Atlas has been approved, so your donation is now officially tax deductible.  It takes a village to raise a child, and Sorry is definitely our baby, so please consider showing your support!

story:
My daughter is a amazing dancer she lives to perform and works hard on being the best dancer that she is.She has been dancing since 3 years old. This year she tried out for Abby lee competition team and actually made the team and was so excited about it but sadly we are unable to pay for her to compete. I didn't realize how much it was going to be. I would hate to brake her heart and tell her that she can't compete this year. This little girl dances from morning to night just practicing and practicing that's all she does. So I ask please if you can help me make this happen for her I would greatly  appreciate it. Without your help Sadly I just can't afford it. Jasmin would appreciate any amount you can help with. 

Thank you! 

story:
Dance Parade New York's 2014 theme  is "BE the MOMENTUM"  -- And YOU can help create memories that will last a lifetime.

Over the past 7 years, Dance Parade New York has become the world's largest event to celebrate the diversity of dance. With your help on May 17th 2014, over 10,000 dancers will come together to celebrate more than 75 styles of dance and culture!


Dance Parade boogies down Broadway in the heart of Manhattan, sashays through Union Square and leaps across Saint Marks Place.  YOU will enable never seen before dance and choreography that highlight the human experience--Everything from Ballet to Breakdance, Two-step to Dub-Step and African to Zydeco--all in dazzling outfits, with live bands, djs and decorated floats.
The parade culminates in Tompkins Square Park where DanceFest kicks off unforgettable performances on four stages--with dance lessons, roaming performers and an epic dance party--all FREE to the public.

All participants in our Community Engagement Programs have the unique opportunity to dance alongside their teaching artists in the Parade and Festival! Click for more on these education programs.

Our Goals:

  • Although our entire budget exceeds $100,000, this BE THE MOMENTUM Campaign seeks $25,000 for essential elements of the parade, festival and eduction programs. The rest of the budget is secured through grants, event sponsorship, our Grandstand and our Annual Parade Showcase that happened March 30th.
  • Of the $25,000 goal, $9,000 will be allocated towards the Marketing, Publicity and Production of the Dance Parade. We will provide sound and parade floats for our Grand Marshals.
  • Another $8,000 will cover critical insurance and production expenses for DanceFest on 4 stages in Tompkins Square Park. 
  • A final $8,000 will go towards paying 12 teaching artists to bring dance to Schools, Community and Senior Centers in under-served communities.
  • The remainder of our budget is secured through grants, event sponsorship and our Annual Dance Parade Showcase scheduled for March 30 2014.


What You Can Get:

  • To show our gratitude, we've come up with some great perks to commemorate your contribution to the 8th Annual Dance Parade: T-shirts, a Photo Album of the Parade, Tote Bags, Magnets, and more!


Ladies or Mens T-Shirt with 8th Annual Dance Parade on back

Be credited in this
2014 Photo Album


Gift Bag with lots of Memorabilia
  • An opportunity to provide scholarships to emerging dance groups across New York City's five boroughs for parade registration. 
  • Thank You's including dance lessons, dinners with celebrities, social media and website accolades and a custom choreography.
  • Major marketing placement including parade floats, festival display booths and street banners to promote your company's branding and advertising.


Dream big and design your own Float!

Your Impact:

  • Come May 17th, the city will light up with color and culture. The general public will see never seen-before dance styles and be able to participate in the FREE Dance Parade and DanceFest.
  • Your support will help emerging dance groups reach broad audiences.
  • Our Community Engagement programs will employ teaching artists to bring dance to deserving schools, community and senior centers throughout New York City's 5 boroughs.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute financially and that's okay!

  • Please spread the word and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools near the top of the page and post on your friends' walls, tweet, or +1.
  • Join our planning team by registering as a volunteer at danceparade.org


Dance Parade, Inc. is a 501(c)(3) Non-Profit. Some donations are tax deductible to the extent allowable by law. For more information call us at 267-350-9213. Thank You

story:
The Fourth Annual Indianapolis Winter Magic Festival needs to pay the rent.

Hi, I'm Taylor Martin and with the folks at Indy Fringe we've been putting on the Winter Magic Festival for the past 3 years. Now, we need a little help in financing this year's event. Since we are using 2 theatres, both our Indy Fringe Basile, 719 E. St. Clair, for close-up and platform performances, and The Cook Theatre @ Indiana Landmarks Center 12th and Central Ave., we need some help paying the rent. So, we've worked out a series of perks to get your money to vanish from your wallet and appear at the landlord's facility almost by magic. 

With the line up we're having, you can't but help want to take advantage of the offers below. January 16-19, 2014.

What We Need & What You Get

We figure that $3,000 will give us a great financial base to bring the acts to Indy and help pay for the rent of the Cook Theatre.  The Great Tomsoni himself, Johnny Thompson is coming. This Time I Got It!! Even though he has retired his legendary dove act, Johnny will be doing a show of some of the great magic he's created and learned in nearly 60 years of performing. He will be doing 2 shows. The one on Saturday at 9 will have an opportunity for you to meet him afterwards. Plus, we have The Crescent Circus from New Orleans, The Action Bros. from Louisville, and Kayla Drescher, the winner of the "Next Great Magician" Search, who was selected by David Copperfield himself. Also, Jamahl Keye's "Broadway Magic" and returning from last year's "Champions of Magic" show, Trent James in his first full length set here in Indy. And that's just at The Cook. At The Basile Fringe, we have 5 of the best close-up and platform shows you'll ever see in one venue. Louisville's Cody Comet, Indy's Caleb Wiles, Indy's Ryan Siebert, Kentucky'sJohn Shore, and from Kokomo the Amazing Obtuse will produce more intimate shows of about 30 minutes to delight you with wonders that only other magicians usually see.

The Impact

What does this all mean? Well, Indianapolis is becoming a destination for magicians and fans of the art and by contributing it means we can make this even bigger. We expect magic fans from as far away as Cleveland and Chicago to attend. Your contribution will just show them why Indy is a special and magical place. And in January, what better way to make the winter days warmer than to see a magic show with your family and friends? 

Other Ways You Can Help 

If you can't contribute, just spread the word among your friends, fellow magicians, and fans of wonder. And you can attend a few shows, too. Ticket prices are going to be in the $7-15 range with Johnny's shows at $30. And if you wish to donate without taking one of the perks, that would be wonderful. Perk items can be mailed or picked up at the Festival.

story:
THE STORY:

For four years, StageBlack has constantly broken new ground, elevating both the African American experience and Theater by empowering artists to create and develop new works. Works of playwrights from across the country have graced the stage in this annual festival. This year, StageBlack makes it’s bi-coastal debut, presenting the same plays in New York City and Dallas. 

DATES:

STAGEBLACK will be presenting in August of 2014. Dates are currently being confirmed.

THE CREATIVE TEAM:

NYC Producers: Shanjala Frazier, Timothy Jones, G. Alvarez Reid, Melvin Shadd and Tony Thompson

Dallas Producers: Branon Gilbert, Nadine Marissa, Cherie Monique and Brandon White

Executive Producer: Jiles R. King, II

WHAT WE NEED:

Producing a show anywhere is expensive but producing in New York City is very expensive. We are raising $12,000.00 to cover the cost of the productions in both cities. We have a dynamic producing team assembled and always have top notch talent on the cast and creative team. Our costs include rental of rehearsal and production spaces, printing and distributing of publicity materials, and materials for set and props construction.

HOW YOU CAN HELP:

By making a donation to this production you are enabling us to provide this story and all the hard work we are putting into it, the production it deserves. Please see our different perk packages below.


If you are unable to help, please spread the word do pass on this campaign to those people who might be interested in helping our cause!

story:
Destination Dance: a site-specific dance tour through downtown Reno

Site-specific dance is work that is created in response to a particular place or site, inspired by its architecture, design, history, or current use. Destination Dance will feature the work of local choreographers who have been commissioned to create unique performances juxtaposed against iconic downtown fixtures, taking traditional and contemporary dance off of the stage and into a new environment.

What We Need

We are raising $3,000.00 to supplement the pay for the 30 local dancers who will be performing in the event. This free event is part of the Artown festival and will be seen by up to 400 people in our community. If we don't reach the entire goal, the funds will still be divided up amongst the performers.

Reshaping the Conventional Notions of Performance

This project aims to embrace the avant-garde ethos of the July festival, demonstrate the talent of our local emerging artists, and attract an audience that is not accustomed to viewing modern dance.

On Thursday, July 12, tour guides will lead groups departing from the Reno City Plaza at 6:00pm, 6:20pm, 6:40pm, and 7:00pm. They will be equipped to discuss the history behind the various sites and the inspiration behind each artist’s choreographic decisions.

The event is free to the public, and people will be welcome to join the tour for as many stops as they choose. The tour is a 1 mile loop and will take 1 hour to complete.

Featuring urban and natural sites located in the Riverwalk/Arts District in downtown Reno, this walking-distance dance tour will allow audience members to engage with dance in a whole new way and view some of Reno’s most treasured locations in a new and invigorating light. Utilizing signature monuments in the heart of Reno, Destination Dance will celebrate our city’s unique sense of place through movement.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, we hope to see you at the event! It's a free and family friendly 1 mile loop through downtown Reno, where you'll experience our unique city, new contemporary choreography, and wonderful performances by local dancers.

Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools, share our Facebook event page, and enjoy Artown this summer!

What We Need
We are raising $3,000.00 to supplement the pay for the 30 local dancers who will be performing in the event. This free event is part of the Artown festival and will be seen by up to 400 people in our community. If we don't reach the entire goal, the funds will still be divided up amongst the performers.

Reshaping the Conventional Notions of Performance
This project aims to embrace the avant-garde ethos of the July festival, demonstrate the talent of our local emerging artists, and attract an audience that is not accustomed to viewing modern dance.
On Thursday, July 12, tour guides will lead groups departing from the Reno City Plaza at 6:00pm, 6:20pm, 6:40pm, and 7:00pm. They will be equipped to discuss the history behind the various sites and the inspiration behind each artist’s choreographic decisions.
The event is free to the public, and people will be welcome to join the tour for as many stops as they choose. The tour is a 1 mile loop and will take 1 hour to complete.
Featuring urban and natural sites located in the Riverwalk/Arts District in downtown Reno, this walking-distance dance tour will allow audience members to engage with dance in a whole new way and view some of Reno’s most treasured locations in a new and invigorating light. Utilizing signature monuments in the heart of Reno, Destination Dance will celebrate our city’s unique sense of place through movement.

Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't contribute, we hope to see you at the event! It's a free and family friendly 1 mile loop through downtown Reno, where you'll experience our unique city, new contemporary choreography, and wonderful performances by local dancers.
Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools, share our Facebook event page, and enjoy Artown this summer!

story:
What's Going On?

I'm Molly Kate, a 23 year-old artist who wants to do so much with my life that I wish I had more limbs.

I've been doing theatre since I was ten years old, growing from youth theatre onto Center REP's Young REP intensive summer workshop, to community theatre in the Bay Area. Theatre is a part of me and will never go away, but I decided against going to a theatre school and getting a degree simply because I never found myself drawn to studying Shakespeare or Stanislavski for semesters at a time.  I took a clowning master class when I was 19 years old, and the teacher, Sara Moore, came up to me and looked me straight in the face and said "You have to do this."  And I've seen enough movies to know when someone tells you that, you don't let that go.  Once I found physical theatre and clowning, my entire theatre performance history made sense, and everything felt like home.  I started researching the types of physical theatre and taking classes at the Flying Actor Studio in San Francisco with renown physical actor James Donlon.  I stumbled across the website for the Dell'Arte International School of Physical Theatre and fell in love.

In higher education I chose a photography degree.  The fields of photography will keep me happy and I know I have potential to keep a couple bucks in my pocket with my talents.  However, in a sudden turn of events, I will be graduating this May, and, to be honest, I am unprepared.  And I know I'm not alone.  The dream of going to Dell'Arte and pursuing theatre has been on the back of my mind for nearly five years and I know I'll regret not trying.

I'm currently only interested in taking their Summer Workshop this coming June.  I want to test the program to see if it is something I would like to pursue for the Masters Degree that they offer in ensemble-based physical theatre.  After reading the information about the workshop that teaches the DAI Intensive, I fell in love all over again.  But I am suddenly graduating college!  I am running full speed at THE REST OF LIFE and I am worried that not doing this summer workshop will be a missed opportunity of a lifetime.

How You'll Make Me Happy

College changes people, and living alone gives us insight into our souls.  While living alone in a tiny, Molly-sized studio and pursuing my degree in photography, I've found myself suffering from depression and anxiety problems.  While they most definitely begin to occur in most people in their 20s, the common denominator for me was that I had to basically give up theatre (something I'd been doing non-stop for a decade) to work on an art form that relies on a different kind of creativity.  I constantly crave doing theatre and my soul feeds off of naturally-occuring clowning in daily life, and the euphoria of occasional swing dancing.  I have a dark sense of regret lingering in the back of my mind, worried that if I get stuck in this business-oriented world, I may never have another theatrical outlet.  Or I'll never know if I truly need theatre in my life.  This month-long workshop will give me a push in a direction that might have a light to guide me.  Currently, it is dark and confusing, and all I crave is physical theatre and fear the loss of missing this chance.  The training I have already done in physical theatre has made me into a better human, and I can feel that.  The way that I move and react to my surroundings has changed ever since I was called to the world of being barefoot, wearing a red nose, and creating something awesome from nothing.  The training Dell'Arte offers will absolutely aid me in the "real world" and give me proper discipline in the areas of creativity that I need.  Dell'Arte teaches ensemble training, as well as learning how to make something from within yourself, and how to properly present it to an audience.  "Effort, Risk, Momentum, Joy" are the words of Dell'Arte.  These are all things that I have, but know I will benefit from studying fully.  Dell'Arte will open a world of possibilities for me, and your donations will help me find them.

What I Need & What I Can Give You

I've done the required calculations, and figured out that for the workshop I will need $3,300.  The program is $1250, the housing is $650, and the rest covers the rent for my empty apartment in Sacramento ($675) and food and transportation and indiegogo percentage (~$400).  

Since I'm graduating so suddenly, I have had no time to save money, especially as a full-time student of one of the most expensive art forms and working a coffee job only 20 hours a week at just above minimum wage.

While I'm not expecting to raise the full amount, anything will help me.

I want to give you my love (I have A LOT OF IT) and my art (the possibilities are boundless).  I don't know what the donations will look like just yet, but anything below $100 I will make original art pieces, and beautiful hand-written thank-you cards with calligraphy and rubber stamps.  Anything above $100 I will be happy to give you prints, photoshoots, or discounts on photoshoots.  Let's talk and let's all be happy.

You're A Starving Artist Too?  Don't Panic!

I'm just a girl who wants some clarity.  We've all been there.  Send my link around to your friends.  Everyone can connect and understand the struggle of following dreams.

Also, go see theatre.  Ensemble-based physical theatre is consistently changing the theatre world and it allows for new ways for audiences to see the world, and the world within themselves.  Take a friend to see some theatre and get inspired.

art is art is art is art...

story:
What is AN AMERICAN FAMILY TAKES A LOVER?

AN AMERICAN FAMILY TAKES A LOVER is a play. A dark play. A funny play. A play about race and sex and the inner recesses of the American psyche.

Short Summary

Richard David, his wife Lady Anne, and their "other" person Justine, are a uniquely American family. When handyman Thomas arrives to fix a mysterious hole in the wall, his presence threatens to tear the family apart. Through swimming lessons, soap operas, Truth or Dare and dusty flowers, AN AMERICAN FAMILY TAKES A LOVER explores The Stockholm Syndrome through a racial and sexual lens.

AN AMERICAN FAMILT TAKES A LOVER was incubated at the cell, a 21st Century Salon, founding artistic director Nancy Manocherian. It received deveopment workshops with The Hive Theater.

 
Theater for the New City presents the cell's production of An American Family Takes A Lover by Amina Henry.

Place: Theater for the New City's Cabaret Theater

          155 First Avenue, NY, NY 10003 (btwn 9th & 10th St)

Dates: November 7-10 & November 14-17, 2013

Written by: Amina Henry

Directed by: Kira Simring

Stage Managed by: TBA

Set Design: TBA

Lighting Design: TBA

Costume Design: TBA

Sound Design: TBA

 

Starring:

RICHARD DAVID Bob Jaffe

LADY ANNE Lila Donnolo

JUSTINE TBA

THOMAS TBA

 

What We Need

Our needs are modest but they are needs nonetheless...

 

Where Your Donation Will Go

set

costumes

lighting

sound

props

advertising/publicity

rehearsal and performance stipend for actors

stipend for designers and production team

 

What you Get

FaceBook shout-outs!

A mention in the program

A show poster signed by the entire American Family team

A hand-crafted recipe book filled with favorite recipes from the cast and crew

An original painting

A hand-crochet scarf

Undying gratitude for being a theater supporter

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Understandably, not everyone has the ability to make a financial donation. But there are other ways to help:

Pass this campaign along to others you think might be interested in donating or attending the show.
 
"Like" us on FaceBook! https://www.facebook.com/anamericanfamilytakesalover
 
Talk about the show and the campaign on FaceBook, Twitter and other social media.

Thank you so, so much!
