story:
Who the heck are "The Masters of SHX" and what's this "Fool's Game" really about???

THE TRAGICAL COMICAL FOOL'S GAME is an original devised play created by a group of five MA students who studied Shakespeare & Creativity at The Shakespeare Institute in Stratford-Upon-Avon last year. It was originally performed in May 2017 in The Other Place (the Royal Shakespeare Company's studio theatre space). About an hour in length, the play is (very) loosely based on William Shakespeare's MEASURE FOR MEASURE. Following the character of Bella, an (almost) nun, the play takes us into a modern-day airport bar. Bella is waiting for a delayed flight and sipping tap water while she tries to Google "online nun classes." Shenanigans ensue as different Shakespearean characters appear and try to give Bella their two-sense about her tricky situation. But are they really in an airport? Is that man behind the bar really a bartender? Do we control our own fate? Are endings actually the end? Or are they just new beginnings? 

This July, The Masters of SHX take THE TRAGICAL COMICAL FOOL'S GAME to the Capital Fringe Festival (relocated to the SW Wharf!) for its US Premiere. With your help, we can bring THE FOOL'S GAME to new audiences in the DC-area!

(Disclaimer: You don't need to love Shakespeare to love THE FOOL'S GAME. This is a NEW play for a NEW world. It's funny, sad, heartfelt, real, and above all else, messy--just like life.)

We get by with a little help from our friends...

Good work requires good support. As a company, The Masters of SHX believe that artists deserve to be compensated for their work. While we aren't operating on a Broadway budget, we can't make this show happen for free. Furthermore, we believe in being upfront and honest about where your money will go. Here's the breakdown:

Festival Participant Fee - $585

Festival Insurance Fee - $275

Production Team Salaries (Director, Designers, Stage Manager, & Crew) - $1,150

Actor Salaries (5 actors) - $2,040

Marketing Materials (Merch, website, graphic design, postcards, posters, and programs) - $850

Merch (T-shirts, stickers, and other fun giveaways!) = $200

Sets, Props, and Costumes - $400 

*Any extra $$$ we raise will go straight to the artists!

Life is hard for a theatre kid...

We are trying to create an awesome piece of art, but there are challenges. We only have one week to rehearse together as a cast (2 of our cast members have to fly over from the UK, and all of our cast works full-time to support their passion in the arts). We've never produced a festival show before, and live performance is a notoriously hard sell. But we have assembled an incredible and diverse team to tackle these challenges. Our belief is that art makes life better. Theatre teaches us how to better connect, feel, and understand the world around us. If you agree, please consider helping us out!

For those of us who are not "rolling in the deep"...

We get it. Not everyone is flush with cash. Even if you can't contribute financially, we would love it if you could help us by getting the word out! Tell your friends, family, co-workers, and strangers on the street about THE TRAGICAL COMICAL FOOL'S GAME. Indiegogo makes it easy for you to share our project with the world. So don't be shy! If you dig what we are trying to do, help us share it with the world!

THANK YOU. THANK YOU. THANK YOU.

xoxoxo,

The Masters of SHX

story:
The Purple Crayon Players:

Since its founding in 2005, Purple Crayon Players has proudly mounted six successful seasons and tours, with our seventh on the way. In this short time, we have established ourselves as both an integral member of the theater community on Northwestern’s campus and a quality service organization in the Evanston area. In our first year as a new group on campus with a unique mission we collaborated with the classics student theater group, Lovers & Madmen, to produce Aurand Harris's Robin Goodfellow, an adaptation of A Midsummer Night's Dream. This production had a weekend of performances on campus, and toured to five schools. Since then we have built our season to include fall, winter, and spring main stage productions, a spring tour reaching hundreds of students throughout the Chicagoland community, and several additional special projects produced throughout the year. Purple Crayon Players is thrilled about how much we have grown in these short six years, and we are constantly trying to think of even more ways to bring quality theatre to young audiences.

Mission Statement:

The Purple Crayon Players is a student-run theatre company on the Northwestern University campus committed to creating high quality productions, events, and educational materials regarding all aspects of theatre for young audiences. Purple Crayon Players believes that audience of all ages can appreciate, be inspired by, and grow through exposure to this unique art form.

We produce a mainstage season of professionally written works for young audiences, while also sponsoring high quality outreach events, educational events, and special projects for audiences of all ages both on campus and in the outlying community. These events support the mainstage season, as well as explore other aspects of theatre, community service, and learning.

Purple Crayon Players feels that making theatre more accessible, in large part through our touring show as well as through events during our season, is a necessary aspect of producing theatre for young audiences. We strive to include diverse opinions, cultures, events, and voices in our season in order to adequately reflect the diverse world that our audiences and artists come from.

Furthermore, we understand the importance of training the future leaders of the TYA field, and strive to provide Northwestern University students with opportunities to direct, produce, design, perform, teach, and explore new ways of expanding the field both on campus and at large.


The Transition of Doodle Pequeño:

Doodle Pequeño and his trilingual goat, Valencia (she speaks English, Spanish, and goat) just moved to Southern California. The apartment they share with mama is packed with unopened boxes. With Halloween comes trick-or-treaters and a boy who wears dresses, Reno, like the city in Nevada. Doodle and Reno evade capture from the evil pumpkin-wielding troll, Baumgartner, and out run their nemesis, Marjoram, and her little brother, Toph all while the Santa Anna winds rap at the door. It is a comedic and honest story of two boys who become friends in spite of their differences while examining the consequences of misused language, providing insight into the lives of Mexican-immigrant children and interrogating the issues of gender-identity and homophobic bullying.

How you can help:

As a completely undergraduate group of students, we have very limited resources at our disposable to put up this incredibly important work. Any help that we can receive in the form of monetary donations will help us continue our efforts to produce high quality, exciting, engaging theatre for young audiences in Evanston.

Your donation will help tremendously in a variety of ways:

  • Purchasing lumber, paint, and boxes to construct our set.
  • Renting sound and lighting equipment.
  • Obtaining fabric and accessories for costumes.
  • Collecting props from shops and rental stores.
  • Publicity efforts as well as marketing in the Northwestern/Evanston and greater Chicago area.
  • And many other countless programming and production endeavors to help make this show a success!

The Doodle Team:

Cast

  • Doodle: Weston Jacoby
  • Baumgartner: Quinn Rattan
  • Valencia: Isabella Gerasole
  • Reno: Treyvon Thomas
  • Toph: Clayton Shuttleworth
  • Marjoram: Courtney Doyle

Production Team

  • Producer: Khari Shelton
  • Associate Producer: Taylor Dabbah
    • Assistant Producer: Abby Albrecht
  • Director: Lindsay Amer
    • Assistant Director: Maddie Napel
  • Stage Manager: Hannah Caroll
    • Assistant Stage Manager: Hannah Greene
  • Dramaturg: Collin Rice

Artistic Team

  • Set Designer: Katy Piotrowski
  • Spanish Language Consultant: Phoebe Gonzáles
  • Lighting Designer: Mari Uchida
    • Assistant Lighting Designer: Rebecca Elowe
  • Sound Designer: Grover Holloway
  • Costume Designer: Cat Chen
    • Assistant Costume Designer: Connor Samuelson
    • Costume Guide: Emily Wills
  • Props Designer: Sam Douglas
    • Assistant Props Designer: Janice Theard

Business Team

  • Fundraising Director: Louis Dietchweiler
    • Fundraising Team:
  • Publicity Director: Drew Guerra
    • Publicity Team: Phoebe Moore
  • Marketing Director: Andrea Swejk
    • Assistant Marketing Director: Kelly McCann
  • Graphic Designer: Drew Dain
  • Director of Social Media: Halima Nur
  • Videography: Shivani Chanilo
  • Director of Print Media Relations: Laken Howard

PURPLE CRAYON PLAYERS EXECUTIVE BOARD:

  • Executive Director: Juanita Anderson
  • Artistic Director: Alison Mahoney
  • Production Manager: Lucy Ahlborn
  • Business Manager: Drew Guerra
  • Outreach Coordinator: Katherine Scott
  • Literary Manager: Lisa Wiznitzer
  • Marketing Director: Emily Wills
  • Education Directors: Khari Shelton, Izzy Garcia, Nikki Resengren
  • Special Events: Nick Raef, Daphna Weinstock
  • Tour Managers: Sally Lindel, Rachel Leshin
  • Technical Director: Alex Goodman
  • Freshmen Board Representatives: Delaney Burlingame, Allie Hagen
    Thank you so much for your support. Your contribution is a part of making impacting art for young audiences.

    Sincerely,
    Khari Shelton,

    Producer

    TheTransitionOfDoodleNU@gmail.com

We strive to include diverse opinions, cultures, events, and voices in our season in order to adequately reflect the diverse world that our audiences and artists come from.Furthermore, we understand the importance of training the future leaders of the TYA field, and strive to provide Northwestern University students with opportunities to direct, produce, design, perform, teach, and explore new ways of expanding the field both on campus and at large.The Transition of Doodle Pequeño:Doodle Pequeño and his trilingual goat, Valencia (she speaks English, Spanish, and goat) just moved to Southern California. The apartment they share with mama is packed with unopened boxes. With Halloween comes trick-or-treaters and a boy who wears dresses, Reno, like the city in Nevada. Doodle and Reno evade capture from the evil pumpkin-wielding troll, Baumgartner, and out run their nemesis, Marjoram, and her little brother, Toph all while the Santa Anna winds rap at the door. It is a comedic and honest story of two boys who become friends in spite of their differences while examining the consequences of misused language, providing insight into the lives of Mexican-immigrant children and interrogating the issues of gender-identity and homophobic bullying.How you can help:As a completely undergraduate group of students, we have very limited resources at our disposable to put up this incredibly important work. Any help that we can receive in the form of monetary donations will help us continue our efforts to produce high quality, exciting, engaging theatre for young audiences in Evanston.Your donation will help tremendously in a variety of ways:
Purchasing lumber, paint, and boxes to construct our set.
Renting sound and lighting equipment.
Obtaining fabric and accessories for costumes.
Collecting props from shops and rental stores.
Publicity efforts as well as marketing in the Northwestern/Evanston and greater Chicago area.
And many other countless programming and production endeavors to help make this show a success!
The Doodle Team:Cast

story:
LOST IN LVOV

Written, Created, Performed by Sandy Simona Levitan

Directed by Marina McClure

In Collaboration with Caitlyn Conlin's Storytelling Band

February 21st & 22nd at 8:30PM

Highways Performance Space

Los Angeles, California

Lost in Lvov, is a multimedia storytelling love letter to the most private immigration stories from my family, and many Russian-Jewish families, just like mine, who left The Soviet Union before and after Perestroika---immigrating to tiny pockets, city blocks and suburb communities all over the United States. We  grew up awkwardly influenced and hungry to be part of our new cultures and communities. Most of the time, living in fear and confusion of our new home.

Their memories left behind implanted in pockets and shelves in their brains, burned in photos they set on fire, and taken to their new homes with Soviet trinkets and recipes they passed down to their grandchildren.

Lost in Lvov, is based on true interviews and events of the Belman Sisters: My Mom, Inessa, and her two sisters, Alla and Anna.

As a child, I kept track of various secretive stories,  first hand experiences,anecdotes, songs and eavesdropping from childhood BBQs, dinner parties, late night kitchen conversations, arguments, debates, weddings, funerals, and long walks around the suburbs of Fair Lawn, New Jersey..busy concrete streets of New York City...or under the  loud railroad tracks on winter afternoons  between west coast visits in the depths of Brooklyn.

This piece blossomed when I moved across the country to Los Angeles to pursue my MFA in Acting & Performance at California Institute of the Arts.  Many home sick nights I recalled their faces,sacrifices, and stories. I mused on what it mean to be a daughter of one of the last immigrant generations like that of my parents.

As I watched the generations of women (and men) in my family unravel, blossom, break apart, fall in and out of love, lose life to illness or time-- I became extremely intrigued and committed to capture these moments of humanity into poetry, dance, music and  live performed short stories.

Now in collaboration with many CalArts Alumni across disciplines and generations:

The Storytelling band, lead by Caitlyn Conlin

https://www.facebook.com/storytellingband?hc_location=timeline 

Award-winning Theater Director Marina McClure 

http://www.marinamcclure.com/

We bring you the next phase of  Lost in Lvov!  Highways Performance Space. http://highwaysperformance.org/highways/

Performed with elements of dance, clown, puppetry, live music, and  home video and film-- a unique evening awaits!

Impact & Mission

My mission is to create a surprise party artistic experience for performers and audience. I create magical, miracle, colorful, cultural, international, funky, spicy, atmospheric artistic experiences. I value and worship a place to play, create, heal, manifest and imagine. My purpose is to be a leader in the playground, a healer in the heart ground, and the inspiration of deep-impossible ideas. Manifesting our childlike voices and dreams into artistic reality and experiences.


What We Need & What You Get

The Arts  come to life, breathe, grow, develop and manifest primarily from humble beautiful, donations, support of friends, family, community and human beings who believe and understand the importance  of the Arts.  

Any type of Art you have ever seen or experienced, has come to life because of donations, fundraisers, and generosity of the public.Especially to those of you who are not able to come see my show live in person, imagine your donation as a virtual ticket to help bring my show to life so that one day I can bring my show to a city near you :)

I am not only producing and remounting my piece, " Lost in Lvov," but I am also collaborating with The Storytelling Band, as well as producing and curating the ENTIRE weekend of Russian-Jewish Artists Los Angeles. What a beautiful and amazing undertaking, I think!!! I am ready for this challenge but need your help. Being a solo performer is not as easy it seems---my work will not come to life with color, passion and vibrance ----if it were not for the amazing collaborators who are donating their time and talent to help me bring my dream into a reality.

The money I am raising is to help me cover the specific costs of my piece--so that I may have funds to not only put the piece up beautifully with proper equipment and resources--but also have funds to pay my collaborators for the time artistry.

$700 Musicians compensation

$500 Director/ Designer compensation

$350 Technical Direction / Equipment Rental/Props/Costume Fees

$450  Live Video Documentation & Edits

$ Any additional funds raised will be used toward applications and proposal packages to National and International  Festivals and a National tour to a city near you! (NYC, San Francisco, and Minneapolis are on my short list!)

Other Ways You Can Help

Any donation is helpful. No matter how big or small.  If you can not donate financially you can help by:

SPREADING THE WORD and pass this on via email/social networks/meditation...whatever your heart's desire!

Is there someone at your job or in your family who you think may be super supportive of Russian-Jewish-Multimedia-Original-Self Produced-Storytelling-Theater? Send this to them!

Have an influx of GIFT CARDS from the Holidays? You can donate those via direct mail. Gift Cards can be used as an alternate way to donate and compensate Artists.

Do you have access to projectors or tech equipment at a discount rate in Los Angeles? That can be a helpful donation by helping us find affordable gear to use for the weekend.

Are you a Photographer? You can help by documenting footage for as much or as little of the event. Wohoo!

Last but not least...just by reading this ALL, you have helped. Thank you for taking the time. I have love and gratitude for you.

story:
Short Summary

Edmonton’s newest burlesque theatre company, Send in the Girls Burlesque brings the corset-ripping story of Henry VIII to the stage Part basement burlesque show, part sexy and scintillating historical thriller, Tudor Queens: A Burlesque marries the art form of burlesque with the medium of theatre to tell the gruesome downfall of six of England’s most legendary queen consorts.

Trapped together in purgatory, the six queens of the house of Tudor are forced to retell their story over and over. As they strip away their royal robes, they strip fact from fiction and slowly piece together their collective existence as wives to the one of the most famous and bloody kings in England’s history.

Made up of Edmonton theatre artists turned burlesque beauties, Send in the Girls Burlesque is a collective concerned with matching the performance style of burlesque with the narrative of theatre to create burlesque that tells a story and goes a step above the usual bump and grind.

The 2013 Canoe Festival is an excellent opportunity for us, however we need financial support inorder to bring our show to this festival. Help us launch Tudor Queens beyond fringe.  We want to revamp the script and design elements in order to create an even more incredible show and experience for the audience. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $2,000 to put into design. Our old costumes from the 2011 Fringe run got pretty shabby and were fairly cheap and our set had to be dismantled in order to save money.  We want to amp up our production values and elevate the look of the show.  The Queens may be dead but that doesn't mean they can't look magical. 

Perks: 

Curtsey- $10- The Queens will sing your praises on Send in the Girls' Facebook page. 

Royal Favour- $25- The queens will send you a commorative photo and declare their gratitude on facebook.

Token of the Queen's Affection- $75-  A Hair Flower made by Queen Kitty Howard and of course a harmony of praises on Facebook.

Crown Jewels- $100- A 2013 Calendar of Send in the Girls Burlesque and a personal thank you letter from Queen Kitty Howard. 

White Knight- $250- A Calendar, A Hair flower by Kitty Howard, A Photo of the Queens and A Personal Thank You Letter. 

 

The Impact

Help us make the show better amd go beyond Fringe Glory.  We are a team of indie artists and need your help in order to fund our future endevors. 

 

What Critics and Audience members said about our last run of Tudor Queens: 

“This show hooks you with sex appeal, but then surprises with real, raw emotion, dramatic tension and first-class acting chops. Polished, world-class burlesque it's not. It's better, because of the emotional commitment of the performers and the clever, saucy script, and because it's a powerful celebration of sensuality and the female form, in all its shapes and sizes. And while the scantily-clad performers gyrate and demure, what impresses you most is not just their hotness, but their brains behind all the glitter. Now, that's burlesque. (Five Stars)”Edmonton’s Vue Weekly

“The Tudor Queens Burlesque is exactly the kind of experience I always hope to find at the fringe. Never have I experienced it executed so perfectly.” Audience Member

“the packed house loved what they could see, judging by the catcalls and applause” Edmonton Journal

“Long live the queens!” Online Reviewer

 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please come see Tudor Queens: A Burlesque in the 2013 Canoe Festival in Edmonton.  Feel free to share our campaign through social media.  Help the Tudor Queens reign again.

story:
What are we supporting?

Off-Strip Productions, an independent non-profit (501c3) theatrical production company, is planning an innovative, in-your-face production of Stephen Sondheim's Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street through the month of October at the Onyx, Las Vegas' premiere arthouse theatre. (Check out some recent press from the LV Review Journal)

What makes this production so innovative?  Well, we don't want to give too much away, but doing a fully staged version (not a concert) in our intimate 96-seat arthouse theatre will create the parlor musical feel that this show was originally intended to have.  You, the audience, will be among the ghosts of Fleet Street as we unravel this chilling tale together.  This interactive quality will make the show even more terrifying and hilarious - exactly what a musical thriller should be.

Here at Off-Strip, we are well aware of what a huge venture this is.  That's why we need your help.  This production will jump start the rest of our Affordable Broadway series.  Please join us in creating a new standard, a higher expectation, and an affordable option for local lovers of quality entertainment in Las Vegas. 
 

Why $8,000? 

Off-Strip is heading in a new direction with unique approaches to household names in musical theatre.  We will continue to bring you the cult titles; however, Las Vegas theatre-goers want to see the classics and hits as well.  Shows like Sweeney Todd, Cabaret, and Damn Yankees or more modern Broaday hits like Wild Party, The Last Five Years, and Next to Normal would make for beautiful productions in our intimate space. 

But shows like this cost money.  To produce Sweeney Todd, for instance...

  1. The rights alone will cost us over $2000 plus book rental fees for a three week run. 
  2. Live music is a must for this show.  Professional musicians who make a living in the field will be practically donating their time to help us create the sound this intricate musical requires, but given union stipulations, but they can not do it for free. 
  3. Of course these shows require sets, costumes, and props - roughly $2,000 worth. 
  4. And, please, let's not forget about the talented cast and crew.  Actors, designers, builders, and technicians all must take time out of their lives and often other jobs to put in the kind of work required for a professional quality show.  We would like to reward them for their work, and we know you will too. 
  5. All of this, plus the cost of advertizing will put us in the &8,000 - $10,000 range for total prduction costs.

If we don't raise the goal, the show will go on - Off-Strip's Sweeney Todd is going to be a great production.  But we don't want this venture to end with Sweeney.  With your generous donations, our box office sales can comfortably roll over into the next production, creating an even more stunning and higher quality theatre experience next time, and so on.  Our ticket prices, on the other hand, will remain affordable.

If we go over, even better!  It will all be used for the same purpose - to create professional quality theatre in Las Vegas that is accessible to everyone.

The Impact

In addition to creating affordable entertainment, your support of Off-Strip Productions means a stronger theatre community in Las Vegas on the whole.  We often collaborate with other theatre groups in town as well, giving them an opportunity to do those projects that artists love to see, do, and be a part of.  Original works, edgy and unique stagings, workshops: this is how great art is created.  And a thriving theatre offers those opportunies.  By broadening our fan base, we create a wider audience for those up and coming projects as well.  Your contribution will encourage the arts in this diversely talented community.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, perhaps there's something you can do.  But everyone has their own unique talents and abilities.  Call us at 702-333-6698 or e-mail us at contact@onyxtheatre.com for details on more ways you can make this production, this venue, and this community a success.  And thank you!
 

IN CLOSING

This is an exciting Project and we want to keep you updated regularly.  Please check back frequently to see what's new with our production.  And thanks again.
